Those people have been directly affected since the notorious events of 16 December, when we saw the coalition actually support the legislation and cause panic and uncertainty for financial advisers, people who had made some attempt to be partly self-sufficient in their retirement and those who had invested in Australia's future.

PARA.TAB: Since that time, financial advisers have been confused and concerned. The Department of Social Security has been confused and concerned. I suggest that the Minister would be interested to know that when pensioners have contacted the Department of Social Security, asking how this measure will be administered, how the assessments will be made, what will be deemed, by whom, at what date and with what effect, those very pensioners have been unable to get proper answers from the Department of Social Security, which has been confused about the administration of this matter. The pensioners themselves have remained confused and concerned.

It could well be that many pensioners, as has been observed to me in writing by several astute pensioners, having done what Senator Coulter suggested might happen—and as Senator Lees mentioned in her contribution to this debate on 16 December as likely to happen—have thought about this and some have considered investing in foreign companies, be they companies such as IBM, Feltex, Fletcher Challenge or whatever, or be they British companies. There have been people who have taken their much needed extra capital from Australia and invested it in foreign companies. That effect is starting to happen. On the strength of that, any examination by the Government of the effect of this measure would probably show that it is revenue neutral: we are going to lose as much as we are going to gain. It is going to cost us as much to administer it as we will gain, or even more.

The Labor Party should really have another look at this and say, `Is this going to achieve what we aim to achieve? Are we actually going to save a couple of bucks on the pension? Are we actually going to save any money, or is it going to cost us a heap to administer it?'. A few astute pensioners have pointed out to me that the chances are that it would be pretty close to revenue neutral. I imagine that the Government should be pretty keen to get rid of this from the books, anyway.

As far as notice is concerned, and with regard to knowing what is going on and being aware of this legislation, on 16 December the argument was well rehearsed. Senator Lees, in her contribution to the debate in this place on that date, made sure that honourable senators all knew and were fully informed about what the effect of this was. In spite of that full exposition by Senator Lees, the coalition decided in favour of a faulty strategy, to vote with the Government. I would have thought that honourable senators who then were interested in the debate would have informed themselves by looking at Senator Lees's speech at that time. That speech, by the way, incorporated a large slice of the dissenting, minority report made by Senator Kernot when the matter was considered by the Senate committee. Anybody who then wanted to be informed on the matter could have read that, yet we still have people claiming that they needed a bit of notice.

Notice was given by me. On 26 March I wrote to all coalition senators and said, amongst other things, quite simply, that Parliament would meet again in May and I would ensure that repealing legislation was introduced as soon as possible. Here it is. I have introduced it as soon as possible. I asked in my letter to all coalition senators, `What will your position be?'. Six people had the courtesy to respond and state what their position would be. All of them stated that they were uncertain about what their position would be; I was not surprised by that. But I got six replies.

I did give warning. As a matter of fact, I wrote letters to all of Australia's major newspapers. The matter was reported in the Australian Financial Review and my letter was printed there. I had my first experience on the ABC program First Edition; I must say that it was a novelty for me to get up so early in the morning and sit there explaining the whole situation. It was enlightening for those who watched, because a sleepy Bell is not the flashest thing around. But I did explain the whole thing at that time on television and on national radio—ad nauseam, as far as I was concerned. Anybody who did not hear it could not have been interested in the issue. It was in the Australian Financial Review; it was in all the newspapers. I have written to pensioners groups about this and this has been going on since that notorious incident on 16 December. That annoyed me so much that I have exposed it wherever and whenever possible.

What we have here is an indication that there have been some people who are not really interested in it, because they have not been paying attention to the debate, and other people who actually want to get on and change it. Those who want to get on and change it are to be admired, congratulated and supported by me.

In conclusion, I want to say something about the effect of this, and this was hinted at by Senator Coulter. I wrote to the Financial Review, and I think to the Melbourne Herald-Sun, about the matter of the investment community's anticipated enthusiasm for the launch of Woolworths onto the Australian stock market. In writing to the newspapers about that float, I made the observation, and I think it should be taken on board by the Government, that, as with the partial float of the Commonwealth Bank, the sorts of investors who are attracted to longstanding institutions—major retailers in Australia and major components of our economy such as the Commonwealth Bank—and who are relied upon to take up a significant proportion of that float, are the so-called mums and dads of the investment community.

I warned in my communication on this matter that the mums and dads will not be there in this Woolworths float. The mums and dads are the very people to whom such an investment will be most unattractive because of what this Government has done and because of what the coalition has done in supporting the Government. I think there is an urgency to pay regard to that and not to distort our financial community by removing such a significant and relied upon component of major floats.

I am not suggesting that it be done for the benefit of the Woolworths float, but I am suggesting that the further selling or abrogation of responsibility by the Government is typical. The further 19 per cent sale of the Commonwealth Bank will be affected in exactly the same way. They are the two significant factors which I think the perpetrators of this penny-pinching crime against pensioners were obviously not fully cognisant of. However, they jolly well should have been because it has a huge effect. As Senator Coulter said, and quite rightly, a clear, strong indication should be given today to those who are interested in this area. It can be given when we vote on the second reading.

Senator Lees and I understand the concern for the procedures of the Senate and for the disruptions. I do not apologise for any of that. This matter had been well worn and well rehearsed when we brought it in here today. Senator Lees and I believe that, while paying some regard to the propriety of conventions here, conventions need to be kicked occasionally, not for the sake of not being boring but for the sake of getting something done. We are actually trying to resolve this situation. If it means that at a later date, not too far hence, we need a committee stage and a third reading stage, that is fine. But let us get it clear now what is going on here today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—While I understand what Senator Chamarette and Senator Harradine said earlier, I do not think the Government is in any position to accede to the honourable senators' wishes. If we do, I think we will get rolled, and one wonders whether it is worth another procedural vote. I would suggest that it is not. I think we should wrap up the second reading today—I will make some remarks on the issue before that—and proceed to the third reading next week. That is probably the only course of action left to us.

PARA.TAB: I have to say to the Senate that I have not yet read Senator Patterson's brilliant contribution, as she suggests. I shall do so and attempt to answer it next week—that is, if there are any points she has raised in that contribution that are not covered in the note I was given this morning. I will go into some explanation on this question of foreign shares which has been raised today by both Senator Coulter and Senator Bell. Hopefully, I can go into some more detail next week.

I want to come to why we are here. When income and assets tests are designed for a pension system such as ours, the design is done with equity in mind. It is not always perfect; it is not always easy, but that has to be the underlying principle. The assets and income test that pensioners now must face has stood the test of time pretty well. We managed to get it pretty right when we first introduced it and, over time, when anomalies have come up we have acted to get rid of them. That is all that this legislation does. What we had was a situation where pensioners could be treated better by investing in shares than by, say, putting money into managed investments. All that we have sought to do in this legislation is to make sure that, no matter what the pensioner might care to invest in, he or she can expect the same treatment. So one investment is not better than another; they are all supposed to be treated the same.

While it has been claimed that those who are pensioners with shares are being singled out, I think the real truth is the exact opposite. For a number of years shares have been treated concessionally. In the past, pensioners who have had shares have been able to be treated singly, and now that anomaly disappears. What the change does is bring the treatment of shares into line with the treatment of most other kinds of investments. For example, equity trusts where people invest in shares indirectly should be treated—

TALK.START.PARA: —Land.
—I am sorry; I missed that. This is a big chamber; I am not used to being here. It will take a while to get the ears working.
—What about antique clocks?

—I am not sure how many pensioners own them. I suspect that, of Australia's l.4 million pensioners, there are not too many worried about the price of antique clocks. I am certainly not. To get back to what I was attempting to say, however: if we look at equity trusts, where in fact people invest in shares indirectly, there is absolutely no reason why pensioners who are in those now should be treated differently from those who invest in shares directly through the share market.

PARA.TAB: It has been suggested that it is also unfair to assess unrealised capital gains. We have to look at what has been underlying the assets tests since they began, and that is that those pensioners with assets are able, if they choose to do so, to realise them. The problem is for those without assets. They are going to be treated pretty unfairly if we simply allow the accumulation of assets by those who have got the resources to accumulate them. The gains represent an increase in resources that can be used by pensioners to provide income support for themselves if they so wish. If we are going to have a needs based social security system—and that is what we have got—it is only fair that they utilise those gains before they call on the taxpayers to give them support.

It does not mean, as I think Senator Bell and Senator Coulter were suggesting, that shares suddenly become a bad investment for pensioners. What it does mean is that the pensioner-friendly treatment of shares will be removed so that investment in shares is based on the intrinsic merit of the investment and not on some concessional treatment by the Department of Social Security. It means that pensioners who invest in shares do not have an advantage over those who are using their savings to generate some income rather than simply generating unrealised capital growth.

Whether pensioners do sell shares to access this growth and supplement their income or whether they just retain the growth as an increase in the value of their investment will be a personal choice, but taxpayers should not be called on to provide a higher level of income support than necessary to such people if they choose not to utilise the gains. I doubt very much that all pensioners will sell their shares, as is being claimed today. They are not all going to race out and sell their shares. Some of those pensioners have been holding them for decades and they have held them through all sorts of changes in the way shares were treated before they were pensioners. They are not going to change the way they do business now.

The rules that will apply to shares have applied to most managed investments for five years. A pensioner with funds in a managed investment knew that there would be gains taken into account and that his pension would be reduced accordingly. Over that time, some 128,000 pensioners have invested in managed investments on the basis of their merit as an investment. Those 128,000 pensioners have managed to do it with managed investments, and we will find that those who hold shares will do exactly the same thing. Let me tell the Senate the numbers so that we get the argument into some perspective. There are about 60,000 Department of Social Security pensioners and about 24,000 Veterans' Affairs pensioners affected by this change. Overall, less than 3 per cent of the pensioner population will be affected. I hope this debate does not become a replica of the first assets test debate nearly a decade ago, when the Opposition sought to frighten all pensioners although only a tiny percentage of them were ever going to be affected.

It also has to be noted that those most affected are those with large shareholdings. Some pensioners have $100,000 invested in shares. When the vast majority of pensioners have nothing invested in shares and precious little invested in anything else, we have to ask ourselves whether it is fair for pensioners with $100,000 invested in shares to be able to avoid any kind of pressure to realise any of the gains. If they choose not to realise the gains, should the people with absolutely nothing have to subsidise them? The Government came to the conclusion that the answer to that was, clearly, no. Pensioners with a small number of shares—and that is the vast number of the 60,000 who are affected anyway—are hardly going to be affected. The change is not going to affect them to any significant extent.

Savings of some $80 million in a full year are going to be raised by this measure. I think that $44 million was claimed by the Opposition, but I am advised that the savings in a full year will be $80 million. That amount of money deserves serious consideration. I would think it is in the interests of all pensioners, when that kind of money is available to be collected from those who have been treated concessionally over the years, to want to see the Government do it.

We can be judged by what we do to help those who are in the greatest need. That includes the increase in pensions that was provided in January of this year and the extension of eligibility for fringe benefits that was implemented in April to pay for those kinds of measures. The money does not come out of the air. It has to come from somewhere. I cannot think of too many more appropriate places than this place. Over 50 per cent of pensioners affected by the share change will benefit from the change I have just mentioned, receiving benefits of up to $20 a week. Pensioners with shares will benefit also from the accompanying measure to allow reductions in the value of shares to be offset against gains on shares or managed investments.

I am not certain whether these matters are to be raised in Senator Patterson's as yet unread speech, but there was a press release from Mr Ruddock yesterday in which he raised a number of matters that I think ought to be cleared up. Firstly, he claimed that pensioners will redirect their savings to overseas shares because the change does not apply to those shares. But, of course, it does. In saying that it applies to overseas shares, it should also be noted—as I am sure Senator Coulter and Senator Bell would be well aware—that there are not too many pensioners with great company structures set up in the tax havens of the world to avoid taxes. It is not going to be a difficult task to locate the vast majority of those who seek to do it and to take it into account.

Secondly, there is a claim that the measure will impact on the floating of shares in public enterprises. Senator Bell has added his weight, if that is the correct term, to this by referring to the Woolworths float which is about to take place. But, as I said previously, the change will ensure that pensioners wishing to invest in shares make their decision based on the intrinsic merit of the investment, not on any concessional treatment.

I for one would not be prepared to say that there is no intrinsic merit in investing in a Woolworths float. Woolworths is a great company and its management has achieved such an increase in market share in the course of the last decade, to the detriment of some very well-known competitors, that it would be difficult to see pensioners walking away from the intrinsic merit of that investment.

There has also been a lot of comment about the method that will be used to implement the measure. Most of that comment is based on a misunderstanding of the way in which the income test works in practice and has worked for years. That method has been endorsed as the appropriate way of operating the income test by the High Court. The basic principle is that the income test is intended to measure the financial resources available to a person at a given point in time. It does not and it should not assess past dollar gains or compensate for past dollar losses.

It ought to be noted that pensioners with shares are around five per cent of all shareholders. Most of them have got small holdings. It ought not be the case that pensioners who have had experience with these investments for years are simply going to run away because of a change in the treatment. It will make the investments marginally less attractive but it will make the tests that are applied to pensioners more equitable across all pensioners—those who have got the funds to invest in shares and the vast majority of pensioners, the 97 per cent, who have not.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I regret in some ways that we have had to debate the Social Security Amendment (Listed Securities) Bill in this way, on the second reading speech. It has occurred as a result of, maybe, some misunderstanding between the Democrats and me about the order in which the formal motions were put this morning. We did not actually run in the order on the paper and I think Senator Bell thought that I had jumped to my feet a little earlier than he had. He missed the fact that Senator Tierney had actually moved his formal motion, the President was looking around to see whether there was another formal motion and I stood. That was not meant to gazump Senator Bell, but that was the way it may have been interpreted.

PARA.TAB: I find it interesting that Senator Bell has entered this debate at this stage. Obviously he got some pressure from some pensioners during the election campaign, but he did not speak on this Bill when it was going through before. We had been having negotiations with Senator Lees's office about the passage of our two Bills and we had hoped that we would have a smooth passage of them, being able to debate this Bill in a manner which gave the Independents time to see it. But that was not what happened and we are now in the second reading stage.

I reject the comments that the Democrats made about our having had some sort of vision on the road to Damascus and changed our view about this. When I spoke on this Bill, taking the Bill through on behalf of the then shadow Minister, Mr Connolly, I expressed our concern and said that after the election we would be looking at reviewing that Bill. We were not in the position to review it from government but we decided that, since we had made that commitment, we would review it from opposition. That is the reason we have taken this action.

The Democrats have said that we should have done so at the time, but it was in an omnibus Bill and there was a gun being held at our heads that, if we did not agree with this, the other benefits flowing from the measures in the rest of the Bill would not go ahead. So we were in a cleft stick, or between a rock and a hard place. Because that provision was not coming in until September 1993, we agreed with that part of the Bill in order that the other benefits would flow, and gave a commitment to review it. So I reject the assertion that Senator Bell makes, that we had not actually taken an interest in this and were not concerned about it. We expressed concern and I expressed concern in that speech.

I listened to what the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, had to say. I believe that there ought to be a total review, so that equity is established; but patching it up or trying to do things in the way he has done does not make it equitable. I do not agree with all his assertions that people will not change. Also, there are other pensioners coming on stream, many of them with superannuation payouts that are not sufficient to live on but are sufficient to invest. They will be discouraged from doing it.

We also have to look at the future. I do not believe, nor do many other people in the community believe, that the Government will make the savings that the Minister claims. Let me say that the social security department has had a very poor record on estimating what gains it will have, and Senator Richardson knows that. I will not reiterate them all here in the chamber, though I could; but the department has been a long way off the mark in its predictions of savings, and so has the Health Insurance Commission. For predictions of savings, I would give the Department of Social Security about two out of 10 at the moment—not a pass—so I do not believe the savings in this. I believe the Minister needs to put a much better argument. He needs to put up a review of the whole area, because there are anomalies. We know about the Auditor-General's report on land. Is the Government going to look at unrealised gains on land? Is it going to look at unrealised gains on art works? The Government needs to get its house in order and make sure that we have some standard and that we have some equity in the system.

I would also like to take Senator Richardson up on the fact that he said this will come on next Wednesday. There are a lot of older people who are affected. Despite the fact that the Minister says the figure is only five per cent, there are a number of them. He makes out that they seem to be the rich, but they may be the more frugal: those who have saved and saved and saved to have that $100,000 to invest. He should not make out they are running around with huge amounts of money. Some of those people have been very frugal and put that aside through their savings, and that is what we are trying to encourage Australians to do. We need every bit of saving we can get in this country. I hope that the Minister will bring it on as he has promised on Wednesday so that we can deal with this issue and so that there can be some predictability for those pensioners who have been concerned about this issue.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the Bill in Committee of the Whole be an order of the day for 12 May 1993.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:

(1)That the orders relating to consideration of appropriation bills in committee of the whole and the powers of estimates committees, contained in the discussion paper on estimates committees and appropriation bills presented by the Procedure Committee on 19 December 1991, be adopted.
(2)That the recommendation at page 5 of the committee's first report of 1992 relating to the titles of office-holders be adopted.

(3)That the recommendation at page 2 of the committee's second report of 1992 for an amendment of Standing Order 61 to operate on a trial basis for the remainder of this period of sittings be adopted.
(4)That the amendments of the standing orders in the third report of 1992 relating to the vacation of the office of the President be adopted.
(5)That the Senate take note of the remainder of the reports and discussion paper.
(6)That resolution (1) come into effect on the first day of sitting in August 1993, has effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders and is of continuing effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not got the motion in front of me.
—It is on the Notice Paper.

—Yes, but I think the Minister said that it had been circulated. I do not think it has been. I have got several concerns regarding this particular change to the procedure. To begin with, it sets out very clearly that the Senate will never again have the right to debate the reports of the Senate committees. I cannot imagine why the Government would want to cause that to occur except that it seems imbued with a sense of power over there, even though it has got only 30 senators in the new Parliament. We will have 36. It still believes that the estimates committees should not be entitled to full debate about expenditure and what goes on in the estimates committees. We have in the past had a watered down system that the Government does not seem to think has worked. It is still wanting to cut time. I know that some of my colleagues would agree with that and would be voting the opposite way to me on that issue.

PARA.TAB: I foreshadow an amendment to the motion that the Committee of the Whole should be permitted to debate the committee reports in the Senate. In that amendment I am not looking to debate all the expenditure in the Estimates. I have a feeling that Senator McMullan may agree with me in the end.

TALK.START.PARA: —Be more explicit about that.

—I am just about to be. I am not asking for all expenditure to be debated. I am not asking for all the parts of the motion to be debated. But in the past we have had reports chastising a department for late answers, for wrong answers or whatever. All sorts of comments come up in the report from an estimates committee that must be brought to the attention of the Senate. There is nowhere for them to go if they are not. So if the estimates committee believes that the department has been obstructive, it says so in its report. If the committee believes that perhaps the chairman has not carried out the full obligations of the chairmanship as the committee believes they should have been carried out, that can be contained in the report.

PARA.TAB: If the report cannot be debated in the Senate, there is absolutely no place for it to go so that the Senate as a whole can agree or disagree, as the case may be, with the report and say that the department was negligent in doing whatever the report claims it has done. I believe it is very important that those reports of Senate committees not be disregarded, as is presently suggested by the Government's motion that we are looking at. That is only one of the many concerns I have but that is one to which I foreshadow moving an amendment.

The other thing is that, since this Government has been in power, many of the rights of honourable senators have been taken away. We used to be able to speak for an hour. Some people would remember Senator Cavanagh. On a very technical Bill, when he and Senator Wright were in the Senate, an hour was a more appropriate time for people of that quality to debate a Bill. I am sure that the Deputy President would remember many occasions when Senator Cavanagh and Senator Wright were debating something. They often tangled in the Senate. Those debates would take considerable time, and rightly so. As a result of a speech going for over half an hour, some good amendments would come out of the debate.

But that time has been cut from an hour to half an hour. Our estimates committee procedures in the Senate have been cut considerably. Many of the rights that honourable senators had previously have been cut. We are gradually getting to the stage where the Government says that we cannot even debate the estimates committee report. That is over the fence. We know that the Australian Labor Party does not approve of the Senate, to begin with. It has had that in its policy for many years. While it is no longer in the written policy, Senator Coates, Senator Evans and many others on that side say that it is of no value. Indeed, Mr Keating has said that there is no value in having a Senate. That would put all the power into the hands of the Prime Minister of the day, and that is where the Australian Labor Party, when it has been in power, has said it should be.

It has to be understood that the Government does not have the numbers in the upper house. Therefore, it must respond to the wishes of the Senate, not of the Executive Government. It is most important that the Senate does not allow the Government to take away the right to debate reports of the estimates committees here. At the moment, it is allowing only amendments and requests to be debated and is refusing to allow debate on the reports themselves.

In my view, the downgrading of the Committee of the Whole is wrong—and this has nothing to do, let me stress, with my amendment. It ought to be maintained as it is—but then I was disappointed when it was changed from the original intention and procedure to what it is at the moment. Again, I am disappointed that the intention of the Government is to downgrade that even further and not allow a full debate. I know some of my colleagues disagree with me on that particular issue, but I am sure that they would agree that the report itself should be debated, and that they will not give up gladly the opportunity of debating the committee report. I hope the Government agrees that is an important thing to abide by and will agree with my amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters, you mentioned an amendment, but I do not know if you formally moved it.
—I foreshadowed that I would be moving it, Mr Deputy President. I have not got it in my hand at the moment but I will circulate it in a few minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the motion and to support Senator Walters's foreshadowed amendment. The abolition of the Committee of the Whole is but a further step in reducing the capacity of the Senate to scrutinise the expenditure and outlays of Australian taxpayers' funds. It will be argued that the debate of the Committee of the Whole which has thus far taken place will be transferred to the supplementary or additional debates of the estimates committees. Of course, that is just not the case. There is a vast distinction between debating in this chamber and the questioning of Ministers here and that of inquiring of them certain information in the estimates committees. It is not only a truth in reality, it is also a truth in perception.

PARA.TAB: It is not without consequence to observe the distinct difference in the demeanour and attitude of Ministers when they are being asked questions in this chamber, from that in the estimates committees. Very rarely can a Minister sustain the position of simply refusing to answer questions put to him or her in this chamber for any length of time. In the estimates committees, however, if the Minister thinks that a question does not deserve a response, there have been numerous occasions when they have declined to answer the question and suggested the questioner move on to the next item. Also, while a chairman presides over the meetings, contributions are made by a number of other senators, invariably because of the multiple combinations of political parties of partisan persuasion. So the general conduct, the general environment and the general attitude in the estimates committees are vastly different from those of the Committee of the Whole.

The effect of abolishing the Committee of the Whole would be, of course, to limit the debate. I have always had the view that it is a fundamental trampling upon the democratic processes and the functioning of the Parliament to reduce the speaking time available to members and senators. I have never supported the reduction in speaking time on any occasion and I shall not be doing that in the future. I think it is fundamentally wrong in principle for any member or senator to make a judgment—which is inevitably subjective—about the quality of the debate and the contribution and the relevance of the debate of any other member or senator.

If that is to be the case, the strength of that argument can only be sustained by moving a gag in this chamber. The fact is that there is grave reluctance to do this on the part of any particular political party, except in extreme circumstances. Invariably, that only prevails at the end of the session when we are running into a deadline and there are a number of Bills to get through. There has always been a grave reluctance on the part of any political party to move a motion to deny any member or senator speaking time. The reason for that grave reluctance is because it is an imposition on one of the fundamental purposes for which senators are elected to this chamber.

I note on page 7 of the report, `Estimates Committees and Appropriations Bills', 19 December 1991, under option (4) it is suggested that these additional hearings could be held outside the Senate's sitting times, but the sitting of the Senate could be suspended to allow the hearings to take place if the Senate's program of business allowed. The report goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It would be open to the Committees to prescribe in advance specified time limits for the hearings.

Given the quite natural partisan nature of estimates committees where there are those on the committee seeking to scrutinise—for altruistic or political purposes, probing and testing and questioning—we have an equal number, on some occasions, who see their primary function to preserve the Government and to protect the Minister. So to suggest that these additional committee hearings would have a specified time limit would, of course, be at the behest and at the pleasure of the majority and the majority inevitably would be the Government. So we are making a partisan decision about the level of contribution that the chamber as a whole can make.

PARA.TAB: There is some question as to whether or not the Bills would proceed past the second reading stage prior to the supplementary hearings. On page 8 under the heading, `Progress of the appropriation bills', it is claimed:

SPEECH.PARA: After the second reading, the further stages of the proceedings on the bills could be adjourned until the supplementary hearings had concluded, and the bills could then be speedily passed
It would be open to the Senate, as it is under the current procedures, to pass the appropriation Bills before the estimates committees had concluded their deliberations.

PARA.TAB: Of course, that has the effect of formalising the marginalising of the supplementary hearings and, inevitably, unless there are amendments or requests regarding the appropriation Bills, the legislation will proceed through the chamber to its conclusion while the additional estimates committee meetings are being held. So they will be marginalised and once they are marginalised their irrelevancy will become apparent and the purpose of pursuing them will, of course, diminish.

I note that under `preferred option' the committee observes that it believes that these proposals will overcome the problems identified in this paper without diminishing the rights of senators or the ability of the Senate to scrutinise thoroughly the Estimates and appropriation Bills. I have to say, with respect, that is an absolute nonsense. I can see no justification for that argument. The truth of the matter is that these proposals are not intended to make the process more efficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did your representative support them?
—We have healthy debates over here.
—Because they thought they improved them, and they were right.
—Again, that is a subjective judgment.
—Of course it is; so is yours.

—Of course it is. But for the time being, I am prosecuting my argument. We have healthy debate over here. I do not recall the last time I saw any Labor senator cross the floor on debates on Standing Orders, notwithstanding the fact that convention has it that it is a free vote. Senator Ray always used to proudly skite that it was a free vote over there, but that they all had the brains to make sure they voted as one. That leaves us in the absurd position of some of my colleagues exercising their right and, inevitably, losing. However, be that as it may, the object of this report is not to make the process more expeditious or more efficient; it is simply to cut down the time available for the scrutinising of the expenditure and outlays of government revenues.

PARA.TAB: The net effect of that will be to ensure that the level of scrutiny by the Parliament will be significantly reduced. As I said yesterday, I would have thought the findings of the Western Australian royal commission, in which Senator McMullan presumably has more than a passing interest, would be a salutary lesson to those who believe that there is something clever, something slick, and something smart about expediting government business through the chamber with the least amount of impediment or the least amount of objection by what might be described as a recalcitrant opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is something good about actually dealing with it sometimes.
—Dealing with what?
—Government business.
—To my knowledge, no legislation has ever foundered in this chamber because time precluded it from being passed through both Houses.
—There would have been if you had had your way.

—That is not true. Senator McMullan well knows that for the first three or four weeks at the beginning of every session—and it is the history of all governments—because of the incompetence of the bureaucracy and the mismanagement of the Government's program, there is a dearth of legislation and we spend all our time debating Standing Orders or debating reports—
—We are ready to deal with the legislation. You will not.
—I am not talking about the specifics. I am talking about it as a matter of principle.
—I am sorry about letting the facts get in the way of your argument.

—The facts are not getting in the way of the argument. The truth of the matter is that, if the Government managed its affairs and the business of the Parliament properly, there would not be a problem. Senator McMullan is now saying to the chamber that it is more important for legislation to be passed than for legislation to be scrutinised. If there has to be a conflict between whether legislation is scrutinised properly, examined carefully, and subjected to second deliberation, and whether it is a question of getting the damned legislation through because the result of the legislation is more important than the scrutiny, we will always go for the latter proposition. That is the object of the argument. The contempt in which this Government holds the Parliament is shown by the way we are now governed by fear. We are now governed by public press release.

PARA.TAB: If the Treasurer wants to change the legislation fundamentally, that happens as a result of him issuing a press statement. The legislation becomes effective from the date of the press statement and then when it is introduced it is made retrospective. That is because of the contempt of this Government for the parliamentary process, in no way better manifest than in the observations of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that this chamber—this States house, this house of second deliberation and consideration, this chamber of sober reflection, this chamber which has more time to scrutinise the legislation carefully—is, in his words, `unrepresentative swill'. It is no secret that if the Prime Minister had his way he would abolish this chamber. This comes from a political party that argues that the level of corruption alleged in the States comes from a bicameral system in one circumstance. The truth of the matter is that because of the vanity and the arrogance of this Government, its members are much more concerned for their legislation than they are for having it scrutinised or having it right.

Madam Acting Deputy President, it gravely disappoints me that we are confronted with this proposal. I take it that the Democrats will be supporting the Government, for reasons which I definitely do not understand. The Democrats have always very properly argued that the forum of the Parliament is the proper forum for the scrutiny of the Government. As a minor party not likely to have to concern itself with the treasury bench, the contribution the Democrats make, as Don Chipp always said, is to scrutinise legislation. Perhaps he put it in a more crude way; he said, `Keep the bastards honest'. One of the fundamental instruments available to the Democrats is the proper scrutiny of the Government in its conduct and in its legislation. To that extent, the Democrats quite properly have never been reluctant to use select committees whenever an issue has come up which they have considered deserved further attention; to the point that the then Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, threatened that he would cut off funding if the legislation was inhibited as a result of further scrutiny and further examination by a select committee of this chamber.

To that extent I find myself in a state of confusion as to why the Democrats will support this, why the Democrats propose to reduce speaking time from 20 minutes, why the Democrats are supporting the reduction of the number of standing committees from nine to seven, and why the Democrats chose not to support my commendable amendment yesterday to increase the number of estimates committees from six to eight. I just hope that the Democrats will do as they always claim, give this proposal the serious consideration it deserves, and support Senator Walters' amendment. To do otherwise would be simply to reduce the capacity the Democrats have in this chamber to maintain their relevancy. That is true of us, and that is true of all parties other than the Government. To accept these nonsensical proposals is simply to hand a further instrument to the Government to disguise, to camouflage and to hide its legislation and its outlays from public, proper and careful scrutiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should start off by saying the Democrats are in favour of the motion moved by the Government, but I am interested in Senator Walters' foreshadowed amendment. I have not seen it, so I cannot comment on it, but I must say I am interested in seeing it when it is available.

PARA.TAB: As far as the substantive motion goes, the Procedure Committee on 19 December 1991 adopted a report into estimates committees and the virtual re-running of estimates committees in the chamber in the Committee of the Whole. I was a member of that committee at the time—I still am—and I thought it was a very good report. I think we would all have to agree that substantial time is spent on looking at appropriations, and so it should be. It is a very big Bill. It is basically the estimate of the amount of money the Government is going to spend in the next year and what it is going to spend it on. It is very important, and it should be scrutinised closely.

However, we have to keep in mind that we have been sitting now for a day and a half and we have had no government legislation before us yet, and it does not look like we will get any today. We have to keep in mind how many hours of consideration of government Bills we have in an average sitting year. I do not know how many hours it is, but it is a small proportion of the whole time that we sit.
I have here some figures which I do not think have been quoted yet. At page 3 of the discussion paper dated 19 December 1991 it was reported:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1990 nearly 20 hours were spent on the additional appropriation bills and over 37 hours on the annual appropriation bills in committee of the whole. In 1991 over 24 hours were spent in committee of the whole on the additional appropriation bills and 30 hours on the annual appropriation bills.

We have got a figure of our own: in the Budget sittings of 1992, 36 hours were spent in Committee of the Whole on the annual appropriation Bills. That is an awful lot of time being devoted to government Bills.

PARA.TAB: There should be scrutiny. The scrutiny should, however, have been very thorough in the estimates committees and I believe it is very thorough in the estimates committees. I cannot see that we really need so much extra time to scrutinise again what we have already scrutinised once very, very thoroughly in estimates committees. So we are quite happy with that, although I am looking forward to seeing Senator Walters's amendment.

The second part of the Government's motion concerns titles of office holders. This is not monumental but I recall that in the Procedure Committee it involved quite a bit of discussion, which was quite interesting. At one point somebody asked what happened in the House of Lords, I believe. We have decided to take out the hyphens from `Deputy-President' and from `Deputy-Clerk' and `Clerks-Assistant'. I am really pleased to see that we are doing that. I do not think there would be any disagreement around the chamber about removing this hyphen. I think this is an excellent point and I am glad to see it in there. I will be voting for it, as will all other Democrats.

We have a real problem with standing order 61 regarding the consideration of government documents. As everybody in this chamber would know, if a government document originates in the other place we often do not get to see it until just before we have to speak on it. That is something we were looking at fixing. I believe that Senator Vanstone, on the Opposition benches, was doing the same sort of thing. We put up a proposal to the Procedure Committee to have a look at this.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is on a trial basis.

—On a trial basis, yes. The first report of the Procedure Committee stated, concerning the proposed amendment suggested by Senator Kernot on behalf of the Democrats, that the effect of the proposed amendment would be that, when government documents are not presented until after 12 noon—as is always the case on sitting Mondays and Tuesdays, when the Senate does not meet until two—consideration of those documents under standing order 61 would be deferred until the following sitting day. If there were deferred documents to be considered on any sitting day as well as documents tabled on that day, the time for consideration of both groups of documents would be 60 minutes.

PARA.TAB: That would allow time for honourable senators to examine documents which were not tabled until after 12 noon before the documents were debated. The rationale applies particularly to those documents which are not made available to honourable senators by the government before they are tabled.

The problem that the Procedure Committee established with that proposal was that sometimes topicality of these documents is very important. We agree that sometimes it is. The committee suggested that, as an alternative, it be provided that, when the Senate sits at two, government documents may be tabled before Question Time. There would then be at least the 60 minutes taken by Question Time and usually the 90 minutes taken by Question Time, petitions and notices for examination of those documents not made available to honourable senators before tabling, before the documents were debated under the standing order. To prevent the tabling of government documents delaying the commencement of Question Time, it could be provided that documents may be tabled by a Minister by handing them to the Clerk without any announcement to the Senate. The Chair would announce the earlier tabling of the documents when government documents were called on for consideration under the standing order.

That is, as Senator Teague has said, just a trial. We are willing to try that and see if it works. But if it does not work, we are still going to go back to our original proposal. We will be going into that in the next sittings.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the matter of the cost of justice. It is an extremely topical item to be discussing this week, which is Law Week. I believe that all legal practitioners, judges and politicians should consider the rising cost of justice, which has put the legal system beyond the reach of most Australians.

PARA.TAB: When I gave notice of my motion yesterday and when I sought its formality today, to its credit, I received support from the Government, even though some of the measures that I proposed, no doubt, implied criticism of what the Government has or has not done in the area of containing the cost of justice. The coalition parties, however, saw fit to oppose the measures that I suggested should be taken to make the legal system more accessible to all Australians rather than to perpetuate the present position in which only the very rich or the very poor have access to the courts.

Let us now look at some of those measures which the Opposition obviously thinks are not worthy of consideration. The first measure which, I believe, is absolutely essential if we are going to get anywhere with the containment of costs is to have independent tribunals with consumer representation to fix lawyers' fees and court charges. The legal profession must be just about the only profession that is able to fix its own remuneration. It is quite clear that, if we are to have any confidence in the need to have certain costs charged and certain fees imposed on people seeking legal advice and legal representation before Australian courts, the fees charged by lawyers should be subjected to impartial analysis. Yet there seems to be a great reluctance to accede to that request and there seems to be a great push from the profession to retain the privilege of fixing its own fees.

The other proposition that I wish to put forward is closely allied to that. It is the establishment of independent complaints tribunals for the legal profession and, for that matter, for judges. Various inquiries of the Parliament—most particularly the cost of justice inquiry carried out by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and the Joint Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act—have received a number of submissions and a lot of anecdotal evidence. No doubt every honourable senator in this chamber has received correspondence from members of the public who have been charged enormous amounts and who have had to suffer the consequences of mistakes made by members of the legal profession who have represented them. They have found that, if they want to do something about it and complain about Caesar, they have to go to Caesar to complain about what has happened to them.

We have had quite extraordinary cases brought to our attention. I have had one where a member of the public had a dispute over $1,900 in a building industry case and the legal bills within 18 months or so amounted to $65,000. Yet when that person sought intervention from the Law Institute she was told that she could go before the Law Institute tribunal but that the most she could expect in terms of damages or satisfaction was $2,500. The other choice she had was to go back to court and sue the legal practitioner who had represented her and whose mistakes of judgment, she felt, and I tend to agree, had—

TALK.START.PARA: —Some mistakes, all right.

—There was no fraud and no real negligence, but there were mistakes of judgment which I believe have made the legal practitioner culpable in allowing clients to run up that sort of a bill. I believe it is intolerable for a person like that not to be able to go to an independent tribunal and bring that complaint, and to then be faced with the choice of either getting very inadequate compensation or risking yet more money to go to court and be represented by yet another member of the legal profession.

PARA.TAB: We have also had, I believe, a number of cases where people have alleged bias on the part of judges. It is time that we recognised that the judiciary has certain responsibilities in our community and that they should be subject to scrutiny. It is also time that we recognised people who feel that they have had—to put it bluntly—a raw deal on the basis of bias by a judge or even negligence where a judge has totally disregarded evidence that he or she should have taken into account. Those people should not be forced to go to yet another appeal, which very often could be to the High Court at tremendous expense, but should be able to have such a complaint scrutinised by an independent tribunal. These are matters that I have brought up repeatedly in both the family law inquiry and in the cost of justice inquiry but, as yet, the other members of those inquiries have not seen fit to support such measures.

I will now turn to the question of legal aid. In this time of rather limited government finance it must be said, yet again, that both State and Commonwealth governments have the prime responsibility to ensure that members of the community who cannot afford, of their own means, to retain lawyers, must receive legal aid. We find that, currently, more than 50 per cent of applications for legal aid are rejected. For most of them, it is not because the case has no merit but rather that the funds are inadequate. In relation to that situation, I find it rather strange that that particular source of funds, which is under the control of the legal profession, is strangled and is not allowed to flow freely into the legal aid coffers.

I will now refer to the interest being derived from solicitors' trust accounts. In all States, except Tasmania, there exists legislation which allocates the disbursement of interest collected, at a lower rate, I might say. The banks are getting some profit out of that, too. That is collected into a guarantee fund. Part of that fund, in the first instance, certainly is allocated to legal aid. However, what I call the mistakes by the black sheep of the profession are also compensated out of that fund. When solicitors, due to fraudulent behaviour, have caused losses to people who have put funds with solicitors for investment, or simply in their trust accounts, these defalcations are made good out of the interest on solicitors' trust accounts.

That money does not belong to the legal profession. It belongs to the people who are members of the community and who have come to solicitors as clients. The legal profession claims to be self-regulating. If that is so, it must look after its own black sheep and it must not use money that belongs to the public. That money should go in toto to legal aid commissions to assist people in getting access to our legal system.

These and other matters are of great importance. The attempts of the profession to retain all manner of privileges, which can be described only as restraint of trade, make it imperative in my view that the Trade Practices Commission should be given the power to supervise the legal profession and to hold it to account. Other examples of why I think that is absolutely essential include the advertising of fees. We are told that there should be a free market in all goods and services to get the best service at competitive rates, yet there is clearly no knowledge on the part of consumers when it comes to legal services. Even where it is permitted for solicitors to advertise their fees—and barristers certainly are not permitted to do so at this stage—there seems to be a cultural barrier. I have yet to see widespread advertising of comparative fees and costs by members of the legal profession.

I believe it is clear that in this day and age we can do without Queen's counsel. That is a title which almost automatically results in a capacity to charge a higher fee, and in many jurisdictions to employ a junior and thus have two counsel. It is not two counsel for the price of one, it is really two counsel for the price of 2 1/2.

There are obviously other measures that can be taken. The legal profession is not the only factor that affects the cost of justice. I think parliaments might wish to look at legislation in simple English. I regret that the work of the Victorian Legal Reform Commission, which through its chairman, Professor David Kelly, has devoted a great deal of time to path-breaking work producing legislation in simple English, has been so brutally curtailed by the Kennett Government.

Another area is the contribution that judges can make. Clearly, increased case management by judges is needed to ensure that issues are identified early, that documents and evidence are provided quickly, and that the delays of the court are not used as a tactical measure to starve out the less financial party to a dispute. I am glad to say that during the inquiries of which I have been a member various representatives of the judiciary have expressed willingness to engage in more decisive case management, and are in fact already doing so. Finally, there is the alternative that our legal system should offer to people who are faced with a dispute or who feel they have suffered an injustice: the mediation process, which should be fostered as an alternative to the legal profession.

I conclude by expressing again my regret that the Opposition has seen fit to oppose the motion putting these measures on the table. I trust that in future days the Senate as a whole will contribute to the pursuit of these measures to bring down the cost of justice to a level at which every Australian can have access to our courts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications in the light of the pay TV fiasco. I remind him of a statement by Senator Evans, his new leader in the Senate, made on 24 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there is no effective excuse for . . . the failure of knowledge and the failure of supervision on the part of Ministers concerned, who, if the doctrine of individual ministerial responsibility means anything in this day and age, bear the personal responsibility for everything that has gone wrong—
Does the Minister agree with this statement of his leader?

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that Senator Evans was in opposition when he made that statement. I thought he might have been because one can find—
—Does it change?
—No; will the honourable senator let me finish. I can produce my record in opposition and, in fact, I will dig it out of the Northern Territory Hansard in terms of censure—
—So you tell different stories?

—No. One can find 50,000 definitions for ministerial responsibility, and Senator Hill knows it. The one I like and support, because I think it is the one that is the most sensible, is the one I quoted yesterday which was espoused by Waterford. But I will go over the ground again. In a modern parliamentary democracy—and I had this view in opposition—the only sensible, reasonable and responsible definition of ministerial responsibility is this: a Minister has to behave with propriety and responsibly, in the true sense of the word—in other words, those two conditions, as I said yesterday, cover things like deliberately misleading the House on an issue which, of course, is an instant hanging offence—and a Minister has to behave competently.

PARA.TAB: The charge of which I was accused yesterday was in fact of being deficient in not sitting down and reading this particular tender document. I have just discovered that I signed seven determinations last week for about $50 million worth of roads contracts. I will not go back and second-guess and sit down like a corporate secretary and read all those again.

But, to conclude, a Minister is rightly held responsible for the administrative failure of a department when there has been a systemic failure of administration while he has been the Minister and he has failed to correct it. For example, where a report from the Auditor-General indicates that there is a serious failure in the department, it has been brought to public attention, and the Minister does nothing about it; he should correct it.

But I will tell honourable senators what the facts are in the midst of all this hyperbole—and everyone is having a great time with this. I came into this portfolio three years ago as a junior Minister in its transport side. In the whole time that I was in that portfolio there was not the slightest evidence to me, or indeed the public, of any systemic failure. Furthermore, it is a matter of fact that, not in terms of process but in terms of the advice I received from the department, that period has resulted in successful massive changes in shipping, aviation, road and rail transport that have provided enormous benefit for this country and will provide significantly more in the next three-year program in transport.

When I got into the telecommunications side of the portfolio, under difficult circumstances last year, we processed a mass of legislation through the House, set up spectrum management authorities and set up the Australian Broadcasting Authority. Again, I had no reason to believe that there was any administrative breakdown in my department at all, and the public record shows that.

The first occasion on which I became aware that there was a serious problem of administration in the broadcasting division of my department was last Friday. I immediately took action. I asked the secretary to the department to commence an investigation into that breakdown. I have now moved to set up an inquiry into that. The investigation has been going on since Friday. I took instant action the minute I knew that there had been a breakdown; the first one that has occurred since I have become a Minister in this portfolio. Having done that, we are now moving to set up an inquiry. The inquiry will be constituted by a qualified person independent of the Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he going to inquire into your role?

—That is a matter for the Senate when the results of the inquiry are brought back to this chamber, as I said they would be. I believe in keeping the correct difference between the Ministry and the Public Service. That person, I hope—and the person I would want to see appointed—will be someone with both legal and administrative experience, and will be someone completely independent of the Public Service.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister seriously asking the Senate to accept that his failure to adequately supervise his department's supervision of a multimillion dollar tender process, in that he signed a vitally important ministerial determination without having read it or obviously comprehended its contents, is not a breach of ministerial responsibility?

—I fully understand the difficulty that lies here, because there is not one single, solitary member of the Opposition front bench in the Senate who has ever been a Minister. I have been on both sides. I had 10 years in opposition. During that time I was shadow Minister for everything and, in fact, Leader of the Opposition. Being a shadow Minister is an absolute bludge compared with being a Minister. That is a fact.

PARA.TAB: As I said before, all those po-faced hypocrites who sit over there casting aspersions would not know because they have never been Ministers. I have no doubt, having talked to some of my colleagues, that if they ever become Ministers—and I have to say that that prospect is looking more and more unlikely with every passing minute—they will know that sensible procedures are adopted in order to handle the paper flow through a Minister's office. In this case those procedures were not followed. I found out that they were not being followed last week. I have instituted an inquiry. Let us get to the real nub of this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Collins, the answer to the question and the supplementary question have gone on for eight minutes, which is well over the normal time. I ask you to conclude your answer.
—I will sit down now, Mr President, and complete this answer when I get asked the next question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware of criticisms expressed by members of the Opposition and certain sections of the media that the Government's decision to fund gender awareness programs for the judiciary represents an attack on the independence of the judiciary? Can the Minister comment on the Government's intent with regard to this reference?

—The Government is committed to ensuring equality before the law for women. The Government also respects the independence of the judiciary. In his women's policy speech which was delivered on 10 February 1993, the Prime Minister announced that funding would be provided to the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration to enable it to develop gender awareness programs for the Australian judiciary. That program is to be headed by Justice Deirdre O'Connor.

PARA.TAB: There are some points to make about it. First, attendance is not mandatory. Secondly, the programs will be developed and run by the institute for judges and by judges. Thirdly, the institute itself approached the Government about this matter at a time when the Government was considering the national strategy on violence against women, which deals with such issues and such programs. Fourthly, the chairman of the institute, Justice John Clarke of the New South Wales Supreme Court, has applauded the Prime Minister's announcement that the institute would receive funds to develop the program, and he made that comment publicly in the Australian on 13 February this year.

In addition, the President of the Law Council of Australia, Mr Robert Meadows, has acknowledged the need for judges and magistrates to be conscious of community attitudes or to be helped, as proposed by the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration and, as the Prime Minister put it, to recognise in themselves prejudices that might impact on their judicial conduct towards women.

This important initiative is in addition to the reference given to the Law Reform Commission to examine issues of women's equality before the law, and work has also started on that reference. In view of the reports in today's paper, where certain remarks are attributed to a judge, I think this question is remarkably timely.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the prepared written answer from which she was reading or, at the very least, to provide it on a floppy disk to make it easier for Hansard.
—Order! It is a matter for the Minister as to whether or not she will table the document.
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is there anything in the advice from the Attorney-General's Department which Senator Collins tabled yesterday which would have precluded him from inserting in the determination of 19 January a requirement for the payment of a five per cent deposit? If not, why does he keep pretending that it would have been improper for him to do so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is about time Senator Alston, particularly as a lawyer, stopped dodging and weaving on this.
—Dodging and weaving!

—Just wait, folks. Have a look at the record. Not only is there nothing in the determination from the Attorney-General's Department that says that should not happen. I said yesterday, by way of a very loud interjection to Senator Alston, that there is not. I went on further to say that it is absolutely clear that the deficiency in this process was the lack of a deposit. At the end of this process that will be the only deficiency that has been revealed. It is a very major one, and I have said that in debate. What I said that the advice of the Attorney-General's Department does—and it does—is to refute absolutely the original position that Senator Alston took on this just last weekend.
—Answer the question.
—Just wait for your own quotes, Senator Alston. That is what I said, and it does. Senator Alston totally contradicted himself on AM this morning when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: What the A.G.'s Department said is that it would not be proper to attach qualitative conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. In the interest of saving a great deal of time, I say that on either side of the chamber we are not concerned about merit based or qualitative assessments.
—That is not a point of order.

—Just a moment. The question relates specifically and only to the payment of a five per cent deposit. Therefore, I invite you, Mr President, to confine Senator Collins's remarks to that issue, and that issue alone.

—On the non-point of order, Mr President: that is not a point of order. Senator Alston knows it, as does the whole chamber. Honourable senators opposite should not go back to their old tricks; they are still in opposition.
—Order! Senator Collins is developing an argument. I am sure that he will answer the substantive part of the question shortly.
—Senator Alston again has just condemned himself out of his own mouth. He said that nobody is interested in arguing qualitative assessments. This is what Senator Alston said last weekend—
—We don't want to hear what Alston said.
—No, I am sure you do not.
—Order!
—Mr President, can I finish? The answer would not be half as long if there were no interjections. I quote Senator Alston:

ANSWER.PARA: The apparent lack of any meaningful qualitative assessment—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr President. An answer must relate to the question that was asked. This answer is not relevant at all to the question that was asked. That is the point of order that Senator Alston made. Surely it can be understood by those on the other side. Mr President, you should require him to comply with that.
—Order! I am listening to Senator Collins before I decide on the point of order. There were that many interjections, I think he had said only a few words last time before the next point of order.

—Mr President, just so there will not be another point of order: Senator Alston has asked me if I said that the advice yesterday was that one could not put a five per cent bid on it. I said, `No, I didn't say that'. In fact, I said that the clear deficiency in the process was that one could not. The reason I tabled the advice yesterday was that the advice did say, as Senator Alston confirmed on AM this morning, that one could not put any qualitative assessment in front of price. That was to rebut and reject what Senator Alston said I should have done last weekend. I quote him:

ANSWER.PARA: The apparent lack of any qualitative assessment of the bids resulted in this problem.

Senator Alston is a nonsense on this issue. Last night on the 7.30 Report—and this is the nub of the issue—Senator Alston was asked, `What is your problem?' He answered, `The problem is there was no deposit'. That is what he said last night. That is my problem, too; there is no deposit. He was then told, `Well, the Government is fixing that. They are bringing in amendments to make sure there is a deposit. Are you going to support that?' Have a look at the transcript. What did Alston say? He said, `No, we are not going to support that'. He was then asked, `Why aren't you going to support that?' He said:
Because the Government shouldn't have done this in the first place.

That is like an ambulance officer coming to the scene of an accident and saying to the victim lying on the road, covered in blood and gore, `I am not going to take you to hospital, mate. You shouldn't have had the accident in the first place'. It is an absolute nonsense.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the advice I tabled yesterday—and Senator Alston knows it—says categorically that the kinds of conditions that the department should have placed on these bids that Senator Alston put last weekend could not have been done legally. Not only does the advice indicate that one could not put a five per cent deposit on but—could I just make the obvious point—why would I assert that, if we are introducing amendments to do exactly that? By simple definition—and Senator Alston is supposed to be a lawyer—how could we assert that we were introducing amendments which were in conflict with the Attorney-General's advice I tabled in the chamber yesterday? It is a nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Now that Senator Collins has conceded that he could indeed have attached the five per cent condition—I asked him a question which he did not answer, and that is, why has he always kept pretending that it would have been improper for him to have done so—is the real truth of the matter that the Minister did not bother to do anything other than glance at the document and, in his own words, merely check it for correctness and, therefore, that it did not occur to him to put the five per cent in place? If that is so, does the Minister seriously suggest that such a fundamental oversight is consistent with modern notions of ministerial responsibility?

—This is real shyster stuff, I must say, with the greatest respect, because I did not in fact say that. What I said was that it would be improper of me and not responsible of me to have been involved in the tender process at all. I have never asserted that the Attorney-General's advice said that we could not do it. By simple definition—even simple enough for Senator Alston—why would the Government propose to introduce amendments into the chamber to do precisely that if we had Attorney-General's advice that we could not do it?

PARA.TAB: The cold hard facts are that it is clear that the departmental officers who were involved in preparing these tenders in the way that I assumed they would—in the same successful way as they had for the third mobile licence for which we got $140 million just a few months ago, and for television licences and radio licences, all of which required these deposits—did not do so. That matter is now going to be investigated by an independent investigator from outside the Public Service. The key question is this: if Senator Alston's problem is the deposit and if the Government has moved, as we have, to quickly address that in a way which still preserves the legal rights of the successful bidders to pursue their bids if they can—if that is his problem and we are fixing it—why will he not support it?

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the expense in providing security to the joint US-Australian facility at Nurrungar during the recent Easter protests. Given that the expense was incurred by the Australian taxpayers, is it reasonable that those taxpayers be made aware of the importance of the Nurrungar facility? If the Minister agrees with this proposition, can he outline to the Senate the continuing importance of these joint facilities?

—I am very happy to do so. The general purpose and function of the joint facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar were, of course, described by the then Prime Minister in his statement to Parliament on 22 November 1988, but it may be very useful, in a post-Cold War context, to explain again their continuing importance. The original impetus to establish Nurrungar during the Cold War was, of course, to provide early warning of ballistic missile attacks and that vital role did help to prevent nuclear war. While the threat of nuclear confrontation is now hugely reduced as a result of recent developments, hundreds of ICBMs with thousands of nuclear warheads do still exist, so the original early warning role of the defence support system remains, to that extent, entirely valid.

PARA.TAB: The end of the Cold War has brought new international and regional uncertainties of which we are all acutely conscious, including the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and the means of delivering them, such as shorter range missiles. During the Gulf War, Nurrungar played a very large part in helping to defend civilians in Israel and Saudi Arabia from attack by such missiles. Maintaining this capability will help to deter the proliferation of ballistic missiles around the world, including in our own region.

Moreover, the facilities make a vital contribution to the increasingly important post-Cold War agenda of collective security. Nurrungar and our other facility at Pine Gap continue to make a really quite critical contribution in monitoring and verifying the arms control agreements which have transformed the strategic landscape in recent years. A clear opportunity now exists to build international cooperation to prevent war. The US, Russia and others, including Australia, have been exploring in recent times a global protection system, with one option being to share data on ballistic missile launches. Nurrungar would be a key element in such a system.

At the regional level, Nurrungar may yet have a further significant role. Australia may conceivably come to rely more than ever on this facility if a ballistic missile threat were to develop in our neighbourhood. On the other hand, the early warning capabilities of Nurrungar offer possibilities for new orders of cooperation with direct benefit to our neighbours' own security. The monitoring of arms control agreements, the discouraging of ballistic missile proliferation, the probabilities for defence of cities against missile attack and opportunities for new forms of regional cooperation are all on our agenda in the post-Cold War era.

I think it is also worth making clear that Australians are fully integrated into all aspects of operations at Nurrungar, because there continue to be claims to the contrary. Of the approximately 450 personnel at the site, slightly more than half—240 at the moment—are Australian. Australians also fill at least two of the four crew commander positions—at the moment they fill three—and a RAAF wing commander is the deputy commander of the facility. We participate fully in all aspects of the operation of the facilities, including tasking of them, to provide information in Australia's particular security interests.

Finally, those like Senator Spindler who argue, however sincerely, for the closing down of these facilities have yet to explain how world security or regional security would be better without them. The Government has absolutely no doubts in this regard.
