We need to be prepared to back up our strenuous efforts internationally to achieve and develop support for arms control measures by demonstrating that we are also willing to support active measures, such as the missile launch detection capability served by Nurrungar, which help to guarantee compliance with international arms control obligations and to promote non-proliferation objectives.

The Government also recognises the increased opportunities for the United Nations, particularly the UN Security Council, to play a constructive role in securing peace and enhancing collective security in the post-Cold War era. We have encouraged the UN to enhance its collective security role, including through peacekeeping and preventive diplomacy. Again, the joint facilities support these and all our other initiatives to secure a more lasting and durable peace in the post-Cold War era.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I raise the issue of the membership of the Prime Minister's advisory committee on Australia's republican options on which there are at present four members from New South Wales, two from Victoria and one from South Australia. Is balancing State representation an important criterion in the selection of members of this committee? How likely is it that the premiers will take—
—But you want to abolish the States.

—Yes, but I want everyone to have a say in abolishing the States. How likely is it that the premiers—who are trying to agree on the last two members—will take that into consideration? Will the Government consider appointing a young Australian to the committee—
—How many Queenslanders voted for you in the leadership contest?
—Ninety per cent, thank you, Senator Ray.
—Order! It is a very interesting debate but I think that Senator Kernot should continue with her question.
—Will the Government consider appointing a young Australian to the committee, perhaps in place of the position that the Opposition is failing to take up?

—A number of considerations were no doubt taken into account by the Prime Minister in determining the composition of the committee. Most prominent among them would undoubtedly be his judgment about who was best able to make an effective and intelligent contribution to the task of identifying and defining the sorts of conditions on which a republic referendum might go forward. I have no doubt that some attention was paid to the State composition.

PARA.TAB: An opportunity, obviously, to redress the imbalance to which Senator Kernot refers will exist with the contributions to be made by the State premiers. I have never purported to understand what goes on inside State premiers' heads and I do not know whether they will take into account the geographical imbalance factor in determining their own representation, but no doubt that will be a consideration.

Finally, I make the point that the Opposition still has its own opportunity to make a contribution in this respect, both to the work of the committee and to any imbalances that might be perceived to exist in it. I invite the Opposition, in all sincerity, once again, to reconsider its position on that and to make a positive contribution to this important exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services please describe for the Senate the impact being made internationally by Australian artists and their achievements? What measures are being taken by the Government to enhance this process?

—It is very worth while noting the impact Australia is making internationally through its achievements in the arts. It is very remarkable for a country of only 17 million people. This is already being noted around the world. I will give honourable senators a travelogue one day of all the people who have spoken to me about it. A number of people and a number of international media are recognising the significance of what Australia is doing and it is contributing to starting to change the international image of Australia. That is very important economically, it is very important for Australian industry and it enhances a range of our relations with other countries in our region and beyond.

PARA.TAB: Only last week I was talking to a representative of one of Australia's embassies who was commenting on the greater ease with which it is possible to make contact with, for example, international business leaders when they are invited to embassy functions featuring Australian artists, rather than the ordinary run of the dreadful diplomatic cocktail circuit. In a number of ways it is changing the image that Australia has overseas and making us perceived as a more technologically advanced nation.

Everybody—most honourable senators here have had the opportunity to travel overseas—will have been frustrated at the image that so many people have of Australia as more of a backwoods country than the high-tech country that we are entitled to be regarded as. Many Australian companies that are trying to sell high-tech products are much more likely to be successful if Australia is perceived as a more technologically advanced nation.

I think, as I look around, that almost everybody here would have heard of the success of Strictly Ballroom. Most people here would know about the success of Australian television drama. Some would even know about the tremendous success that we are having in children's television. But these are not isolated international examples. This year, five Australian films gained official selection at the Cannes film festival, which is being commented on around the world by a number of media commentators as being an outstanding performance by the Australian film industry. It is certainly not doing Australia's image over there any harm.

Two Australian artists went to the Venice Biennale, which is the showcase for international contemporary art. Those two artists, Jenny Watson and Hany Armanious, are not just good artists but are artists at the cutting edge of modern high-tech art. They have a significant capacity to change the way that Australians are perceived internationally. For those who have had the opportunity to make intelligent decisions about where they go overseas, this might be a significant advantage. I could cite a number of examples in the areas of ballet, Aboriginal art, et cetera, but I have no intention of doing that because the list is inexhaustible.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an abuse of Question Time.

—This is the basis upon which the Government provides the $141 million it does to the arts, and it is the basis upon which we built the extra initiatives in the distinctly Australian document that go directly to these areas of policy and enhance the capacity of Australia to make these sorts of contributions. It will help to make the arts a more successful industry in itself with a lot of foreign exchange earnings, which one would have thought Senator Short would be pleased about instead of complaining.
—Make a ministerial statement on it if it is that important.

—Senator Short would love the opportunity to make one. It is something on which we will build. There are some substantial enhancements of these things in this Budget, which I am sure will be welcomed by everybody, at least on this side of the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. In view of the Minister's repeated claim that he was not made aware until last Friday of deviations from the normal tender process when it came to allocating satellite pay television licences, will he today table all advice that the department has given him or his office on this matter, including all notes of telephone conversations and any other relevant material?

—A debate on this question was initiated by the Opposition yesterday. Clearly, although he launched the debate, Senator Alston was not listening to it. I said yesterday—and it is a matter of fact—that all that material will be made available. It is already in the public forum as a result of the court processes a few months ago.
—That is MDS.

—No, it does not just relate to that. All the information that was made available that can be made available is there. I also said yesterday that any further documents would be provided. I asked the secretary to my department yesterday to do that. But I make the obvious point that the most appropriate action for me to take, having had this matter brought to my attention last Friday—and it is a serious deficiency that has occurred—is to have the secretary to the department, in consultation with me, appoint an independent inquiry of the department. Hopefully, I will be able to announce the person who will head that in the very near future. I want at least the first results of it to be made available to the Senate in time for it to consider them before it adjourns at the end of the autumn sittings.

PARA.TAB: I have no difficulty with that request, because, as I said, most of the relevant paperwork, including the relevant file notes and so on, are in the public domain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you agreed to table the material or not?
—Would Senator Hill just let me finish.
—You never answer a question.

—I am sorry that I do not answer in a way that suits Senator Hill. I will table the documents which apply to Senator Alston's question. As I said yesterday, I have asked my departmental secretary to start the process of getting those documents together now.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The real question I asked the Minister was: will he table them today? The Minister says that those documents have been on the record in the Federal Court for several months. Presumably, officers in the Minister's department have been crawling all over those documents for the last six days since he started bucketing his department and, therefore, he is clearly in a position to table them today, and I ask him whether he will do so.

—That is not a real question; that is an unreal question. It indicates again that the lack of ministerial experience of the front bench opposite is a real problem. I will tell the Opposition what will happen. This gets back to the same po-faced hypocrisy. Let us look at the Senator Richardson and Senator Bolkus matters of last year. They were tragedies for modern democracy which have since been put right by an overwhelming mandate of the Australian people. Does the Opposition know what would happen—everybody in here knows what would happen—if I ran into the department, as I am apparently almost supposed to do—
—You, run!

—I am getting close to being able to do that with every passing day. If I ran into the department and grabbed a big handful of the documents and I came in here today and heaved them on the table, and one of them was found to be missing, next week I would be condemned.
—No, you wouldn't.

—I know Senator Alston had his fingers crossed behind his back when he said that. Of course I would. That gets back to the central issue. I know perfectly well that the key issue is whether I should have intervened and put five per cent or $5 million into this project. If after my intervention there had been only a few applicants, and if one of those successful applicants had been the Packer-Murdoch consortium, I would be being censured now for having intervened in the process.

PARA.TAB: The same story applies to these papers. I said yesterday that I asked the departmental secretary in the proper way to get them together. That is being done now. When it is done I will table them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will the Minister say whether or not, on the piggery at Parkville, New South Wales, of which the Prime Minister is a part owner, sows are kept permanently tethered on short chains? Does the Prime Minister acknowledge that this system of keeping sows is widely regarded as obsolete, and that the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare recommended, in its report on intensive livestock production, that this system should be banned?

—I think it ought to be appreciated that that question does not concern my ministerial responsibility or that of the Prime Minister in this instance, and as such I do not think it is appropriate for me to seek an answer from him. I do point out, however, for the record, that the Prime Minister is not responsible for the day to day management of the piggery, which I am told is subject to all relevant codes of practice in relation to the treatment of animals.

PARA.TAB: We respect the right, and I certainly do, of individuals to express a point of view about the conditions of farming of animals and the policy issues that are involved in that. I think, Senator Powell, that we all ought to recognise and respect the right of any individual to invest in an industry which is productive and which will produce export earnings and jobs for Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask the Minister the question that was not answered when I raised it in yesterday's debate on the pay television tender farce: did the Minister's department tell him at any stage of the high level advice that I know it received long before the closing of tenders for satellite pay TV licences that the process was going to be corrupted by a series of collapsing bids from shonky applicants?

—The short answer to Senator Baume's question is no, that advice was not given to me. It is interesting to have a look at the debate yesterday. Opposition members were saying, `Oh, well, it was perfectly proper for the Minister to be apart from the process after it started'; my `negligence' was that I did not sit down and go through the determination and second-guess the department. But it would have been perfectly proper after the process started, when the box was open and the bids started going in, to have involved myself in what the bids were, whether they were shonky or whether they were fair dinkum.

PARA.TAB: I asked the secretary to my department to speak to the officer concerned this morning, after the Australian Financial Review article appeared quoting her. The departmental secretary has advised me that the statement attributed to the head of the broadcasting division of the department is accurate. But nothing hangs on that, and the public record shows it, for the simple reason that the entire bidding process, from start to finish, has been knee-deep in speculation about who was going to bid, whether the bids were going to be of this nature or that nature, or what. After the process started, I kept apart from that.

As they say in this business, history will judge me on whether I made the right decision. This is not very pleasant, of course; but, as I said yesterday, and I meant it, I would rather be in here being attacked for not intervening in the process than be in here being attacked for intervening in the process. I personally would have had great difficulty defending that in terms of my own views on these subjects. I said yesterday, and I repeat it, that not only did I decide that I was not going to have any involvement in terms of this tender process but also I told the senior staffer in my office that he was not going to either. I also spoke to the departmental secretary last year and said that this would be an arm's length process.

All I am saying in response to Senator Baume's question is that the officer has confirmed that the statement she has made is accurate, that is, that approaches were made. Months ago—and this was revisited on Lateline last night—I had representations on the central policy issue of whether it should be a price-based or a merit-based process. All those arguments were run again last night.

I conclude by saying that there has been confusion in some reporting that the criticisms that are now being made by these people are criticisms of the five per cent deposit not being put on. They are not. The criticisms are that they thought this was going to be a disaster because a beauty contest was not entered into. In all the examination I did of this issue, and it was extensive, before the Bill came into the House last year, if on balance I had come to the conclusion that a government or a government agency was a better test of a company's financial viability in the marketplace, I would have gone for that merit-based system. If I had come to the conclusion that a merit-based system was better in terms of not burying the process in litigation, I would have done that. The classic example is the third commercial television licence in Perth; but there are hundreds of examples, not just here but around the world.

The difficulty with merit-based processes, with respect, is this: does a price-based process, on balance, on the records that one can look at, produce a better return for the asset? The honest answer to this is yes, it does. Does a price-based process, at the very least, produce as good a result in estimating the future financial viability of a company as a government or government agency? The answer to that question is, on balance, yes, it does. It certainly produces no worse a result, because there have been failures in both.

The history of this industry, and Senator Baume knows this, is that it has been buried in litigation, not just here but around the world. This has been a feature of the industry for 20 years, and I want this inquiry to investigate it later, as I said on Lateline last night. That does not go just for this administration. All the concentration at the moment is on this Government, rightly, and this Minister, but licence issuing for broadcast licences has been absolutely deluged in litigation going back 20 years. As I said, the former communications Minister, Tony Staley, a man for whom I have the highest regard and respect, and I deal with him in his role as a public broadcaster, had a decision taken against him by the High Court of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not polling well at this end.
—We all have our views on these subjects.
—Order! Senator Collins, this is becoming another very long answer.

—I will conclude on this point. It ended with the Minister receiving direct official advice from the department of the Attorney-General that his Australian Broadcasting Tribunal was acting unlawfully—advice which he then ignored and was censured for ignoring in the House of Representatives—and he was called upon to resign. Of course, the Minister did not resign. All I can say is that nothing hangs on these inquiries being made because the speculation was right across the board.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The small portion of that rambling answer that related to the question apparently indicates that the Minister's indolence is accurately reflected by the department's lack of action. Is the Minister aware that the Prime Minister's department received similar high-level advice of the prospect of collapsible bids corrupting the tender process, also in plenty of time to avoid this shambles? Did the Prime Minister's department inform the Minister's department of that advice? Will the Minister table such advice? Why did the Prime Minister in this instance not, once again, go over the Minister's head to intervene to fix up this mess; or did his department not tell him either?

—This question has about as much value as the question that Senator Baume asked yesterday, trying to link Senator Richardson to a group of Marshall Islands pornographic pig farmers who had interests in pay television. It is an absolute furphy; it is claptrap. I took a decision in January to intervene on this matter that Senator Baume has just asked about. I took that decision based on one very simple premise: that this Parliament had decided that there would be a national satellite system providing the major television coverage for pay TV for Australia, and that as part of that coverage there would be a role for our national broadcaster as part of that national pay system. That was one of the major issues. I thought the Senate would have supported my action on this because it was the Senate that insisted on this being done. On the question of whether this was my decision or the Prime Minister's decision—
—No, that wasn't the question.
—Yes, it was.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question I asked is not the question that Senator Collins is now saying he is answering. I asked specifically: did the Prime Minister's department receive similar advice of the prospect of collapsible bids corrupting the tender process? I invite him—and I ask you to invite him, Mr President—to answer that question.
—Order! In relation to the point of order, I ask Senator Collins to relate his answer to the question.

—On that particular part of the question, which I also heard, if I am expected to be directly responsible for the administration of the Prime Minister's department as well as for everything that goes on in my own, these are ridiculous questions. I have no idea what happened in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I do not know.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Nauru which is led by the Speaker of the Parliament, the Hon. Paul Jeremiah. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming them to the Senate. I trust their visit will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Mr Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TAB.EMPHASIS: Mr Jeremiah was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Can the Minister inform the Senate how the Australian Army plans to counter possible trauma and family disruption suffered by our troops returning from Somalia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate is aware, the Government views the contribution of Australian troops in Somalia as absolutely integral to the success of UN operations there.

—Well, some people actually think this is an important issue. The battalion group deployed to Baidoa has done an outstanding job in very difficult circumstances. The troops' professionalism and their sensitivity to the local community are renowned amongst all the participants in the UN operation.

PARA.TAB: Specifically, the responsibility for counselling all members of the Army for operational stress lies with the Australian Army Psychology Corps. All members of the Army involved in operational deployment overseas are routinely counselled both prior to departure and on their return to this country.

Currently, there is a team of four psychology corps officers and one soldier in Somalia to prepare the members of the 1st Battalion, RAR, for their return to Australia. One of the psychology corps officers is a counsellor for the Vietnam Veterans Association and served in Vietnam. This team will be accompanying the troops home.

Psychology corps services will be available to soldiers in Townsville, for those who wish to self-refer, for continuing individual support. In addition, all Australian veterans have access to the services that are provided by the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. As part of the regimental structure, padres in the Army community services are available at all times to speak to, and also give assistance to, the soldiers and their families.

Group pre-departure and homecoming briefings are conducted for families as well as spouses and soldiers. Pre-departure counselling and briefings for both the troops and their partners included information on the history, the culture and the political situation in Somalia. The troops were also briefed on their possible reactions to the situation they would find in Somalia and how to manage the emotions they might experience as a result.

Debriefing counselling will encourage the troops and their families and partners to talk about the experiences of the troops in Somalia. They will be advised of the troops' likely reactions to their experiences, how to deal with the effects of their emotions and who to speak to in the event that they may require assistance. They will also be counselled on the likely effects the absence of the soldiers will have, both on themselves and on their families.

The Australian Defence Force has recognised the importance of not only adequate preparation of personnel for active service but also proper services for the integration of those personnel back into the community and, of course, their family life on their return.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity the Government did not have that approach to the Vietnam fellows when they came back. It rejected them. My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I ask: can the Minister confirm reports that child carers will be required to provide their tax file numbers to Medicare offices in order for parents of children in child care to receive Labor's child-care cash rebate? Is this not a significant and unintended use of tax file numbers and is it not in direct contradiction to undertakings by the Government during the election campaign that tax file numbers would not have to be provided to Medicare offices?

—The Government is concerned with the affordability of child care, to which Senator Newman has alluded. In particular, it has announced that on 1 July 1994 it will introduce cash rebates for child care. Those cash rebates will be paid through Medicare offices and they are not, as has been claimed by the Opposition, payments that have no regard for low income earners. In fact, the cash rebate payments come on top of the fee relief system and make sure that the Government's commitment to affordability of child-care is its principal concern.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question was very clear and related to the use of tax file numbers and the child-care rebate. Mr President, I wonder whether you could ask Senator Crowley to address the question and not the wider policy issues, which she is attempting to do.
—Order! Senator Crowley has been answering part of the question, but I would ask her to relate her answer to the question asked by Senator Newman.

—I was saying that the cash rebates are a recognition by government that child care is an economic issue, and a very important one for workers. The way in which the Government is proposing to introduce the cash rebates—and I will be introducing legislation this session to deal with the first step of that, as I think Senator Newman would know—is by allowing those payments to be made through Medicare offices.

PARA.TAB: The health insurance legislation amendment, which will be coming down in this place this session, will allow the Health Insurance Commission to do the preparatory work for the payment of cash rebates through the Medicare offices. The details of how it will be worked out are still under examination but, in general, what will be required is that first of all the carers will provide their tax file number to the Medicare offices. Secondly, the user of the child care shall have to produce a receipt as evidence of actually having bought or, if you like, paid for that child care. The important consideration of the tax file numbers is certainly something that the Government is addressing, as the privacy legislation of the Government will be absolutely critical in this matter, and those considerations will be taken into account.

Finally, I would have to say that I do not know where Senator Newman has gleaned the notion that the Government denied this or said differently during the election campaign. That is not my understanding, but certainly I will check to see whether that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for her answer, but it does not do anything other than acknowledge that she does not know much about the subject. The Minister mentioned that the Government is addressing this issue. In what way is the Government addressing it? Does the Minister not acknowledge that the potential linking of tax file numbers and Medicare numbers would allow us to get dangerously close to a de facto Australia card system? Is she not prepared to acknowledge that that is the potential of what is being proposed?

—The Health Insurance Commission legislation amendment to which I have referred, which I think is to be introduced today and certainly will be debated during this session, will certainly allow Senator Newman to go to these details. One of the important considerations is to give the Health Insurance Commission the opportunity to do the work that is required—to get the precision and the detail that is needed for the manner in which these payments will be made through the Medicare offices.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that it is useful for Senator Newman to jump the gun, anticipate all sorts of problems and draw very long bows indeed. The reason that the Health Insurance Commission legislation has to be introduced is precisely because we need a new database and a new program to deal with this payment. It is not covered under the Medicare arrangements, and will be quite separate from them. So I think it is considerably mischievous of Senator Newman to make the associations that she has.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I refer the Minister to the continuing shortage of medical practitioners in rural and isolated communities and the valuable work being done by nurses practising in these areas. I ask the Minister: firstly, will the Government recognise the contribution being made by nurses and explore legislative or other means of allowing nurses to prescribe certain medications, make referrals to specialists and have admitting rights to local hospitals; secondly, will the Government explore the option of granting nurses, particularly those practising in rural and remote areas, Medicare provider numbers?

—I met with the Nursing Federation in Melbourne a couple of weeks ago and it raised these matters, which I know have been under consideration for some time. Under our general practice grants, we will be attempting to address, at least in part, the problem of the lack of doctors throughout rural and remote Australia. I would not pretend for a second, though, that that is likely to solve the problem in the short term.

PARA.TAB: Despite the resistance of doctor organisations, it would seem to me inevitable that some services will finish up in the hands of nurse practitioners. I will not be able to answer in the space of the next few weeks on the extent to which that will occur and whether or not nurses ought to be given Medicare provider numbers. After we have had some proper consultations with the medical profession—and I do not mean over years; I mean over months—I intend to say something about it in the Budget sittings, because we cannot leave it on the table forever.

There is a real problem in rural Australia because the spread of doctors gets worse every day, not better. It will not be good enough for the medical profession to simply rail against the idea of nurses performing the functions that have hitherto been those of doctors, unless it is prepared to assist us in making sure that there is a better spread of doctors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked a question by Senator Boswell relating to the rural adjustment scheme. I now have a detailed answer to that question. It might suit the processes of the Senate for me to seek leave to incorporate this rather long answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to the question on notice from Senator Boswell regarding the level of access to RAS in Queensland

Support for farmers under the Rural Adjustment Scheme takes account of the realities of operating a rural business in Australia. Over time there will be movement of producers into and out of the industry and the RAS is aimed at smoothing this processes so that the competitiveness and efficiency of the industry is not reduced.
Consequently RAS support is targeted at those farmers who have long-term prospects for profitability, but who require some short-term support to improve their productivity.

Under the exceptional circumstances provisions, support is available for carry-on purposes when a farmer is facing difficulty due to certain exceptional circumstances. The recent national allocation of $50.6m is directed at producers suffering hardship from the exceptional circumstances of the prolonged drought in parts of Australia and by the depressed prices for wool.
In Queensland, under the exceptional circumstances provisions, additional Commonwealth funds of $11.3m have been provided under the RAS to provide interest subsidies of up to 100% for farmers
this $11.3m consists of $6.3m for specialist wool growers and $5.0m for drought. This is in addition to a further $9.5m provided to Qld for drought since Sept last year.
In answer to the Senator's specific questions, I can advise him as follows:

PARA.TAB: 1. I have been advised by the RAS administrators in Qld that for the period 1 July 1992 to 31 March 1993, the approval rate for all RAS applications is close to 65%, whilst the approval rate under the existing Special Drought Assistance is 95%

ANSWER.PARA: clearly this indicates that the assistance is meeting its target because the majority of applicants are being assessed as eligible.

PARA.TAB: 2. The Senator's question assumes that if 40% of producers are not receiving assistance, then they will all leave the industry. I should point out that people are assessed as ineligible for RAS for two principal reasons.

ANSWER.PARA: One is that they have the capacity to support their debts and operations out of their own income or assets—a situation in which it is inappropriate for the Commonwealth to be providing subsidies.

The other is that they are found not to be profitable in the long-term. In this case, farmers may be eligible for Farm Household Support, which provides support to farmers either while they arrange the sale of their property, or supports those farmers who believe they have a future in the industry but are unable to obtain further commercial support. Farmers who move out of farming may also be eligible for the increased re-establishment grant of up to $45 000.

PARA.TAB: 3 & 4. The number of producers who will be assisted under the package will depend on the number of applicants who are assessed as eligible and the level of interest rate subsidy offered to each successful applicant. Funding was provided to each State Government on the basis of an independent assessment of need by the independent RAS Advisory Council after consultation between the Commonwealth and each State Government.

5. Producers who are assessed as eligible for Farm Household Support will not also be eligible for RAS support. However any producer who has previously received RAS support may be eligible for Farm Household Support if they cease to be eligible for RAS.

6. It is difficult to forecast just how many producers will actually receive interest rate subsidies for the first time under the exceptional circumstances provisions. However, Queensland report that an increased number of producers received assistance last year for the first time and they expect this trend to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) in response to a question without notice asked by me this day relating to the tender process for subscription television licences.

SPEECH.PARA: Today in Question Time I asked the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), by way of a supplementary question, whether he was aware that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet received similar high-level advice, as his department did, of the prospect of collapsible bids corrupting the tender process, and that this advice was received after tenders opened but in plenty of time before the close of tenders to allow this potential shambles to be corrected. Maybe the Minister was too busy chatting with his colleagues to listen. I then asked whether the Prime Minister's department informed the Department of Transport and Communications of this advice that it had received. I will go through it slowly for you.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't need to.

—I am glad you got it this time, because your answer in Question Time showed that you had no comprehension whatsoever of the significance of the question. Will you table—through you, Mr President—whatever advice the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet received from high-level people in the industry that this corruption of the tender process would proceed; that is, if PM&C advised your department, or indeed advised you? Why did the Prime Minister not go over your head once again to intervene to fix up this mess, or did his department not tell him either? Here we have a situation where it is not simply that your department did not tell you—according to you—but that the Prime Minister's department told neither you, nor the Prime Minister, nor, apparently, your department, because you had no preparedness to respond to the question I asked you.

PARA.TAB: It is not for you to say, `Don't hold me responsible for the actions of the Prime Minister's department', which was your response to the supplementary question, when you were eventually required to answer the substance of it by the President, because you had no intention of doing that at all. Having said that you are not responsible for what the Prime Minister's department does, I simply ask you, and the Opposition requires an answer: did your department receive such advice from the Prime Minister's department? If so, will you table it? Is that too complicated for you to answer, Minister, because it was at Question Time?

We have a right to know what was going on in this area. In the past, the Prime Minister has been only too willing to interfere when you have made a mess of things in your department. He would move straight in. Even when the permanent head was away, he would ring up the deputy secretary.

Clearly, there was a major shambles. Before tenders closed, you had an opportunity to correct the situation because at that point you had not received tenders. At the time you were advised of the shambles, tenderers had not committed themselves to an irreversible situation. You had an opportunity, and your department had an opportunity which it decided not to exercise, to correct a shambles. Your department did not think it was worth telling you because you said that you did not want to know.

That is the classic bottom-of-the-harbour answer. The people in the bottom-of-the-harbour situation were told, `Don't ask and you won't be told any fibs'. You did not want to know what the situation was. The simple fact is that this shambles could have been corrected before tenders closed and before any tenders were submitted. If that had happened, you would not now be threatening to put before this Parliament retrospective legislation changing the rules after the game has started.

You could have fixed it, Minister, had you had the knowledge and the desire to have the knowledge. You had no desire to have the knowledge. You admitted today in this place that you had advised your office that you did not want to know about anything or change anything, even when it was inevitable, had you known, that there would be a shambles. You had the power to fix it—not by intervention in the sense of damaging intervention, but by intervention to restore the normal tendering process that you say you had inadvertently changed. By your act of commission, which was signing a document changing the normal rules, you had changed the rules.

Before tenders closed you had the capacity to fix it up. You instructed your office that you did not want to know anything and, clearly, your department was aware of the fact that you did not want to know anything. Apparently, your department then did not convey to you the views of senior members of this industry that this farce was going to proceed—that there were going to be collapsing bids put in by shonks. Despite your department knowing it, and despite the Prime Minister's department knowing it, nothing was done to fix it up.

You, Minister, are where the buck stops. As you indicated here, if you told your department that you did not want to know about any problems and that you did not want to be involved in this whole matter, that is a culpable and a disgraceful situation by any Minister of the Crown.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Order! Senator Baume, I am feeling quite redundant. Would you address your remarks through the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Madam Acting Deputy President. The Minister clearly has stated today that he did not want to know and he did not want to intervene, no matter what the shambles.
—I didn't know there was one.

—He says that he did not know there was one. His department knew of the certainty of the shambles; the Prime Minister's department knew of the certainty of the shambles; but the Minister did not want to know. I rest my case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had a fairly dramatic demonstration as to why Chris Puplick, a former senator for New South Wales, told the Bulletin recently that more people bought tickets to the sleaze ball than were paid-up members of the Liberal Party in New South Wales.
—The Labor Party is in the same position.

—Is it? We only have about 400 in the Northern Territory, I know that. Senator Baume's question is a serious one, and I will address it. Indeed, I called my office to implement some action after Senator Baume's last question. I am not aware that any advice was given to my department by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I will immediately inquire as to whether that is correct. I think Senator Baume would accept, reasonably, that until I make that additional inquiry I cannot properly address the other elements—
—It was raised yesterday.

—I would stay out of this if I were Senator Crane. I will answer that major and most important part of Senator Baume's question, as to whether high level advice from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet was received by my department. There are a number of crucial elements about that. The advice that I got, as I said in the chamber today, was that there was an approach by an industry representative to an officer of the department inquiring about whether multiple tenders were possible. My advice early today, although it was not specific as to time—I had assumed that that inquiry came after the bidding process was opened; in other words, after the box was open and bids were in—
—No, the boxes weren't open.

—I know what Senator Baume has said. I am saying what my knowledge was. I am just indicating a number of things I will cover. I will first of all check whether there was any such advice from the Prime Minister's department to my department and I will find out whether, if such advice arrived, what time it arrived. Once I have that information I will provide it to the Senate at the first opportunity available to me.
—In this whole sorry saga the claim that has constantly come from Senator Collins, on the other side of the chamber—
—Poor old Bill O'Cheesecake.

—Senator Collins has had heaps of time to give us his erudition. We have not had any to date, so perhaps he will have the courtesy to listen in the chamber to the verdict of this place, instead of showing his total and utter contempt for his ministerial responsibility by marching out. He is marching out because he does not want to know, in the same way that he did not to know what was happening in his portfolio.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins has told the Senate on numerous occasions that he was not at fault because his department did not tell him. But he has also told us that he did not want to intervene. So it follows that, even if his department had told him, he still would not have done anything. As Senator Baume has said, he did not want to know, so it was irrelevant whether or not he was told. He had already made it clear to the department that he did not want to know about these things. He wanted the department to handle it so he did not have his hands dirtied. So whether he was told or not is no defence, given that he has already stated very clearly that he did not want to intervene.

In other words, even if he had been told, he would not have done anything about it. That is the problem. Even if he had been told, he already told them that he was not going to do anything. So, at that point in time he had created the very opportunity for this situation to occur. By sticking his head in the sand, by saying, `I don't want to know what is going on in my department in case I get blamed for it', he has created a situation where this nation has been laid open to spivs and con men to perpetrate frauds on the public and where we are an international laughing stock—all because he did not want to assume the ministerial responsibility that comes with the red leather. That is the problem.

If he had been willing to say, `If there is a problem, come and see me', then it might be an excuse that he was not told. But it was very clear he did not want to know. So whether or not he was told, the responsibility lies with Senator Collins. His contemptuous treatment of this Senate today matches the contemptuous nature in which he has dealt with his ministerial responsibility. He has stuck his head in the sand and it follows, as night follows day, that if his head is in the sand, his backside deserves a kick.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Colston this day relating to the Nurrungar defence facility.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister offered a number of reasons why Australia should continue the so-called joint facility arrangement at Nurrungar. I say `so-called' advisedly because I believe that it is well and truly on record that the base is under effective United States control. The Australian personnel, including the deputy commander, play an extremely subservient role, and there are a number of cases on record where not only were we not consulted before a decision was made and were not involved in the decision but also, very often, we were not even told about it. I shall return to that point shortly.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons that the Minister advanced as to why Nurrungar, in its present form and organisation, is still useful is the contribution it can make to collective global security. I am quite ready to admit that this may well be a useful contribution but, if that is so, it should not be under the control of one particular nation; not the US or even the Australian nation, but the United Nations. Australia could do nothing better than to further and strengthen the role of the United Nations and its current peacekeeping efforts and the growing responsibility it accepts in that area. Australia should transfer control and supervision of Nurrungar to the United Nations.

The other reason offered by the Minister was regional security. If regional security is a concern, surely it should be under the control of the Australian Government rather than a government that is rapidly withdrawing its forces and its concerns from this particular region.

I return to the point I made before. It is quite clear that the United States has effective control of Nurrungar and if it is true, as the Minister says, that there is an early warning role against nuclear attack from other quarters of the globe, by other nations, then the truth is that Australian citizens are likely to be the target of a first attack. If people wish to launch a nuclear conflict—a conflict that involves the United States—the first thing they are likely to do is to knock out United States' communications facilities. That should be very obvious, as has always been acknowledged.

The reality is that our Government is exposing Australian citizens to that particular risk in the potential conflict which we would not originate, which we would not know about, and which we certainly would not have a part in. It is for all those reasons that we should review our participation at Nurrungar and should either abolish it or radically change its organisational structure.

The truth is that the Australian taxpayer currently contributes $30 million to the upkeep of the Nurrungar base. My question to the Minister is: what do we get for it except risk to Australian citizens? Not only do we get risk to Australian citizens, we are also apparently prepared to accept the very

SPEECH.PARA: serious infringement to our sovereignty by allowing a foreign base on our soil over which we have no control and which puts our citizens at risk.

PARA.TAB: At a time when the Government is moving very rapidly towards establishing a more independent form of government for Australia—a republic, which the Australian Democrats support as a general principle—it seems extremely curious that we are prepared to give up effective sovereignty in this particular way. I will not raise the question of economic sovereignty and the way we open Australia up to overseas imports.

I conclude by saying that I believe it is untenable and not worthy of a nation that seeks total independence, and rightly so, to allow another nation to infringe its sovereignty by having a military base on our soil over which we have no control.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What I find exceedingly curious in all of this is that Senator Spindler, who is otherwise as intelligent as he is charming, seems to have an absolute blind spot when it comes to this particular issue. I simply ask him to read very carefully the response that I gave today when it appears in Hansard and to see for himself when he does so that I really have answered quite directly and quite explicitly all the questions he has raised again today, as he has raised in many other public forums.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON ANIMAL WELFARE REPORT OF JUNE 1988: `KANGAROOS'

1. The Committee RECOMMENDS that aerial surveys of red and grey kangaroos be conducted in New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia at least annually but preferably twice a year.

Accepted with modification. While direct monitoring of kangaroos is a State Government responsibility, the Commonwealth sees itself as having a role to assist the States, where feasible. The high cost of aerial surveys already places heavy demands on the resources of State agencies and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS). Rather than to arbitrarily assign survey frequencies, surveys should be more frequent in States where harvests take a high percentage of the population and less frequent where harvests take low percentages. Annual surveys in the eastern States and triennial surveys in Western Australia are seen as sufficient to ensure kangaroo conservation.

2. The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service undertake or commission more research into either the further refinement of the aerial survey method or into alternative survey methods or combinations of survey methods to arrive at more reliable indices of abundance and estimates of total population size of kangaroo species.

Accepted in principle. ANPWS currently devotes considerable resources to aerial surveys of kangaroo and the development of ground survey techniques through the National Wildlife Monitoring Unit (NWMU) and has and will continue to commission research to further refine aerial survey methods and other alternative survey methods. Any new research program would be administered by ANPWS in conjunction with its existing research and survey expenditure.

3. The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service commission or conduct regular surveys by appropriate methods of all species other than red and grey kangaroos which are subject to legal killing.

Accepted with modification. State agencies already undertake regular surveys and generally support this proposal. The Commonwealth accepts that it has a role to assist the States to conduct and develop surveys, within Commonwealth resources. The NWMU has been involved in surveys of the Bennetts Wallaby and Rufous Wallaby in Tasmania, the Wallaroo in New South Wales and also the Whiptail Wallaby in Queensland. Staffing and financial resources currently limit the level of activity by ANPWS in surveys and survey assistance to States, however ANPWS will consider providing additional funding for this purpose from existing appropriations.
4. The Committee RECOMMENDS that the quota include both the commercial and non-commercial kill and that it be incorporated into the kangaroo management program.

Accepted in principle; subject to State agreement. The Commonwealth Government preference is to include both commercial and non-commercial harvests in an agreed quota as it would provide a pre-set limit of the overall harvest. The greatest need for expanding the quota to include the non-commercial kill is where the rate of this harvest is comparable with, or larger than, the commercial kill. This is, currently only the case in Tasmania. Tasmania supports this recommendation, however the other States are generally opposed.
5. The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service commission or arrange research into the effects of a male sex bias in the commercial shooting of kangaroos.

Accepted in principle. Current situation shows differences between the States in level of sex bias. ANPWS will consider allocating additional funding for research, to be undertaken with the co-operation of the States.

6. The Committee RECOMMENDS that before any licence or permit is issued to kill kangaroos or wallabies, the applicant must demonstrate that he is the owner of an appropriate firearm as specified in the Code of Practice.
Accepted in principle. A matter for State action, which is partially supported by some States and also addressed in Recommendation 8.

7. The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service commission as a matter of urgency an independent research project to establish conclusively whether or not shotguns or rimfire rifles are appropriate to kill any species of wallaby humanely.

Accepted in principle. The CONCOM Code of Practice for the Humane Shooting of Kangaroos currently prohibits the use of rimfire rifles, but allows shotguns in certain circumstances. A detailed investigation of the appropriateness of these weapons would be best undertaken with joint State and Commonwealth support.

8. The Committee RECOMMENDS that adherence to the Code of Practice should be a requirement of any licence or permit and failure to adhere should be grounds to suspend, withdraw or refuse to renew a licence or permit.

Accepted in principle. A matter for State action which is supported by some States. The Commonwealth has for some time supported the incorporation of observance of the Code of Practice as a licence condition and while some States have begun to do so, the Commonwealth would encourage all States to adopt this recommendation.
9. The Committee RECOMMENDS that all new applicants for a kangaroo shooter's licence pass a test of marksmanship before being issued with a licence.

Accepted in principle. A matter for State action which is partially supported by the States. The Commonwealth sees this as one means of ensuring only appropriately qualified people are able to take up new kangaroo shooting licences and would encourage all States to adopt this recommendation.

10. The Committee RECOMMENDS that commercial shooters applying for renewal of a licence and who did not kill at least five hundred kangaroos under the kangaroo management program in the preceding year, pass a test of marksmanship before being issued with a licence.

Accepted in principle. A matter for State action which is partially supported by the States. The Commonwealth supports the concept as a possible means of ensuring that only skilled marksmen operate in the industry, but believes the threshold kill figure recommended may have to be examined further by State authorities and that it may be more appropriate to re-test shooters at appropriate intervals according to age.

11. The Committee RECOMMENDS that commercial shooters kill kangaroos for the carcasses and not for their skins only, except where the relevant fauna authority considers a carcass trade is impracticable and authorises skin-only killing.

Accepted. A matter for State action which is generally supported by the States. Consistent with Commonwealth policy, as a total carcass industry provides for data on carcass weights to be collected in addition to sex and age information and therefore produces a more complete monitoring data pool. The Commonwealth believes full carcass shooting is a preferable conservation management approach.

12. The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian Customs Service, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the State fauna authorities establish arrangements for the random inspection of consignments of kangaroo products which are to be exported.

Accepted with modification. Under current administrative arrangements the Australian Customs Service (ACS) is responsible for export verification and is restricted in its ability to inspect kangaroo products by resource limitations and other priorities. Commonwealth ability to inspect kangaroo consignments will be enhanced through establishment of the National Wildlife Protection Unit in the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (Recommendation 13) to work in conjunction with the ACS and State fauna authorities.
13. The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service establish a fauna squad to investigate the illegal export of fauna.

Accepted with modification. The Government has recently established a National Wildlife Protection Unit (NWPU) within ANPWS to consider all wildlife import/export trade (including native birds and reptiles) in conjunction with ACS. This initiative will provide a significant boost to wildlife trade investigations and further clamp-down on illegal wildlife trade, which under current legislation is subject to maximum penalties of $100 000 and/or 10 years imprisonment for an individual, or $200 000 for a body corporate. Funding for the continued operation of the Unit will be made available from existing ANPWS appropriations.

14. The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service establish controls over the export of kangaroo skins by appointing inspectors to check kangaroo skins at fleshing works and to seal containers containing skins for export at those works. Only skins sealed in containers should be exported.
15. The Committee RECOMMENDS that skins taken under approved management programs be tattooed or be able to be identified in some other way after being fleshed when the royalty tag has been detached.

(14 and 15) Accepted in principle. The Government agrees that there is scope for expanding export control over kangaroo products and sees inspections at fleshing works to fall within the responsibilities of the National Wildlife Protection Unit (NWPU). The issue of controls on the export of native wildlife had been the subject of comprehensive reviews of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982. Recommendations contained in this review together with those of the Senate Select Committee will form the basis of operations for the NWPU. The development of uniform containers for export and the process of sealing would however require more detailed investigation along with other alternatives such as tattooing to identify individual skins. The NWPU will give a high priority to investigations to consider the most cost effective means of preventing illegal exports.
16. The Committee RECOMMENDS that fleshing works which treat kangaroo skins for export be licensed by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service.

Accepted in principle. The Commonwealth notes that fleshing works are currently licensed under relevant State legislation. The benefits of additional Commonwealth licensing need to be investigated further by the National Wildlife Protection Unit but the proposal could provide an appropriate means of regulating the export and preparation for export of kangaroo products. Licence control regulations would provide the means for establishing any packaging or skin identification requirements determined from the above investigation.

17. The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service conduct or commission research to determine the nature and level of suffering of wallabies and non-target species which ingest 1080 poison or any other poison used to kill wallabies. Depending on the results of that research, a decision should be made by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service on the future use of poison to kill wallabies in Tasmania.
18. The Committee RECOMMENDS that all methods of killing kangaroos other than by shooting be banned on mainland Australia.

19. The Committee further RECOMMENDS that in Tasmania the use of poison to kill kangaroos be permitted only until such time as the research recommended by the Committee has been completed, provided that the research is carried out expeditiously.

(17, 18 and 19) Accepted in principle. While the Government agrees that the most humane means of harvesting kangaroos should be employed it notes that no currently approved export programs involve poisoning. The Government also notes that the determination of control methods outside the export harvest is a State responsibility. As Tasmania currently has no approved export program, the issue of wallaby poisoning is a matter to be decided by the Tasmanian Government. The Government does however support research being undertaken by Tasmania, or in association with Tasmania (under the proposed Kangaroo Research and Survey Supplement) to quantify the impacts of 1080 or any other poison on wallabies in areas where it is currently used.
20. The Committee RECOMMENDS that, as a fundamental principle, the kangaroo remain a protected animal. However, its deleterious effects on human land use must be taken into account.

Accepted and already supported by State, Commonwealth and Territory legislation for all kangaroo species. The Commonwealth would urge the Northern Territory to consider reclassifying the Agile Wallaby under legislation as protected fauna over its entire range in that Territory (the only species in Australia not so protected), and all States and Territories to ensure that any necessary control of kangaroo species is carried out without detriment to species conservation.
21. The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Commonwealth and the States and Territories work out on a co-operative basis over time a system for national management of kangaroos.

Accepted. In signing the National Strategy for Ecologically Sustainable Development, Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments have agreed on the objective of improved kangaroo management at the national level. Governments have agreed to work towards an integrated and co-ordinated kangaroo management strategy which is based on development of national guidelines for kangaroo management, the use of market mechanisms and the early finalisation of National Game Meat Standards. The impact of kangaroos on productive land use activities such as farming and grazing will be considered in the development of the strategy.

22. The Committee RECOMMENDS that fauna authorities conduct inspections of properties where kangaroos are allegedly causing an unacceptable level of damage to assess the extent of the problem and to advise landholders on methods of coping with the problem.

Accepted in principle. This is a matter of State responsibility and is essentially already in place. While the Commonwealth accepts the principle that property inspections should be made wherever possible, it recognises the limitations to State resources and believes that the need for inspections should be assessed by local State officers. The Commonwealth would however urge the States to maintain a close liaison with landholders and provide an advisory service on means of minimising kangaroo damage.
23. The Committee also RECOMMENDS that the killing of kangaroos be permitted by fauna authorities only where non-lethal methods of containing kangaroo damage are impracticable.

Accepted in principle; recognising it is a State responsibility to determine whether to permit commercial killing of kangaroos and the harvest methods used, particularly where no exports are involved. The Commonwealth would however caution that consideration of non-lethal methods should include determination of any detrimental impacts on kangaroo conservation, such as the potential for widespread use of exclusion fencing to impose significant restrictions on kangaroo mobility and dispersal.
24. The Committee RECOMMENDS that funds be made available by the Commonwealth for research into kangaroo proof fences.

Accepted. The Government supports further research into kangaroo proof fences along with other non-lethal control measures and ANPWS will consider the provision of additional funding for this purpose. Such research will also consider the likely impacts of the fences and other control measures on kangaroo welfare and kangaroo conservation.
25. The Committee RECOMMENDS that commercial shooting of kangaroos continue to be permitted in areas where there is a need to reduce populations of kangaroos for damage mitigation purposes.

Accepted. The Government supports continued commercial harvesting under State management programs, as it sees this as the most humane and target specific means of kangaroo damage mitigation practicable for use on a large scale.

26. The Committee RECOMMENDS that in a non-commercial area, where a landholder does not possess an appropriate firearm or does not pass a test of marksmanship, the fauna authority arrange and subsidise the use of a commercial shooter to contain kangaroo damage, provided that no non-lethal method is practicable.

Noted. This is a matter of State responsibility which is not generally supported by the States. The Commonwealth accepts the principle of the recommendation but believes that the idea of subsidising a commercial shooter requires more investigation, with States mostly viewing the proposal as being impractical. In the first instance, States may consider expanding the role of local officer advisory functions to facilitate contact between landholders and commercial shooters. A commercial arrangement could then be made by the landholder to subsidise the operations of the shooter directly.
27. The Committee RECOMMENDS that fauna authorities be allocated more resources to enable them to fulfil their responsibilities for the management and protection of kangaroos and other wildlife.

Accepted in principle. The Government considers that it is a matter for the States and Territories to determine their budget allocations for wildlife conservation but would encourage expansion of activities and also active consideration of alternative funding sources for fauna conservation and management, to supplement existing funding. ANPWS will consider allocating additional funding for this purpose from existing appropriations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments about the Government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I believe that the response comes as a result of the actions of the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, Senator Burns, who queried the Government in recent times as to why we had not received a response some five years after the report was handed down. I suspect that that is why this response has come forward.

PARA.TAB: Most of the recommendations and replies put forward from the Government are only accepted in principle. Most of the matters referred to are matters which relate to the States. It seems to me that a delay of five years in replying to this report certainly rests with the Minister concerned, and it is something that the Minister responsible for that portfolio should have taken in hand long ago.

When I was appointed to the committee in 1987, it comprised such famous names as Senator Cooney from Victoria, Senator Morris, Senator Brownhill, Senator Devlin, and Senator Norm Sanders from the Democrats. Prior to that we had Senator George Georges, who was the original chairman of that committee.

This inquiry into kangaroos started in 1983 and it took five years to put the report together. It seems coincidental that it has taken five years for the Government to respond to it. If it was relevant in 1983, I guess from what I have seen in the media over recent weeks and months that the matter of kangaroo culling is just as relevant today.

Over the time of the development of this report, all sorts of claims were made by animal liberation and animal welfare groups around Australia. I remember the first accusation made to us in the early days was that we had been nobbled by farming groups and lobby groups and that the report we brought down would not reflect the true views of all Australians.

One major concern of the Australian Conservation Foundation was that we develop national legislation to cater for the proper management of kangaroos and other wildlife populations. I am pleased to see in this response that the Government has accepted that recommendation. The Committee's recommendation to the Government was that the Commonwealth and States and Territories work out on a cooperative basis over time a system for the national management of kangaroos.

In the last five years prior to this response being presented, the national strategy for ecologically sustainable development was signed. Part of it involved the State and Territory governments agreeing on the overall objective of improved kangaroo management at a national level. The major concerns of the major animal welfare groups that were shown in the early days seem to have been answered through the Government's acceptance of responsibility in that area.

It is also interesting to note that Senator Georges was heavily involved in the committee in those days. Of course, he is no longer a member of the Senate. I noticed just the other day that he and his wife featured on the front page of the Telegraph Mirror as having clocked up $33,000 worth of travel. I note further in the article that he is the coordinator of the national kangaroo campaign. It is pleasing to see that, even after all this time, Senator Georges is still showing a keen interest in the kangaroo problem within Australia.

It is interesting to see that recently in Canberra our Governor-General fell foul of the animal welfare lobby in dealing with his problems with kangaroos. For some reason or other, the legislation in the ACT seems to be a little different from that of the other States and from the committee's recommendations. A reading of the Governor-General's problems shows that he certainly got into hot water, if not kangaroo tail soup, when he suggested that he would cull the kangaroos and have a kangaroo feast afterwards. That comment certainly brought upon him the wrath of some animal liberation groups.

It seems that the Governor-General has an oversupply of some 150 kangaroos at Government House, which is obviously creating many problems. The multiplying of the kangaroos at such a rate makes it easy to understand why we have such a problem all around Australia. As my colleagues Senator Cooney and, particularly, Senator Burns, who is chairman of the rural and regional affairs committee, would know, the overabundance of kangaroos was manifesting itself when we had inspections around Australia to look at the effects of the drought on the farming communities and what could be done about it.

European settlement and the provision of more pasture and water have combined to vastly increase the number of kangaroos in Australia—to huge numbers. Figures in the report of five years ago—I suspect they would be much higher now—indicate that the number of kangaroos in Australia was then reaching 32 million. The effect of kangaroos on the degradation of land through their competing for pasture with the few sheep that are now left is quite obvious when you move into the back blocks of the western districts of Queensland and New South Wales.

As Senator Burns would recall, one of the farmers on one of the farms we visited had become insolvent and had moved to Sydney. He left his son on the farm, but the son earns a living shooting kangaroos rather than making his living from tending sheep. In recent times, kangaroo culling and the use of kangaroos has become a very important industry in Australia.

Kangaroos are a great source of high protein, low fat meat. The hides of kangaroos are sought after for their leather. I am pleased to see in the Government's response that the committee's recommended method of culling kangaroos by shooting has been accepted. If this method was accepted in the Australian Capital Territory, Mr Hayden would not be faced with a bill of $40,000 to sterilise a few kangaroos.

I think it is ridiculous in this day and age, when it has been accepted that sheep and cattle can be slaughtered for human consumption, that kangaroos, which are in plague proportions, cannot be culled. Because of public reaction, at Yarralumla the Governor-General is required to spend $40,000 out of his budget to give vasectomies to a few male kangaroos. It is ridiculous when the Government could employ some professionally trained shooters who would solve the problem in one night.

It is no surprise to me that we still see, in the media, reports of well meaning people who are pushing the point of view about perceived cruelty to kangaroos. I note in a letter to the editor from Jacqui Kent, who is a member of the National Kangaroo Campaign in Queensland, that she criticised Tasmanians. That is one of the reasons I am on my feet today. In this letter she stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a new World Heritage Management Plan has been passed which will permit packs of dogs to rip into wallabies on the high Central Plateau of Tasmania. These animals may also be blasted away by shotguns. Neither of these can ever be considered as "humane" methods to kill our wildlife.

If one takes that article as it is, one would be gripped by those very stirring words. In reality, shotguns are used in Tasmania because of the topography of the State. To say that we use high powered rifles particularly in built-up areas where the major problems with kangaroos occur is quite unrealistic.

PARA.TAB: This evidence came out in the committee's kangaroo report. I think it is a pity that these people who are making so much noise and criticising the Governor-General in what he wants to do do not read the report because it took five years to collect all the information. The response we have today has taken five years.

The committee spent quite a deal of time assessing the most humane way to cull kangaroos. The decision to use centre-fire rifles with professionally trained shooters was unanimous until Senator Sanders changed his mind on the day when the report was presented. It was thought that this was the most acceptable way to cull kangaroos. The committee recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that commercial shooters kill kangaroos for the carcasses and not for their skins only. . .

I am pleased to see that the Government has accepted that recommendation. The committee took the view that allowing the shooting of kangaroos just for their skins would be a huge waste of a very valuable product—high protein, low fat meat. This meat is being used only for pet food at the moment. I am pleased to see that some States are now allowing kangaroo meat to be used.

PARA.TAB: In Tasmania we have always used wallaby meat. In recent times a new export industry for wallaby meat has opened up in Tasmania. This is along with all the other wonderful food and wines exports that come out of Tasmania. We are exporting prime cuts of wallaby meat to many areas of the world.

In recent times, when the Tasmanian Government moved to bring in regulations that would complement the kinds of things we recommended in our kangaroo report and which the Government has been trying to get all State governments to accept, once again the old furphy started to surface about cruelty. I cannot understand why everybody in Tasmania, particularly Ms Peg Putt, is getting so uptight about the method of shooting kangaroos down there. After all is said and done, the regulations they were bringing forward were to limit shooting of wallabies to certain times of the year and to tag the animals, which is exactly what happens in Queensland, the State from which Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator MacGibbon come. It has been going on for many years up there. It is Queensland's way of controlling the numbers of kangaroos being culled. Even so, we still see emotions running high, with people writing to the papers and getting uptight about the killing of our national emblem. I can understand that but, as I said earlier, killing kangaroos, as opposed to cows or sheep, for consumption seems to engender much more discussion amongst certain groups in our community.

I am pleased to see that at last the Government has answered these recommendations. I have looked through the answers in the brief time I have had them, and I am pleased to see that most of the recommendations have been accepted either in total or in principle. I am also pleased that the Government has accepted some of the innovative ideas we put forward in our report, such as funds being made available by the Commonwealth for research into kangaroo-proof fences, which would provide protection for farmers and other sensitive areas kangaroos have invaded, as an alternative to the final solution of culling. I am also pleased to see that the Government has accepted that we continue commercial shooting of kangaroos where damage mitigation is required.
