As I said earlier, this problem has been evident over the last few years, particularly in Senator Bjelke-Petersen's State. I know that the drought there is causing all sorts of problems, but it certainly has been exacerbated by the huge numbers of kangaroos.

Now these Government responses are through, I hope some more sensible debate about this emotional subject can go ahead. If the fuss and bother that has occurred in Canberra over a few kangaroos at the Governor-General's residence is any evidence of the feeling in the community, the culling of kangaroos in Australia will always be something people will get upset about. I hope this report, and the responses that have come through at last, will quieten some of the more extreme elements of the animal liberation lobby in our community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and I also thank the Senate. I am a strong supporter of the Australian National Maritime Museum at Darling Harbour, Sydney, and of the extent to which it can be made available, through newsletters and membership, to Australians in every State. Its predecessor, in Port Adelaide, which was directed by the national museum's current director, Dr Kevin Fewster, is another important resource and is an excellent predecessor to this wider canvas that we now see in Darling Harbour.

PARA.TAB: This annual report is very significant because it is the first substantial report. During 1991-92 the museum was officially opened—one of the last acts of the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. During President Bush's visit to Australia in January last year, he made a speech at the museum and the contribution to the museum by the United States was officially received and acknowledged by the then Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and also by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson.

In the short while that I have had this report available to me, I have been able to flip through all of its pages, to see its structure and also to read in detail a number of areas that are of special interest. I commend the museum for the structure of the report, for its financial accountability, for the director's introduction and for the ample number of photographs, which I think are very appropriate for a report of this kind.

I congratulate Mr Peter Doyle, the chairman; Dr Kevin Fewster, the director; and the members of council for the way in which the museum has developed in its first year and a half. I note that the membership of the council includes one of Australia's recent and continuing heroes—or should I say heroines—Kay Cottee, who, as a boatbuilder, a yachtswoman and the first woman to circumnavigate the world solo, has won the imagination of all of us.

Other members of the council include Michael Kailis, a major entrepreneur involved in the fishing industry in Western Australia, whom I have met on a number of occasions, and my good friend Sir James Hardy. He is listed as being a council member from New South Wales, but I would see him as still representing South Australia, the State of his birth, his youth and his first sailing. Indeed, one of the major exhibits in the museum is one of his most successful smaller yachts, which he donated to the museum. I pick out those names, but I commend all of the members of the council and the representative of the Royal Australian Navy for their part in the business of the council.

I refer briefly to the finances of the museum. I see that there is a $17 million annual allocation for operating expenses. Whilst this is balanced, there are creditors of $2 1/2 million for the financial year ended June 1992. I am sure that that is in hand, but on my own visits to the National Maritime Museum I have always asked questions of the director and other executive officers about the financial viability of the centre. I wish it to be entirely viable and able to expand in its exhibits and its accessibility to the public and I hope that its financial matters do reach an even keel very soon.

I note the attendance figures on page 85 and the enormous burst of attendance in December and January, the first two months of its opening. I commend the museum very strongly and I will watch for its continuing annual reports.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to the erratum to the annual report of the Australian Tourist Commission, I am glad to have the opportunity of drawing the Senate's attention to the fact that tourism is now one of Australia's largest and fastest growing industries. This is borne out by the following statement in the managing director's report:
Australia moved back into strong, sustained growth during 1991/92, with short-term arrivals growing by 13 per cent to a record 2.5 million.
On page 10 I noted that the Australian Tourist Commission's prime task was to market Australia internationally as a tourist destination. In fact, on that same page it is stated:
. . . Australia has been rated as the most desirable holiday destination in Japan, the US, Singapore and Sweden.
On page 13 the report goes on to state:
Tourism's developing relationship with the aviation industry and the environment emerged as important policy areas for the unit outside its core planning and evaluation role.

The aviation part of our tourism industry is something which I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate. Successive federal governments have for decades promised Brisbane an international airport befitting the city's stature as the international gateway to the State's tourist attractions. But unfortunately this has been put off time and again. When we think about the growth of tourism in Australia, we need to recognise that Queensland is a very important tourist State and the money that comes from tourism is of great help to the economy. In view of this, I think it is very important that the Government does do something as soon as it can to help get the new airport facility built. An editorial in the Courier-Mail the other day said:
The first and most damning observation to be made is that the present international terminal is a disgrace. It is cramped and substandard compared with similar terminals in other States.

It is something we would expect to see in the Third World rather than in a thriving capital city. Indeed, Queenslanders have often complained that Brisbane international airport is little more than a shed compared with the world-class domestic terminal that is sited across the runway.

PARA.TAB: As Queensland depends heavily on its reputation as a popular tourist destination, it is very important that something be done. When we realise that Queensland's economy is set to lose $27 million in visitor revenue unless the international airport is completed before its scheduled opening date of January 1996, it is very important that action be taken.

Apparently, the main stumbling block to a revised schedule is that the Federal Government will have a shortfall of $8 million. However, when we consider that Queensland's economy stands to gain at least $27 million from an expedited completion date, it is hard to understand why the Federal Government hesitates at all. The Federal Government is, in effect, turning down a 350 per cent return to the economy. When we acknowledge the fact, as I said earlier, that tourism is one of this country's largest and fastest growing industries and may indeed hold the key to an economic recovery, surely it should be one of the main priorities of any government at this time.

In 1991 alone, tourist expenditure in Australia amounted to $25 billion and tourism's contribution to GDP exceeded 5 per cent. Tourism accounts for approximately 450,000 jobs, either directly or indirectly. Indeed, some 1,000 jobs are likely to be created should the Government see fit to fast-track this project. I ask the question: how can the Government afford not to encourage this industry? The continuing growth in our tourism industry has contributed to the fact that Queensland has had one of the lowest unemployment rates in Australia. The fact that our economy has such a large tourism base largely accounts for this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the correction to the Australian Tourism Commission report. I do so simply to support the call of my colleague Senator Bjelke-Petersen for urgent attention to be given to the state of the international airport at Brisbane. As Senator Bjelke-Petersen has said, and as has been reported fairly widely in the Queensland press, the current facilities are a disgrace—and for Australia's premier tourist State, that is simply not good enough.

PARA.TAB: When we talk about tourism matters, I always indicate with some pride that the airport at Cairns in Far North Queensland is a great example of what can be done when local people are given the opportunity to direct how an international airport should be built and operated. Indeed, the international airport at Cairns was constructed by the Cairns Port Authority, a semi-government authority made up principally of prominent people in business and government in Cairns. The authority constructed that airport many years ago now and Cairns has not looked back since.

There has been enormous tangible benefit to Australian tourism from the building of that airport. Cairns is now the tourist gateway to Australia. It has many more international flights than, for example, Adelaide and the number of flights continues to increase all the time. This has occurred because the tourist people in Cairns have supported the airport as well as the other infrastructure and development that needs to be implemented to attract overseas tourists to our land.

I am aware of the expansion in recent times of activities run by Cairns tourist operators. These are not major corporations but little one-, two- and three-people businesses. These established businesses are now looking to expand their activities. I know of a tourist operator involved in whitewater rafting who is now taking people into New Guinea. He is even going further afield into the Pacific islands. This business, which is all generated from Cairns, is assisted by the fact that the Cairns airport is so good and so popular.

The tourist area in the city of Cairns has a boom feeling about it. I might say that this tourism capital of Australia would have benefited substantially from the Liberal-National Party proposals for the tourist industry that were put forward in the run-up to the last federal election. It would have benefited quite substantially from the additional money that we would have made available for advertising and promotion, particularly in Europe and America from where we attract a lot of tourists to far North Queensland.

As I say, I concur with my colleague's remarks about the Brisbane airport. I urge the Government to have a look at this matter and give it a bit of urgency. In looking at ways in which that can progress, the Government should consider what happened in Cairns many years ago and possibly learn something from the advancements that have been made there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to speak on this report, but I find the remarks of Senator Macdonald rather hypocritical. On other occasions Senator Macdonald has spoken very strongly in favour of the building of the Tully-Millstream power station; in his speech a few moments ago he talked about the excellent business which has been developed in Cairns for whitewater rafting on the Tully River. This activity, which employs quite a large number of people, will be totally destroyed if that power station is built. Senator Macdonald then went on to say that tourist operators in Cairns are taking visitors from Cairns to experience whitewater rafting in New Guinea. Of course, the reason they have had to use other rivers is that, if he had his way, he would close off this option.

PARA.TAB: I have rafted down the Tully River. It is an absolutely magnificent experience and one that should be protected. Quite a large number of people are engaged in giving tourists an experience that they can gain in no other way. People are employed not only to operate the rafting but also to make videos of tourists' experiences and to provide meals and transport. As such, this activity really needs to be looked after. I am really surprised at Senator Macdonald's dissimulation in dealing with this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I should not let this go. Under standing order 191, could I explain a part of my speech which has obviously been misunderstood by Senator Coulter?
—If you believe that you have been misunderstood, go ahead.

—I do not want to interrupt the course of the Senate too long, but obviously Senator Coulter has misunderstood this. He says that he has been on the Tully River. If that is the case, then he would know that the Tully Mill hydro-electricity project, which still has my strong support, will in no way interfere with white-water rafting. If Senator Coulter knew anything about it, he would appreciate that the construction of the Tully Mill hydro scheme would enhance whitewater rafting in the area by providing and guaranteeing all year round water in the Tully River.

SPEECH.PARA: The significant thing in this report of the Australian War Memorial is the reference to the 50th anniversary of the opening of the museum in 1941. I will deal with the routine part of the report first. The most significant part is in the new acquisitions list which includes the acquisition of a P40-E aircraft for the collection. The museum has sought this type of aircraft for many years because of its great Australian military relevance. It is a worthy addition to the collection of memorabilia in the museum.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy President, you will remember the problems we had in the Senate estimates committee hearings, both the main estimates and the supplementary estimates, where the $550,000 cost of this aircraft was to be paid for in part by disposing, in quite a reprehensible way, of an equally historic aircraft. It is not without amusement that I see the statement in the report:
The aircraft's $550,000 cost is being funded by disposing of appropriate collection material.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that slipped past the editor of this report. It is quite wrong to be disposing of what is appropriate material in the collection at present. That is a matter we will raise at one of the estimates hearings in the near future.

PARA.TAB: The Senate should reflect on the great achievement in setting up the Australian War Memorial. It is a memorial that in my experience is unique in the world. It is a very fine memorial to those Australians, men and women, who served this country in all the wars that we have been involved in. The memorial has a budget of $15 million. The great difficulty that the museum faces, and which it refers to very politely in the report, is shortage of funds. There is nothing new about that. Governments of all persuasions since the museum was opened have failed to come up with adequate funding. But, as each year passes, the collection gets larger, the responsibilities of the museum and its obligations thereby increase and so the gap gets wider between what is required and what is provided.

One sees that critically in the curatorial services and their inability to maintain the collection. Some of the material in that collection now goes back over 100 years. It requires highly skilled curators with sophisticated techniques to keep it in a condition whereby it will survive not only for another 100 years but for times beyond that. The memorial also needs considerable storage space. This report does refer once more to the difficulties of inadequate storage and the problems that that brings.

The other great difficulty that comes from lack of funds is the inability to change displays. Whether it is an art gallery, a museum or a memorial, to maintain public interest one must be able to rotate a collection. The actual collection in a facility like the Australian War Memorial is many, many times the number of exhibits that are on display at any one time.

The Australian War Memorial is an institution which I think attracts more visitors than any other similar institution in Australia. There is a huge throughput of Australians and overseas visitors going through the war memorial. As the war memorial report says, the system works against getting repeat visits from visitors because of its financial inability to change the displays that it would like to.

Only about 10 days ago, I was fortunate to be in France for the 75th anniversary celebrations for the battle of Villers Bretonneux. While I was there I met the director of the Historiale de la Guerre, the new museum at Peronne. It was very interesting to see what is being done there with respect to new display techniques. It is a great pity that because of shortage of funds the Australian War Memorial, which actually loans some material to that museum, cannot avail itself of the modern display techniques, including modern videos and the simple format of the displays that are being used in France at present in that museum.
The bigger issue with respect to shortage of funds clearly is the deterioration of the collection—a state of affairs that will continue unless adequate curatorial services are provided.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak briefly to the Anti-Dumping Authority annual report and in particular advert to page 11 of the report which provides a brief run-down on the legislative amendments made to the anti-dumping legislation last year. One achievement that we can record is the reduction of time in the prima facie decision stage, which came down from 35 to 25 days.

PARA.TAB: That was rather disappointing. Originally, the Australian Democrats had an amendment before the Senate to reduce it to five days and the Opposition had a similar amendment. That amendment was passed in the Senate, but when it went to the House of Representatives the Government rejected it. When it came back the second time before the Senate, the Australian Democrats were deserted by the coalition. We stood alone on the question of the five days and obviously that amendment was defeated.

It was an important amendment for Australian industries which are being hit to leg by a rising tide of cheap imports, as we have again seen demonstrated by the recent balance of payments figures, the worst for three years. It is important that we make it easier for Australian industries to fight the dumping of cheap goods. Other countries are doing it. The United States accepts a prima facie judgment and when it finds an industry is facing what they call `disruptively high levels of imports', the United States authorities do not hesitate to slap immediately emergency countervailing tariffs of up to 100 per cent on these imports to make sure that their industries do not go down the drain.

We do not seem to have that same concern. At the moment it seems to me that the Anti-Dumping Authority should be renamed as the `importers authority' because it helps importers. It helps people who compete with Australian products because it is taking a very sharp stance against Australian producers.

Another aspect that needs to be looked at is the interpretation of the legislation by the Anti-Dumping Authority. The provisions of the legislation require that an industry shows that not only are the products being dumped at prices below their production cost in their own country, and not only is damage being done in general terms to the Australian industry, but also that a causal relationship is established between the damage that the applicant has experienced and the dumped goods.

Two celebrated cases, Caford Castors in Melbourne and Greenseas cannery in Eden on the New South Wales coast, were able to show the first two, but the authority rejected their claim for the second. I have read some of those reports. It is beyond me how it is possible to say, in general terms, that the industry is suffering damage; yet the applicants are judged not to have shown a direct link between that damage to the general industry which has been linked to the dumped goods and their own particular difficulties, despite the fact that these companies are experiencing a drop in turnover and consequent retrenchments.

It is high time that this chamber looked again at the anti-dumping legislation. At the very first opportunity the Australian Democrats will move amendments designed to protect Australian industries rather than overseas importers, and we look forward to the support of the Opposition for those amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the annual report of the Anti-Dumping Authority, I wish to raise very briefly and very broadly some of the problems with the authority and some of the proposals that the Liberal and National parties had for making the Anti-Dumping Authority far more effective.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, you would know, as we all do, as we have moved around Australia over the last couple of years, particularly in the pre-election period, that people were very concerned about the Government's proposals to reduce tariffs—proposals which, in some instances, the Liberal and National parties agreed with. We do live in a more competitive world and we have to realise that on many occasions tariffs, while they benefit one industry, are quite substantially paid for by another industry.

When people demand level playing fields, they do not seem to understand that under the anti-dumping and countervailing measures there are proposals to stop goods coming into Australia and being sold at a price lower than their cost of production; or goods and services being sold in Australia that have been subsidised by their government in their country of origin. If we were effectively able to stop those goods coming in with those unfair advantages, a lot of the concern that is expressed about removal of tariffs would dissipate. The coalition recognised that. It had a very good plan to improve the Anti-Dumping Authority to ensure that goods that were coming into Australia unfairly would be stopped and penalised by the imposition of anti-dumping duties.

In the Fightback proposals, we indicated that we would ensure a fairer trading environment by introducing effective anti-dumping and countervailing procedures. We proposed to reduce the preliminary inquiry period to 65 days, after which provisional measures could be imposed. We would then allow the Australian Customs Service five working days to determine whether a complaint lodged met with formal requirements. The ensuing preliminary inquiry would, in normal circumstances, take a maximum of 60 days and up to another 30 days in exceptional circumstances. Provisional measures would be available after a positive preliminary finding. The preliminary inquiry would be followed by a final inquiry of up to 90 days.

To ensure that a fully informed decision was made within these time limits, the coalition, if in government, intended to provide adequate resources to both the customs service and the Anti-Dumping Authority. We would ensure that the injury tests currently imposed would not require the virtual decimation of an industry before action is taken, as can happen under the present legislation.

We urged the Government to take up our proposals to reduce those time limits quite substantially, and also to look at the injury test to make sure that an industry does not have to be down and out before it can get some relief. Hopefully, in the term of the current Parliament, the Government will take up the proposals. I hope that, in its next report, the Anti-Dumping Authority will be able to report that the Government has adopted our proposals and that, as a result, Australian industries are given a much fairer go against subsidised and less-than-cost-of-production imports.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Heritage Commission is the Commonwealth's chief agency for identification and assessment of areas of conservation and cultural significance. Over the years it has performed an extremely vital role in establishing and maintaining the register of the National Estate and in providing information and advice to the Commonwealth about areas entered on the register.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators may remember that last year during Question Time I asked a question about the AHC. I referred to the perceptions in the community that the commission was becoming increasingly remote from the community and from environmental groups. I had heard from environmental groups that significant concern existed about the role of the commission in the regional assessment process. I had also heard that concern existed about the general direction in which the commission was heading; that is, away from more open community involvement and community organisations and towards a greater interface, specifically with the forestry industry. Concern was expressed that the commission was being co-opted by State forestry agencies.

After I asked this question, I was contacted by staff of the commission. We had a very productive meeting at that time, at which we discussed the changing perceptions of the community in relation to the AHC and what action the AHC was taking to counter these perceptions and to increase the community participation in the working of the commission.

I have always been a vocal supporter of the AHC, as have the Australian Democrats. We have always advocated a very strong and independent role for the AHC. Our concern centres very much around this changing role for the AHC and, specifically, the direction the Government seems to be giving it. We still have many of these concerns.

In March 1991, the former Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, announced his commitment to provide, for instance, resource security legislation for the timber industry. As part of this commitment, he promised to establish a process of integrated regional Commonwealth-State assessment of environmental and heritage matters. The AHC was to be responsible for the implementation of this joint assessment process.

In March 1992, the Prime Minister, Mr Paul Keating, announced in the One Nation statement that he would initiate resource security legislation for the forestry industry. This was supposed to be done without compromising environmental values. This totally unrealistic commitment was, as every senator knows, defeated in the Senate last year by the Democrats and the coalition although, as everyone knows, the coalition's opposition to this Bill was not based on its concern for the environment.

The commission established a regional assessment group to cope with the increasing workload created by these additional responsibilities. The commission has worked on two major regional assessment projects, one in south-west Western Australia, which has been completed, and one in the East Gippsland region of Victoria. The Western Australian agreement has been criticised by environment groups because it has led to a situation where the State forestry agency has legitimised and entrenched its role in the logging of native hardwood forests. In fact, logging activities in the karri and jarrah forests have increased in intensity since the agreement was finalised. A regional assessment in Tasmania has been proposed. However, I understand that there is very little cooperation with the Tasmanian forestry agency and suspicion from conservation groups in relation to this process has also meant that the process has not got very far.

My main concern is not with the Australian Heritage Commission itself but with this new role adopted by the AHC that is being driven by government policy. There is a real perception in the community that the AHC is working more closely with industry and less now with the public. I appreciate that the staff within the AHC are very concerned about this perception and that they recognise that community participation is still highly valued. In fact, the AHC has recently completed two major studies into the enhancement of community participation in the National Estate. But my main concern, I stress, is about government policy, and that concern remains.

So I commend the work carried out by the AHC in identifying and assessing those areas that deserve to be listed on the Register of the National Estate. However, I believe that the Government must redefine its forestry policy and thereby redefine the role of the Commission vis-a-vis State forest agencies and, in doing so, restore public confidence in the Commission.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the annual report of the Central Land Council for 1991-92. This 80-page report very comprehensively covers the activities of the Central Land Council. I am certainly one to criticise at times much of the administration of land councils in the Northern Territory, but, as honourable senators will appreciate from my comments in a few minutes on the next two reports, the reports of the Anindilyakwa Land Council and the Tiwi Land Council, and on this one, the report of the Central Land Council, I extend a compliment to those three land councils on the way they have carried out their activities. I will be making far more critical and trenchantly strong remarks about the activities of the Northern Land Council, which I do not hold in high regard at all. I think its report to this chamber is lousy.

PARA.TAB: But in looking at this particular report of the Central Land Council, the work that is obviously being undertaken with regard to agreements and attitudes to policy in all aspects is very important on behalf of the people of central Australia. I was very pleased to note the comment on page 61 of the report, where the council gives an analysis or a quick comment on the coalition green paper on Aboriginal affairs by Dr Michael Wooldridge, the then shadow Minister, in June of last year. The paper gave it the same tenure and status that it afforded to a number of other Northern Territory Government, local government and Federal government initiatives in that year. I am certainly aware that the work that is imposed on many of the commissioners is onerous, particularly when they are drawn from a large geographic area.

In particular, I note that the expenditure and financial statements are unqualified in the auditor's report. I find that very pleasing. I am also pleased to note the special references to the trust administration by the Central Land Council of the royalty trust accounts that it undertakes. The details that are set out on page 79 and 80 of this report properly analyse the trust details on behalf of various trust accounts. Unlike the Northern Land Council, which has omitted these sorts of statements in its report, it is commendable that the Central Land Council has fully met its obligations in this regard. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

This is the first annual report of that body. It is interesting to note the following, in the Chairman's opening remarks:

Some of our people here wanted to have their own Land Council because they thought the Northern Land Council was too big to help them personally. They didn't know our culture or our people because they came from different places.

This report is unqualified in regard to the financial statements. I commend the Land Council in that regard. It is interesting to note the range of activities that the Land Council has undertaken on behalf of the Aboriginal constituency they represent. It has been, as it acknowledges, involved in negotiations with Telecom, organising telephone services. It has negotiated with the Australian Maritime Safety Authority concerning lighthouses. It is involved in negotiations with BHP, which is very important as the manganese miner, regarding mining agreements. Of course, as anyone would expect from an Aboriginal land council, it is deeply and sincerely involved in discussions about sacred sites, sea closures and other issues. This first report is commendable. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tiwi Land Council is that area of administration that is generally known to many people as encompassing the Bathurst and Melville islands to the north of Darwin. It is also an important small land council and a breakaway group from the Northern Land Council, which has been so controversial and which has obviously not met the aspirations of Aboriginal people. The Tiwi Land Council has been operating for some time. It engages in a number of commercial activities on behalf of Aboriginal people. The report highlights many issues. I wish to comment on three. The first issue is—and I quote from the Chairman's report:

. . . the growing interest and academic success of our younger people at diploma and University access level. Sixty-seven Tiwi students, comprising 4.5 per cent of our population, are studying at tertiary level. . . Ten years ago we recognised the future required proud and secure Tiwi people. The welfare net may save our bodies, but our hopes were drowning. We still have much to do, but there is now evidence of a belief in our future.

PARA.TAB: The second issue relates to what the Tiwi Land Council believes to be a census anomaly. The census has identified a declining Tiwi population in the area and the Land Council is taking steps to ascertain what is happening to the population. I note that there are particular illness problems on the Tiwi Islands. Further in the report mention is made of the incidence of kidney disease in the Tiwi Islands and the important work that is going on there by the Menzies School of Health Research.

The third issue that the chairman has drawn to our attention is that of the mining views and the views of others who seek to influence the Tiwi people. Again I quote from the report of the Chairman, Mr Kerinaiua:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we . . . were very surprised at the determination of non-Tiwi people to tell us what we should do. Stories that our land would sink and disappear or blow-up in an atomic explosion, were told to frighten us. Our visits to existing mineral and sand projects allowed us to see just what goes on.

There are important prospects for sandmining on the north of Melville Island and the Tiwi Land Council will have to deal with those matters very intricately, and I know they are doing so very responsibly. It is a pleasure to note the keenness, the determination, of this particular community and the fact that their accounts are unqualified. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

By then our time will probably have elapsed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the comments that I have made, very pleasingly, on the Central Land Council, the Tiwi Islands and Groote Eylandt, this report of the Northern Land Council is very concerning and ought to concern every honourable senator. The activities of the Northern Land Council need almost a royal inquiry. Next week, at the Senate estimates committee hearings, I certainly intend to pursue a number of issues very keenly. The point which requires our most urgent attention is the auditors' report for the year ended 30 June 1992, which is qualified by the following:
1.Expenditure on land claims exceeds the approved budget item by more than 20%. This contravenes Section 34 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (NT) Act 1976.
2.Total expenditure is in excess of the total approved budget. This contravenes Section 34 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (NT) Act 1976.

3.Note 12 to the financial statements states the intention of the Northern Land Council to distribute $546,003 pursuant to Section 35(1) of the Aboriginal Land Rights (NT) Act 1976 and sets out the distribution made in 1991/92. We are unable to express an opinion whether these distributions are in accordance with the provisions of Section 35 of the Act.

The Northern Land Council needs to be condemned for its profligacy and its total inattention to the proper standards of good administration on behalf of its Aboriginal constituency. It has obviously become a very political and involved organisation. For a number of years it has relied on the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, and the former Minister, Mr Hand, propping up its annual budgets and throwing more money at the problem rather than seeking decent solutions. I have put three very important issues before Minister Tickner since early this year. The first relates to very severe allegations of rorts of fringe benefits tax by senior management personnel within the land council itself.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the trust accounts and mining royalty funds which the Northern Land Council administers on behalf of its own constituency are not even covered in this annual report, other than to get gobbled up as two one-line items in the annual balance sheet. There is no listing of the trust balances as there were previously; there are no statements of income, revenue and expenditure, as should properly be set out in these particular accounts.

The third issue that I have raised with Minister Tickner is the excessive use of consultants to carry out anthropological, legal and administrative functions of the land council. This has amounted to in excess of $1 million in the last year as a proportion of its budget. Many of these consultancies have been going to former employees of the land council who have retired or taken redundancy packages, or who are relatives of senior executives within the organisation. There have been jobs for the boys. There have been all sorts of pay-offs. Certainly, in the Senate estimates committee hearings next week I will be demanding and looking for explanations. I am concerned that, in the comments by the chairman on page 1 of this report, attributed to Galarrwuy Yunupingu, is the statement arising from and following the Mabo decision we all deal with in so many areas. SPEECH.PARA: On first hearing the news of Mabo I said the Federal government should quickly negotiate a treaty and implement national land rights. That would be a good start. The alternative is plenty of court cases around Australia, but this is not the best answer.

That second paragraph of the chairman's annual statement in the NLC's report highlights how political this organisation has become and how much it has moved away from the good and proper focus that it needs to give for the constituency it should and ought to be serving. The administration and finance of the NLC are a disgrace. The budget blow-out is totally unacceptable and this matter needs a major inquiry at the earliest possible date. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Higher Education Funding for the 1993-95 Triennium

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I bring the 1991-92 annual report of the Department of Employment, Education and Training to the notice of the Senate because of the outrageous claims it makes in relation to government education policy. The report quite correctly notes that the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 has been amended to implement the policies outlined in the report. However, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) and his department then go on to claim that the changes to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Act 1988 increase the autonomy and flexibility of our universities. It is important for the Senate to know that this statement is complete rubbish and, in fact, the opposite has occurred.

PARA.TAB: The changes to this Act which the report refers to actually has resulted in all universities in Australia being placed under the direct control of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. This completely bypasses the role of the States which are constitutionally responsible for our universities. Up until 1987 there was a reasonable degree of cooperation between the Commonwealth and the States on policy formation for the universities. This State authority has been eroded severely since 1987 and now has been eliminated altogether.

The report reveals an even more disturbing change. There is a big difference between the funding of the universities of Australia through the appropriation of Parliament and funding them through ministerial determination. Under the new arrangement, the appropriation is not subject to scrutiny. There is no debate in the Parliament and amendment is no longer possible. Under a ministerial determination, the whole decision is left up to one person's discretion—the Minister's.

I also point out to the Senate that this ministerial determination has not as yet been presented to the Parliament and that universities are still obviously operating with funding. The question therefore arises: why has the determination, which is a disallowable instrument, not been tabled? What is the Minister hiding? Why is public comment being hindered by the Minister's delay in presenting his determination? In the Canberra Times on 12 February, Crispin Hull says that the new funding arrangements:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . will have a huge impact on the independence of universities and ultimately academic freedom, which is one of the important legs of our democracy.
He also says that the new legislation is:

divisive, can wreck universities' autonomy, will eliminate the states' role and put unnecessary power in the Minister's hands. It has the potential to be an insensitive, centralised and dangerous power. The universities in Australia are too important to be placed under the ministerial thumb.

This opinion was supported by the editorial in the Canberra Times on 14 February and letters to the Australian and the Canberra Times signed by seven professors of the Australian National University, including one of its founders, Sir Mark Oliphant. It is therefore clear that, contrary to the claims of this report, the higher education sector has lost autonomy and flexibility under the policies of this ALP Government.

The Government is continuing to centralise control of the higher education sector, and our universities are losing their autonomy and their independence. As higher education funding now stands in Australia, the Minister of the day has the power to determine how much funding each university will be allocated and the Minister will base his determination on a set of criteria which universities have met through his insidious profiling process.

PARA.TAB: The only real scrutiny the Australian Parliament has over the higher education funding sector is in the global amount for the entire sector. This means that the universities may be forced to abandon their own research and teaching agendas and follow the social and economic vision of the Labor Government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: There is much in this report of the Automotive Industry Authority that we can be pleased about. The quality of cars produced in Australia is judged to be equal to that produced overseas. The price that we have to pay here for the six-seater family car is approximately equal to the prices that are charged, for instance, in the United States. Our exports in the automotive industry are up by eight per cent.

PARA.TAB: However, there is also another story. Table 2.5 of the report shows that from June 1988 to June 1992 imports of passenger vehicles rose from 65,000 units in 1988 to 147,000 units in 1992, an increase of 82,000 units—over 100 per cent. Table 25 in Appendix 1 shows that during the same period 10,756 jobs were lost in the industry. The accelerating trend of imports in recent years is highlighted by the import figures for the period 1991 to 1992 when there was an increase of 23,698 units. During the same period—the link is very clear—the producers of cars, the assemblers of cars and specialist component producers shed 5,113 jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: When jobs are shed because of increased productivity, in one way we can be pleased about that so long as we ensure that provision is made for retraining and relocation of the people who are affected. However, when jobs are lost to imports, despite the fact that a level of prices and quality has been reached which on the face of it makes us competitive, I believe this calls for a second look at our policy as it relates to the car industry.

We should be very cognisant of the fact that this is one industry in which the Government has decided to intervene. We have a plan, statistics and a policy so that we can monitor what is happening. This report is extremely important and deserves further consideration. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
