SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

TAB.TAB: (a)recognises that:
(i)the wool industry is in the worst situation since the inception of wool production in Australia, and
(ii)many individual growers, especially those in pastoral or drought-stricken areas unable to grow cash crops, are in an extreme financial situation;
(b)notes that the industry's problems are devastating rural communities and service towns;
(c)notes the contribution made by the wool industry over the past hundred years;
(d)confirms its belief that there is a long-term future for the industry;
(e)calls on all political parties to work jointly towards a long-term solution by actively seeking to increase demand on a continuing and long-term basis in new as well as traditional markets; and
(f)while recognising that some small measure of relief is being provided by the Government, calls on the Government to address the suffering endured by various individual growers.

SPEECH.PARA: I will briefly go through this motion. Basically, paragraph (a)(i) states that the wool industry is in the worst situation since wool production began in Australia nearly 200 years ago. In fact, each woolgrower today is losing approximately $30,000 per year. The people and towns that rely on individual woolgrowers, especially those in areas where nothing but wool can be produced, such as some pastoral areas of Australia—some pastoral areas can run cattle, but some are limited to producing wool as they cannot run cattle or grow cash crops—are in a very extreme financial situation.

PARA.TAB: I make particular mention of the towns and industries that service those areas. If the woolgrower does not survive or make a dollar, neither will the corner store, the ever decreasing number of doctors, nurses or pharmacists, the small business people who service and sell machinery or the supply stores in those remote communities. Everyone in those areas will suffer badly.

When debating this motion we must recognise what the wool industry has done since its inception in Australia. Not only has it supplied massive amounts of income tax to the Treasury but also it has employed people, and provided an opportunity for dealers to sell their machinery and service people to sell their services. We have to recognise that when looking at establishing a system for the future. That is one reason why we have to recognise the woolgrowers and help them to survive the situation that they are now in.

I, like most woolgrowers, and everyone else in Australia believe that there is still a long-term future for the wool industry in Australia. In the last 40 years I have known at least three sharp downturns in the wool industry. Each time, the industry has revived and prospered and then prepared itself for the time when wool prices again drop. It happens in most service industries and the other industries that keep Australia going. Successive governments have recognised this by making special contributions or allowances available when they occur. It happens to all industries.

Of course, not the least affected are the present one million unemployed. The Government is attempting to do something to alleviate their suffering. I believe that it should do the same for the wool industry.

I have always said in my statements on the wool industry, especially since the latest severe collapse, which probably started last November, that we should be taking a bipartisan approach to this issue. There is no need—it will not do anything for the industry—for political point scoring. We have to move forward in a united way because this problem will require more than a six-month solution; I am looking at a five- to seven-year solution, if not longer.

I have twice asked Mr Crean, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, to come to Western Australia to address the growers. I know that he talks to the peak bodies of primary industry around Australia. It would help if he spoke to growers person to person so that they could hear what he has to say and he could hear first-hand what they have to say. Amongst other things, woolgrowers need some personal commitment to, and understanding of, their problems as well as financial help in these extreme circumstances. I am very disappointed that, as at this time, Mr Crean has not seen fit to travel to Western Australia, even though he recently travelled to the drought areas of Queensland, after which he came home and recognised that there is a problem there.

I thought that in the Governor-General's speech the other day there might have been mention of the problems that exist in the wool industry and some measures by which the Government would assist the woolgrowers in such circumstances. Unfortunately, there was no mention of it. I believe that every other group in Australian society got a mention. The woolgrowers certainly did not.

I will digress for a moment. I have listened to a few first speeches in the last few days. I took particular note of the speech by our new Labor senator from Victoria, Senator Kim Carr, and the speeches of two new members in the House of Representatives—Mr Smith, from Western Australia, and the member for Capricornia. They had the common theme that Australians have shared responsibility and that we share the wealth of Australia.

I think that principle of sharing wealth with industries remains true of the Labor Government, except when it comes to the rural industry. Rural industries have certainly shared their wealth by paying massive taxes when wool prices have been high. I believe that it is time that the Government recognised the situation that woolgrowers are in and did something to help them in the future.

Because we have quite a number of speakers on this subject, I will briefly explain what the situation has been in recent years. Senators may remember that in 1988 the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, agreed to lift the reserve price from 700c a kilogram to 870c a kilogram. That was the beginning of the disaster.

The Government had its own representatives on the board of the Australian Wool Corporation to investigate the reserve price scheme. The Minister was fully aware of what was going on at that time. There were a lot of woolgrowers around Australia who were not at ease with increasing the reserve price. But the Minister agreed with the Australian Wool Corporation's recommendation. That was the wrong thing to do at the time, but that is water under the bridge. If the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and Mr Kerin want to wipe their hands of the situation, they must remember that they were part of the decision that was made to lift the reserve price. They must also realise that they caused the disaster.

Nobody needs me to tell them again what has happened since. Even though the scheme collapsed in February 1991 because of rising debts and massive production rises, the corporation still operated the reserve price until 30 June 1991. As a result of that collapse we have a massive debt. Australia now has a debt of $2.1 billion and a stockpile of 3.9 million bales. As woolgrowers we must take responsibility for that debt; no woolgrower wants to walk away from that debt.

There were a lot of inequities, which I will point out, in having this unreal reserve price scheme. These inequities led to overproduction. In 1985-86, 173 million sheep were shorn in Australia. In 1990-91, due to the unreasonably high reserve price, 212 million sheep were shorn. Production in greasy kilograms went from 813 to 1,030 million during that period. That was far too great a production to sustain such a price.

The Government was part of the decision to introduce a reserve price for wool. I know the industry was at fault, but the Government was also because it agreed to the scheme. Mr Kerin was running around the world giving guarantees which upset our relationship with the other trading nations.

I suppose one could ask why I am standing in this chamber outlining all the problems and indicating what the Government has not done. In the brief time I have, I will outline some solutions that are available. Various solutions have been put forward by others.

One solution put forward is the destruction of the stockpile or dumping the stockpile in the ocean. This would mean that the stockpile would not act as a dampener on prices. I do not believe that is the way to go. I believe that if we left the present debt for future generations, or even the present generation, to deal with, it would still not be the way to go.

It has been suggested that the stockpiled wool could be given away as foreign aid. I do not think that solution is very practical. One could suggest that the stockpile be sold at a premium, but I cannot see the stockpile moving. The stockpile has moved very little in the last 12 months. The idea of putting a floor price on the stockpile does not seem to work either.

At least 1.8 million bales of wool in the stockpile are made out of locks, bellies and pieces that never, at any stage, should have been in there. They should have been sold at the price offered at the time and the reserve price should have been used only for premium wool. I believe that that wool should be put out to tender immediately and got rid of.

I believe that the long term solution lies in more aggressive marketing and in developing markets in places where wool can be used but is not being utilised at present. The main thrust, and the Government's thrust, should be towards eastern Europe where mills have been sold off at bargain prices for government enterprises, as eastern Europe enters a new found democracy. If we could exchange our raw material for equity in those mills—we are allowed up to 51 per cent equity in those enterprises—we would have those mills captive forever for Australian wool. That is the way to go.

There are some mills that are not on the market whatsoever but, as those countries do not have the hard currency to buy raw material, we should give them raw material in exchange for equity towards the finished product that goes on to other markets. I was with a parliamentary delegation to the region, led by our own President, Senator Sibraa, and we could see the opportunities that lie there. So the solution lies in creating long-term demands, because we have lost our market share with the high prices that we have had in the past. Cotton and synthetic fibres have increased their market share, which we will find very hard to get back.

But other speakers will outline further our belief and the way that the Government, or everyone in Australia, should attack the wool crisis. But in those five or seven years it will take to rectify the position in Australia, the Government has to do more than the various superficial measures it announced last week. One of those measures was to extend debt repayment simply for another year. The Government has to do far more than that to make sure that those viable woolgrowers can remain in position to take advantage of the situation when the wool industry revives, hopefully by these measures that will be put into place with a bipartisan approach. I will leave it at that, and let my colleagues further the argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking in this debate today in my capacity as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, I will firstly say that in terms of the motion that Senator Panizza has moved, and in fact most of his contribution, there is much with which the Government can agree. I think his points (a), (b), (c), (d) and (e), which recognise the problems the wool industry is facing and outline the particular contribution of the wool industry to Australia's economy, are quite valid.

PARA.TAB: The point at which the Government would take issue is point (f), which calls on the Government to take some small measure of relief in addressing the suffering endured by various individual growers. I will outline a little later the details of the package that was announced last week. Before I do so, I will deal with a couple of matters on which I disagree with Senator Panizza, the first one relating to the personal commitment by the Minister, Simon Crean.

The Minister did visit Queensland. His primary purpose in doing this was to look first-hand at the effects on the wool industry, and also because that area is stricken by a terrible drought. Senator Panizza expressed concern that there had been no visit to Western Australia. Frankly, even though I am sure that the wool industry in Western Australia is suffering similar problems, it is very difficult for the Minister to visit every wool region in Australia. The Minister did not visit Tasmania, and personally I would have liked him to do so. But it is a bit impractical to expect the Minister to visit every wool region in Australia. The important thing is that the Minister visited a representative area of the industry as quickly as he could, analysed the situation and put together a package, which in a moment I will briefly outline, to deal with some of the problems faced by the wool industry.

No-one pretends that this is an easy issue or an issue that will be resolved very quickly. I take issue with Senator Panizza's analysis of what he referred to as the cause of the disaster; that is, the lifting of the reserve price by the previous Minister, John Kerin.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shared responsibility.

—Well, shared responsibility. That may have contributed to the current problems being faced by the wool industry. Senator Panizza referred to the former states of the Soviet Union and eastern Europe. I agree with him, but I do not think anyone could have predicted the collapse of the Soviet Union, the way in which it was going to occur or the terrible effect it would have on the wool trade.

PARA.TAB: Our outstanding wool debt with the former Soviet Union now totals some $260 million. I do not think anyone in this place seriously suggests there is much chance in the short term of collecting too much of that $260 million. The wool arrears have been rescheduled and are to be repaid in 10 equal and successive six-monthly instalments. The first repayment is to be made on 1 January 1995 and the final one on 1 July 1999. I think it will be very difficult to collect the existing debt, let alone sell any significant amounts of wool to Russia and expect the payment fairly quickly. I think that is a very important part of the wool debate that Senator Panizza did not touch on in any detail.

One other matter that does cause me concern—and the Opposition does like to perpetuate myths—is the reference to the Governor-General's speech. I draw pages 20 and 21 of the speech to the attention of honourable senators. There are a number of references to primary industry and various programs in that speech. I want to put to bed the accusation that we have heard continually for the last two days that there was no mention of primary industry issues in the Governor-General's speech, because there was.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about wool?

—Wool is not mentioned on page 20 or page 21, and it is not mentioned in the speech. Wool is not alone in that. Many other industries in Australia were not specifically mentioned in the Governor-General's speech, and I do not think it should be viewed as a slight on the industry.

PARA.TAB: I have already referred to the very rapid response by the Minister in visiting Queensland, in the context of both the wool problems and the severe drought being experienced there. On his return the Minister was able to put together and have Cabinet endorse in a remarkably short time—a matter of only a couple of weeks—a quite reasonable package to deal with both the short-term and the long-term issues that are fundamental to the future of the industry.

The package included funding by the Commonwealth of up to $44.6 million under the exceptional circumstances provisions of the rural adjustment scheme, commonly known as RAS, for specialist woolgrowers. It will cover the period from May 1993 to June of next year. The package includes $5 million from the Commonwealth to provide support under the exceptional circumstances provisions of the RAS to drought affected woolgrowers in Queensland and New South Wales. It also includes the maintenance of the wool tax at 8.5 per cent from 1993 to 1994, and that will mean 3.5 per cent for wool promotion. I hope no-one in this debate will suggest we should not be having some sort of financial contribution for the industry for wool promotion, because that is part of the long-term answer to the industry's problems.

The package includes 0.5 per cent for research and development—my previous comments apply to that issue—and 4.5 per cent for the management of the debt and the stockpile. The package also includes extending the Australian Wool Realisation Commission's debt repayment schedule from seven years to eight years and introducing more flexibility to the setting of those repayments. Also, a committee has been established to review the wool industry structures and the operational arrangement. It is to report back to the Minister within the next three months. The Minister will be visiting a number of the key international markets.

I know that earlier today Senator Calvert requested that I arrange a meeting with him and the Minister concerning some wool matters. I accept that the Opposition, in very large part, is genuine in its attempts to achieve a bipartisan approach on many of these difficult issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Totally genuine.

—Just about totally genuine; I will give it 99 per cent. There was the occasional political barb in there. We would not be politicians if we were not occasionally point scoring in debate, but I do accept the bona fides of the Opposition on many of the points it has raised.

PARA.TAB: The motion before us implies that the Government has not done enough. I have outlined what I think could realistically be expected, given the total cost of the package. I listened with interest to Senator Panizza, and I will be sitting through the whole of this debate and listening with interest to the contributions of other Opposition senators in the hope that they will detail—and I mean detail—the sorts of things that Senator Panizza called for in his motion but did not detail. In particular, I refer to the sort of financial contribution that the Opposition, as an alternative government, would be willing to make over and above what this Government has committed. I will be listening with particular interest to details of the proposed costs of what such an alternative government would be prepared to provide.

The package outlined by the Minister has been broadly welcomed by many of the groups in the rural community. I have a news release from the New South Wales Farmers Association. It is not an organisation that was forward in its support for us at the last election, but I accept that its welcoming of the Crean package is quite genuine. The news release says:

SPEECH.PARA: NSW Farmers' Wool Committee Chairman, Charles Armstrong, said that the $44.6 million extra Rural Adjustment Scheme funding would also help wool producers in the short term.
The changes to the debt repayment schedule and the effective removal of the stockpile from the wool market until July 1994 are seen as positive moves to put confidence back into the market.
These two actions should have the effect of reversing the decline in the wool price, but I would stress there is still much to be done to overcome some of the other problems of the wool industry.

The New South Wales Farmers Association then detailed some of those issues. As I have mentioned, the other parts of the package should deal with some of the longer-term problems that the industry faces. I have deliberately kept my remarks fairly short because I did give a commitment to some of the Opposition senators who intend to speak that we would endeavour to allocate time to as many honourable senators as possible.

PARA.TAB: There is a common concern about the human tragedy that is occurring on the land in this country at present, not just in the rural sector associated with wool. When I was reading through the media cuttings that I am given as a result of my portfolio responsibilities, I saw a report in the Courier-Mail of 30 April of a grazier suiciding as a result of the drought tragedy. In fact, I was discussing this with Senator Boswell yesterday. The terrible circumstances which our rural industries are facing at the present time are reflected in this terrible human tragedy. I will not give the grazier's name, but the article stated that a 55-year-old father of two, a former councillor with the Bowen shire, was found dead behind a shed on his cattle property on Wednesday morning. He had shot himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were three in the north of New South Wales.
—There have been others, I know. It is a terrible example of the terrible circumstances that people are facing in the current rural crisis. A colleague of the grazier stated:

PARA.TAB: He was trying to save his stock. He was a very compassionate man. It's a long time from now until they can expect any rain in November.
He had a heart as big as a lion, it was built to match his ambitions, he was a role model for a lot of people.

SPEECH.PARA: The article went on to state that he had won the property in a land raffle in the 1960s and built it into a prosperous venture. That is a tragic example of some of the problems confronting us.

PARA.TAB: The Government welcomes the opportunity to be involved in the debate today. We accept sincerely the contribution of the Opposition. We on the government side believe that the package put together by the Minister—a package put together very quickly in the circumstances following a quick response by the Minister to the areas affected in Queensland, both for drought and wool—is, in the circumstances, very substantial and is a very substantial reaction. Some of the criticisms made by Senator Panizza are simply not valid and the Government rejects them.

In conclusion, the Government looks forward with interest to hearing some detailed response from the Opposition, and alternative government, as to any further measures it would be making in the current circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to the contribution made by Senator Sherry. I am quite sure that if I do not then Senator Boswell, Senator Campbell, Senator Chapman or Senator Crane, who will speak in the next little while, will respond to some of the suggestions Senator Sherry made.

PARA.TAB: It was quite interesting listening to the Governor-General's speech the day before yesterday. He delivered the speech under headings from A to Z. I listened the whole way through for a mention of the rural crisis. When he was talking about A for agriculture, I thought that something would be mentioned but nothing was. When we got to D, I thought we would hear something about drought or something about the disaster facing the wool industry. When we got to F, I thought there would be some mention of farming or perhaps the wool industry. When we got to P, I thought we would hear something about the pastoral industries and again nothing was mentioned. We could have had a bit about primary industry, but the closest we got was `pharm', which ended up as pharmaceutical. The Governor-General did not even talk about the farm. I am therefore worried about whether the government of the day has an interest in the wool or farming industries because there was no mention of them whatsoever. Even when we got to W for wool, there was no mention—

TALK.START.PARA: —We were asleep.

—You were asleep, were you? You should not have been. It is disgraceful that the Governor-General, in giving the program for this Government, which Senator Sherry tried to defend a moment ago in saying that the Government has done a lot for the wool and rural industries, did not mention these matters in the whole speech.

PARA.TAB: The wool industry was once Australia's biggest export earner, the one which carried Australia for decades. It was largely responsible for opening up this great nation of ours. This is the industry which the Keating Government has absolutely failed. In fact, the Australian community has ridden on the sheep's back for so long that it is now time the rest of Australia gave a little bit back to the industry which has helped them so much over all those years.

In his reply a moment ago to Senator Panizza's motion, which I strongly support, Senator Sherry basically said that the Government has done a fair bit, that it has done enough. I tell the Government that it has not done anything yet. It does not realise the enormity of the problem. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) rushes out to Queensland for a couple of days to look at things and thinks he is an instant expert, but he is not. He does not realise the enormity of the problem.

Wool prices at the moment are at their lowest ever in real terms. There is a stockpile of 3.9 billion bales. Only four years ago the Australian wool industry earned the Australian economy some $6 billion in exports; it now earns only $3 billion dollars. There is a tremendous amount of financial hardship, there are tremendous problems—Senator Sherry just mentioned suicides, for example—and people are really hurting.

The average woolgrower will lose nearly $34,000 this year. This means that, on average, in the past three years each wool grower has lost nearly $108,000. Most wage earners could not comprehend the statistics I have just quoted—$33,000 gone in just one year and more than $100,000 blown away in just three years.

I was given some figures the other day on the debt per sheep and those figures are really worrying. One study estimated that the debt ranged from $15 per sheep to $28 per sheep, or $3.20 to $5.80 per kilogram of wool. A woolgrower would break even with a price of 420c per kilogram and the indicator at the moment is well under 400c a kilogram. That is a real worry.
An article I read in the Sydney Morning Herald by Anne Davies stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Telecom has reduced call charges between capital cities by up to 9 per cent but calls to rural and remote Australia will fall by only 2 per cent or not at all under the new pricing arrangements.
The Australian Consumers Association said:
There is a real danger that many, including rural and remote consumers, will become second best customers in the new competitive environment.
I would say that the rural and regional communities are second rate with the package the Government has come up with to help an industry that has helped Australia so much in the last century.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the human face to this wool crisis is immense. Senator Sherry mentioned the problems of people committing suicide as well as other problems in respect of what is happening in the rural areas. An article I was reading in a paper only the other day stated:

SPEECH.PARA: On average, one farmer was leaving the land every hour of every day.

If that is the case, this Government has to grasp this problem and do something about it. It has to help the wool industry maintain its position as the leading primary industry in this country and make sure that it has the chance to survive so that when the economic upturn comes around in the world our woolgrowers will be there to do something.

PARA.TAB: There is a mountain of problems out there. There is a mountain of problems which were actually created in the first instance by Senator Sherry's Government putting interest rates up so damned high that people could not jump over them. Interest rates were at 20 per cent plus. The Government drove farmers to the wall before the commodity downturn came. They were driven to the wall before they even had a drought.

Just one year ago with the drought inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, on which I had the honour of being deputy chairman and on which Senator Sherry has served, we heard some of the most tragic stories of people in the western divisions. They have had some rain in western New South Wales since we were out there. However, the problem is even worse now because they have had a commodity downturn, they are still paying off debts caused by those high interest rates that the Government foisted on them, and they are not getting the help and assistance they so justly deserve.

I was talking to some people in the western division this afternoon and two agents from the Broken Hill area cited some interesting figures which I believe are pretty correct. The on-farm price for a bale of wool is now about $185; that is about $1 a kilogram. In round figures, 30 fleeces go into a bale. Shearing costs for that bale of wool are about $3 a head. So that is $90-odd for that $185 net on-farm bale of wool. Drenching of each sheep costs about $1.50; that is fly control, dipping, et cetera. So basically, by the time we have paid our costs, interest rates and debt, and looked after ourselves, we are well out of pocket on that net on-farm bale of wool. There is really no money left to feed the family or send the kids to school.

That is where I do not think the Government has addressed things quite well enough. It is saying that if people have assets, they are not entitled to some of the help that they justly deserve. I believe something has to be done about that.

The problem is not only in the western division; it is now starting to come into the tableland areas where there are big rural properties which have done well for very many years and which are now starting to feel the pinch. They are feeling the pinch because of the commodity downturn, the high interest rates from so long ago and the costs and charges which are being foisted on them all around the place by the Government.

It is very easy to say, `We are giving help again'. The Government is giving plenty of help to the waterside workers when it makes them redundant; they get something like a $100,000 golden handshake. If a farmer becomes redundant and has to leave the land, what does he get? He gets $45,000, but that is still subject to the income and assets test. The Government is looking after the waterfront guy—giving him 100,000 bucks—but it is not really looking after the people who are being forced off the land because of a lot of the problems associated with the Government.

There are problems all along the line. Those opposite are quite happy to give as much money to Kodak as they have given in rural assistance. Is that fair dinkum? Is that right, when we have a wool industry which is suffering as badly as it is at the moment? We have an industry which deserves help and assistance, and those opposite are not giving it.

I have a lot more things to say, but many others want to speak in this debate. My last point is this: the other area that the Government has not looked at is helping the shire councils with the rates that are not being paid by the woolgrowers and other people suffering from the drought and the wool decline. It is not helping with the alleviation of government charges, and it is not helping with the levy alleviation because it is still making those farmers pay their 8 1/2 per cent levy. If the Government had given them a bit of assistance with that, it would have given farmers a little money to put food on their table.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved today by Senator Panizza is quite straightforward. In Senator Panizza's language, it lists various things which it asks this chamber to recognise and note. I will not waste the time of the Senate by re-reading them but, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, I find it quite easy to agree with those things which Senator Panizza has asked us to recognise, because they are self-evident.

PARA.TAB: We have a situation in the wool industry which is worse than any other situation since that industry's inception in Australia. It has reached the stage of a truism. It has reached the stage where words are not sufficient to redress this problem. It has reached the stage where, in agreeing to define the problem, we are not actually doing anything to resolve it. In essence, that is what I want to spend a few minutes today speaking about. While we can stand here and agree with this, and while we can pontificate about what the problem is and what the potential solutions might be, until we actually act, we have done nothing for which we should be admired.

The motion itself is bland enough and it can be agreed with. It contains enough platitudes to be readily acceptable to all, and of course we accept it as a statement to be agreed with. But I am afraid that it does not propose any action. In some ways we can be thankful for that, because ideas to solve the problems of the wool industry abound—in almost every newspaper we pick up, in the letters to the editor, et cetera. The so-called solutions to the ills of the industry do abound. But what does not abound is action.

I think that the Government was rightly criticised for its failure to make particular detailed, precise mention of wool in the Governor-General's speech. The Governor-General's speech would give little hope to those who are struggling to resolve the actual problems which are being faced by woolgrowers today. It was not a speech which inspired us to action. Indeed, for some of those in the chamber, it was such a somnolent sort of arrangement that it inspired quite the opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't want to shoot the messenger.

—Not wanting to shoot the messenger, I would suggest that, as an inspiration for action, this speech failed. I do not know what I can say here today that can inspire this Government into action to resolve this problem.

PARA.TAB: In listening to Senator Panizza, I was pleased to hear that he is not one of the `burn the stockpile' brigade. That is a suggested action which would have disastrously negative results, not the least of which I would have thought was patently obvious. One of the many letters to the editor about this particular subject observed that it would be interesting to watch Mr Wayne Goss of Queensland actually trying to burn the stockpile; he would need a few packs of matches to do that. Mr Merrylees of Euroa, who wrote a letter observing that, is to be congratulated because the sort of superficial, glib action that is proposed in that way is a bit harder to deliver.

As honourable senators would know, the stockpile is not a bunch of bales of wool stuck beside the wharf in Melbourne. What we have is wool distributed throughout Australia in various places, and at one stage there was even a considerable amount of it overseas. The cost of administering, safe-guarding and storing that wool stockpile is considerable and has to be borne by those very people who have produced it. To go along with a match and set fire to it is, frankly, physically rather difficult.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was actually a French visitor who proposed it.

—The day we need to be advised on our wool stockpile by the French will be a very sad day indeed, and I know Senator Sherry thinks that too. I was pleased to hear Senator Panizza speak of the quarter of a million bales of locks and bellies that actually comprise a significant part of the stockpile because it is with regard to that section that I propose some action ought to be taken. I was pleased also to hear Senator Panizza talk about aggressive marketing because I think that is precisely what ought to be done. As a matter of fact, Senator Panizza said a lot that I agree with and on which he is to be congratulated. Selling on the basis of exchanging equity in some projects in our traditional markets is also an idea on which he should be congratulated. I agree with Senator Panizza on all those remarks.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that we need to be looking at a very large part of the stockpile to be marketed not in the traditional way that wool has been marketed—not necessarily as a textile, not necessarily recognising all the fine qualities of wool, but recognising some of the other qualities. I have already mentioned wool's innate resistance to being easily burned, its elasticity and its insulation properties. The fact is that wool that has been bought at 700c or 870c is wool that is not readily seen as being the raw material which it in fact is. It is an insulator; we should be promoting it as that. I have insulated my home with it and, as a competitor to synthetics, it is miles ahead. Those who have worked hard to establish it as an alternative insulation product should be supported.

Wool is not only a heat insulating product but also a sound insulating product. We import a lot of synthetics to stick in cars to deaden the noise under the bonnet and to do all sorts of things in sound deadening, but wool is remarkably good in that sphere. We are still importing synthetics and we are still making wool bales out of synthetics. It has been demonstrated that some of the sorts of wool that Senator Panizza was talking about would be eminently suitable for manufacturing into wool bales themselves. It would have the side effect of reducing the contamination which is such a problem in the wool industry. This contamination is sometimes added to during core sampling when some of the synthetic fibres become mixed in with wool.

These sorts of propositions are not easy to come up with when we do not have action by this Government—a government that has the philosophy of reducing intervention. I must say that the coalition also supports most aspects of a non-interventionist government. The Democrats want to see more direct intervention by the Government in this area and a lot of other areas. The Government should be taking the lead, whether through tax subsidies or through the Government actually going ahead and buying some of that wool and proposing to do some of it itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —What you do think Professor Garnaut will do?

—I do not think Professor Garnaut will be proposing any government intervention. That would be entirely opposite to his stance on any other aspect that he has proposed. That is why criticism should be made here. I would like to see a recognition that the Government accepted responsibility for creating the problem and also now accepts the responsibility of solving it. To accept that responsibility is to act. Senator Coulter earlier today suggested that action could be taken by increasing Australia's foreign aid. A lot of people have proposed giving it away to somebody.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter's suggestion is that foreign aid could be served by the Government actually buying the stuff. It could then be provided as development aid to developing countries. It would not compete with our traditional markets. It would be raw material used by developing countries. In fact, the provision of raw materials could well be a stimulus to the establishment of industries which would at some stage in the future be seeking further raw materials from Australia. If it is imaginatively dealt with, government action could recognise the responsibility as well as create a solution to the problem in the future. That is the sort of thinking that is required by Government—actual government actions and actual interventions.

Apart from the marketing that Senator Panizza has mentioned, with which I agree, the other area which begs for direct government intervention is the area that was touched on by Senator Brownhill in much more detail than I propose to do in the time remaining. I refer to government intervention in accepting responsibility for direct financial assistance. I too was on the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs which examined the drought problems. At that stage I supported the concept of the Government providing transaction based subsidies for those who were suffering from the drought.

We have an occasion here when we should recognise that what is required is government intervention rather than just words. It is years since Senator Lees and myself first proposed that the assets test for assistance such as Austudy should be done away with. It is years since we first asked the coalition to join us in voting for that. We hear a lot of words, but they result in not much action.

TALK.START.PARA: —While most Australian people and industries continue to suffer under the recession inflicted on them by the mismanagement of this Government, it is beyond argument that rural people, and wool growers in particular, are suffering much more than most. That is why it is entirely unacceptable, as has been mentioned by Senator Bell and earlier speakers, that there was absolutely no mention of the wool crisis in the Governor-General's speech opening this Parliament last Tuesday.

PARA.TAB: It is nonsense to suggest, as Senator Sherry did a few moments ago, that many other industries were not mentioned in that speech. That may well be true. But it is also undoubtedly true, as Senator Sherry failed to mention, that many other industries are also suffering under this recession. No other industry is in the crisis situation that the wool industry faces today. That is why it should receive particular attention in this re-elected Government's program over the next three years. Of course, such attention ought to have been mentioned in the Governor-General's speech opening this Parliament.

It seems that the only thing we can agree on about wool in Australia is that we do not agree about the extent of its difficulties, and in particular about how the problems of the wool stockpile should be solved. The longer the argument goes on, the more the industry continues to suffer. There is no argument that some of the problem is not of Australia's making, but it cannot be argued that it is not our problem. Australia must find the solution to this problem.

I have great difficulty accepting the arguments of some farmers that the stockpile should be frozen. One can understand the concern behind that reasoning. Many farmers feel that unless the stockpile is frozen, they will be left insecure and that it is a gamble. Perhaps 10 or 20 years ago that view may have been correct. But I believe that freezing the stockpile simply leaves that insecurity hanging over the heads of the industry, and of growers in particular. As long as that stockpile remains, it will have a depressing effect on the international demand for current production and therefore a detrimental effect on the current price of wool.

We have to recognise that the world of trade is now a vastly different place from what it was many years ago and that a 3.9 million bale stockpile of wool, which represents 85 or 90 per cent of the current annual production of the wool industry, will continue to depress wool prices. By its continuing existence the stockpile will create a necessary increase in the wool tax to pay for both the storage and the interest costs of that stockpile. Those costs are simply a burden that wool growers can no longer afford to carry.

It currently costs about $240 million per year to maintain that stockpile through the interest payment on the debt and through storage costs. Growers simply cannot afford to pay that in the current situation where they are receiving such historically low prices for their raw wool. There is no other way forward but to aggressively market that stockpile, cut the industry's losses and move forward without crippling the future financial ability of the industry.

A focus on increasing demand and creating demand must be the highest priority for the industry. Unless consumers are willing to buy, changes to the wool tax, to industry structures and to selling systems are unlikely to reduce the stock to manageable levels. We must aggressively market the stockpile overseas and also apply some lateral thinking to its marketing.

It has been clear for many years that we have to develop new and alternative uses for wool. For consumers worldwide, paying for wool and caring for wool has rendered it a luxury item when compared with man-made fibres—synthetics. While that has been addressed in advertising terms, we have been tardy in researching what can best be described as the big picture of where wool is heading. This has resulted in the current crisis, which is the culmination of many different difficulties peaking at once. We have lacked the managerial skill to deal with that crisis.

It may also be time to halt the mind-set that Australian wool is a glamorous commodity and accept that it is a commodity, full stop, which we must sell overseas whether it be as wool for use in the textile industry as is traditionally used; for items such as wool insulation batts; for soaking up oil spills; or for whatever other non-traditional uses entrepreneurial minds and some lateral thinkers may come up with.

The are two difficulties confronting us are the short-term difficulty with the stockpile, and the long-term viability of the very industry itself. Both stand a good chance of being part way solved if we can take wool in new directions, not just for now but permanently.

While it is possible that we can reduce and probably eliminate the stockpile in a controlled fashion, it appears impossible thus far, when considering the views that have been put forward, for all interested parties to agree that this is the way we have to go. Perhaps aggressive marketing will convert the doubters.

We have to accept that we are at the crossroads for this industry which is of such great importance to Australia. If the industry, and therefore Australia, which still remains heavily dependent on its prosperity, is to move forward and prosper, we have to find new uses for wool and new wool users within the world textile industry. We must assume a much more aggressive and entrepreneurial approach to achieve these goals.

A wide range of possible initiatives have already been put forward by wool industry bodies. They include placing wool in markets where access to hard currency is restricted, using wool from the stockpile to establish equity in joint venture processing facilities in specific mills or in those countries with hard currency problems, using stockpile wool for the development of domestic processing facilities in Australia, using stockpile wool for specific foreign aid programs and to cement Australia's relations with specific countries, and ensuring that more aggressive marketing of the stockpile is done in a way that does not damage the selling of new wool from current production.

The overriding consideration of all of these initiatives is the need at all times to isolate stockpile sales from existing ongoing demand. In my view, the best way to get an urgently needed substantial reduction in the size of the stockpile, while allowing its eventual use in any or all of the ways that I have just outlined, is to call tenders for the purchase of specific quantities and types from the stockpile on the condition that wool so purchased must not find its way back into existing uses and markets, which would only further depress the market and price for wool coming onto the market from current production.

There may be some practical difficulties in policing this requirement. However, I understand that, for example, it is possible to chemically treat wool to make it impossible to be used in textile manufacturing. This would ensure that purchasers would have to find new uses for the wool that they have purchased by tender, whether it be for insulation, oil spills or any other alternative use that might be developed. I believe there would be entrepreneurs willing to punt on their capacity to resell wool for such alternative uses, if the tender process was initiated.

The industry should at least take the steps of researching this option and the practical difficulties of it, which I certainly do not underestimate, and also try to find ways of overcoming those practical difficulties. Should the Australian Wool Realisation Commission decide to develop any or all of these marketing initiatives, the Australian Wool Council and the IWS have indicated their commitment to make available the resources and personnel to assist in that task.

The task of stimulating demand for Australian wool for traditional uses, however, hinges on three critical elements—quality, improvements in selling methods and international wool promotion. Customers continue to point to quality failures in the fibre we supply and we must address this seriously, not only to safeguard our future but also to give us an added marketing advantage compared with other exporting countries.

The Australian Wool Corporation recently addressed this need through the establishment of a contamination task force. The task force investigated quality systems for the wool industry, and its report recommended the adoption of total quality management. We can market successfully only if we have a quality product to sell. This has been echoed by the international retailing community, most recently by the Managing Director of Country Road, Mr Stephen Bennett, and also Peter Glover from Marks and Spencer in the United Kingdom.

In the light of other colleagues wishing to speak in this debate, I conclude by simply reiterating that the Australian Wool Corporation must have three clearly defined goals as essential characteristics of future profitable wool marketing. Firstly, there must be a higher quality product; secondly, there must be efficient channels of distribution and market information; and, thirdly, there must be cost-effective promotion. The current crisis of the wool stockpile must provide the catalyst for appropriate action to be taken in the future to ensure that this industry remains a viable one, not only to the benefit of woolgrowers, but to the benefit all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have a limited time in which to speak, I will get to the basic points that I wish to make. I congratulate Senator Panizza for moving this motion. I would also like to discuss a few things which I believe could be done to improve the current situation. I express my dismay that wool was not mentioned in the speech made by the Governor-General the other day. One must justifiably criticise the Government and the wool industry for not having in place a long-term strategy for handling the stockpile and the production of wool in this country at the time the reserve price collapsed.

PARA.TAB: We on this side of the chamber made our position absolutely clear. We even went so far as to suggest a slaughter scheme, but we were knocked all over the place. At that time, we said that the production of wool would have to get down to 700,000 kilos a year if there was to be any chance of our handling the stockpile without crunching the market. We now know that production is still over 800,000 kilos a year, and that is a fundamental problem.

Having rejected the option of reducing production, the thing that the industry and the Government must now do—and it is the Government's responsibility to rural Australia and to the infrastructure which exists in this country to take the lead—is reduce the size of that stockpile.

This can be done in a number of ways, as long as it is pursued with vigour and a little bit of vision. Other uses of wool have already been mentioned. I particularly want to mention the utilisation of wool as an insulator. Like Senator Bell, our house in Perth is insulated with wool. It is cheaper and better than alternative forms of insulation, but one never sees it advertised or promoted. With the right promotion, effort and marketing, this area can expand, and the Department of Trade must assist with this. China, for example, is utilising only 60 per cent of its production capacity. We have a wool scouring operation in Fremantle, which we visited recently, that is working three days a week. That could be utilised in part of the process. It needs some leadership, promotion and effort. Hopefully, at a later time, I can enlarge on this issue.

The second issue I wish to mention in respect of utilising wool and addressing the stockpile situation is the importance of upgrading the overseas marketing of our live sheep and mutton, which is something that has been forgotten. That is the other side of the equation. It will be a real challenge for us to go back to the situation we were once in, but I do not believe it is impossible. It is not only a challenge to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean); it is also a challenge to the new Minister for Trade (Senator Cook). We need to market in the Middle East, Asia and these other countries. We need to carry out proper promotions and trade negotiations so that we can get rid of the surplus sheep that have nowhere to go. That is another option we have which has not been pursued. I understand that we still have only three agricultural attaches in the whole world. Looking at the agricultural production in this country, that is certainly an area that needs to be addressed.

As other speakers wish to participate in this debate, I have had to restrict my time to five minutes. The challenge to the Government in this motion which we are supporting is to take a bipartisan approach to solving this problem. Pain and suffering are occurring in rural Australia now. Every woolgrower in this country is losing $5 a sheep every year. That cannot be allowed to continue. In fact, it is a disgrace that it has been allowed to go as far as it has. No other section of the community has ever been put under so much pressure, in terms of its social wellbeing, its financial wellbeing and its contribution to this country—after all, it did put $3.8 billion into the economy last year—and been neglected for so long.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was also appalled that the Governor-General's speech—prepared by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his office, I presume—made no mention of the wool crisis that is now afflicting so much of rural Australia. As Senator Panizza quite rightly pointed out, it is afflicting specialist woolgrowers and pastoralists, in particular, who have no alternative. They cannot go into cash crops or move across to beef production or other alternative forms of income.

PARA.TAB: It was a disgrace that in a very long speech the wool crisis was not even mentioned once. I must say, having read so frequently about the Governor-General's newly found rural pursuits of riding horses, shooting kangaroos in his bottom paddock and even eating kangaroos, that one would think he personally would have some influence. Perhaps it would be better if he were the Prime Minister and if Mr Keating went off to Yarralumla and lived for a few days out there.

More seriously—I mentioned this in a debate yesterday—some specialist woolgrowers I met recently at Boyup Brook, south of Perth, were not happy that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Simon Crean, was dealing with the problem. They thought that the crisis was now so serious and so deep that it required the imprimatur of the Prime Minister to state that he believed personally in the future of a wool industry, that he believed personally in maintaining Australia's rural infrastructure and the small country towns and larger regional centres which are being destroyed by the crisis afflicting the wool industry.

During my meetings over the last couple of weeks with specialist woolgrowers two matters were brought up time and time again. Senator Sherry has asked us to be more specific in our contributions about the sort of assistance that is required. I cannot—and I do not think it is appropriate in the sort of broad brush policy speech we are making at the moment—go into those sorts of details but I can tell Senator Sherry, and I hope he takes it back to the Minister, that these woolgrowers, to whom I have spoken at some length over the past couple of weeks, have said that the rural assistance scheme, or RAS, as it is known colloquially, and the RAFCor. are seen as totally inadequate schemes for delivering the sort of assistance that is required in this crisis.

The criteria for viability and assistance and the bureaucratic method of processing assistance through RAFCor. and RAS are seen to take too long and to have, to use the words of these specialist woolgrowers, too narrow a window to enable farmers to become eligible for assistance through those means. I must support the concept of some other survival-type assistance being delivered to farmers with some sort of viability.

Take the position of a specialist woolgrower in Queensland, in the south-west of Western Australia, or in Senator Sherry's home State of Tasmania, which is also your home State, Mr Acting Deputy President, who has no other form of income and who has lost his farm, income and lifestyle. It would be of little difference if that woolgrower's homestead were perched on a rolling green hill or in a dust bowl in drought-stricken western Queensland. When one loses ones farm, family, lifestyle and income, it makes little difference what view one has out of ones homestead window.

With those words I would encourage the Minister for primary industry, the Prime Minister—and I am thinking on my feet, suggesting that this might be an act of bipartisan or non-partisan faith with the woolgrowers of Australia—and perhaps the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, to tour, together, for a day or two some of the regions where the wool crisis is hitting deepest to show to the people that there is a commitment at the very highest levels of our democracy to the survival of a wool industry and a recognition of the contribution which the wool industry makes to the very fabric of Australian society.

It is very popular to talk about a sense of national identity and coming to grips with multiculturalism, gender balancing and all the sorts of concepts the Governor-General went through in his speech two days ago, but the balance between the country and the city, the very fabric of Australian society, is based on the foundation stone of our very strong outback community, the concept of the pioneer. It would be helpful if the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition were to join together in a non-partisan affirmation of the importance of the wool industry and in a genuine commitment to seeing the industry through this crisis.

I want to conclude—in time for Senator Boswell to make a contribution—by supporting the remarks of all senators who have said that we need more active and aggressive marketing of wool. It is easy to say that but if I had a stockpile of any product—be it, say, motor cars; for example, Ford Capris—the last thing I would do to sell it or to try to get rid of it would be to set up a series of bureaucracies like the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. The way to run down the stockpile and to market wool more aggressively is to ensure that we get the process in the hands of small entrepreneurs and sales-based people and out of the hands as much as possible of bureaucrats sitting in offices earning set salaries, regardless of how much wool they sell in a particular year.

I have also met a number of entrepreneurs in Western Australia in the last couple of weeks. One of them I met last Friday, a fellow by the name of Felix Smith, who has a company called Envirofirm, one of the biggest wool insulation providers in Western Australia. He has told me of the frustrations he has had dealing with the Australian Wool Corporation. He is not allowed to use the Woolmark on the houses in which he puts the insulation. When one has a house that has wool insulation in the ceiling, the very minimum one could do is put a Woolmark on the front door; it actually becomes a trendy idea to let people know that one has wool in one's roof.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that formal?

—We will go into that over a cup of tea later. I am putting it to the Senate that these bureaucracies are not the appropriate bodies to be aggressively selling wool and that if they are going to stay in existence they certainly need to up their game. They are certainly not helping entrepreneurs in Western Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few remaining minutes that the Senate has left on this motion—we owe Senator Panizza a vote of thanks for bringing it forward—I rise not only to support Senator Panizza's motion but also to support the greatest rural industry in Australia, the wool industry, which is now down on its knees. This industry supplied $6 billion worth of export sales only a matter of a couple of years ago. It is in a desperate situation. I do not think I have ever seen a more desperate situation than in the western areas of Queensland, where there are dedicated woolgrowers, and the western area of northern New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: I want to approach this debate in a bipartisan way because this industry deserves the support of the total parliament. The Crean package was welcomed. It provided $15.6 million in drought relief for an industry on its knees. The rural adjustment scheme, worth $170 million, takes the figure up to about $200 million. That is a lot of money. I accept that and I acknowledge it. But I want to contrast that amount of money, a little over $200 million, with the amount that the Fraser-Anthony Government provided in drought relief in 1982—$400 million in 1982 dollar terms or $700 million if that figure is carried forward. So this Government has put $200 million into the wool industry, as against what the Fraser-Anthony Government put in for the 1982-83 drought. I want Senator Sherry to accept those figures as accurate because they show the total commitment that these two parties have to the wool industry of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are doing the same today.

—The flocks and the herd were saved, the people were saved. When it rained in 1983, Senator Sherry's Government got the benefit. It came in and got a free kick with an economy that was moving up on the sheep's back. I point that out because I do not believe the Labor Party is mean or penny-pinching; I just think it does not understand the gravity of the situation.

PARA.TAB: I saw Mr Crean on television going out to see Mrs Greer. In front of the television audience she prayed to Mr Crean to understand the situation. The $200 million given in the drought package, the RAS package, fades into insignificance when compared with what was given to Kodak, to BHP, to the steel industry and to the waterside workers. One has only to look at the new foreign affairs building on which $190 million is being spent. It has a gazebo and everything that goes into making it a pleasant place for Canberra people to work in.

The Frasers and Anthonys of this world were great men for rural Australia. I think Mr Fraser has been terribly maligned by a lot of people. He was one of rural Australia's greatest friends. I am prepared to stand up in the chamber and acknowledge Mr Fraser as a great friend of rural Australia. The achievements of Fraser and Anthony must be compared to the eight lines given to rural matters in the Governor-General's speech. Therefore, I repeat that I do not believe the Labor Party understands the gravity of the problem.

Forty per cent of the woolgrowers in the western division of New South Wales and 40 per cent of the woolgrowers in south-western Queensland are not eligible to receive assistance because they cannot prove they are viable. How can anyone be viable when the wool indicator is 389c per kilogram in the middle of a terrible drought?

The very wealthy woolgrowers who have inherited wealth and who have got a bit of money put away in the sock—and there are very few of those left—will be viable next year. The growers who are viable now will be marginally viable next year, and the borderline cases this year will be unviable next year and will be forced to get farm household support. Once a grower gets his feet on that sticky paper, it is only a short time before he is removed from his farm. Once he accepts that farm household support, which is equivalent to the amount of the dole, he must pay it back at commercial interest rates if he stays on the property for over nine months.

Farmers are fighting desperately not to accept the farm household support because they know that once they accept it they are on the ropes and will never escape. So they are working twice as hard. They are sending their wives out to work, sending their kids to school without adequate food and money for lunch. All these things are happening out there in the bush at the moment. Fifteen thousand growers are currently receiving interest rate subsidies; 6,000 to 7,000 of those growers will come off contracts at the end of this year. Some of the contracts will be renewed, but where do those 6,000 or 7,000 growers go? They go on to the RAS and they will end up exiting their farm.

Nothing will help woolgrowers in the long term unless the price of wool returns to a market price that will give some returns at sustainable levels. I know it is important to give the aid, and I know that RAS is accepted. Every dollar is accepted; every dollar is necessary out there. But unless we can find a solution to increase the price of wool, every bit of aid, the $200 million—I hope Senator Sherry is listening to this—will not go anywhere. We will have to think laterally to provide a way of increasing the floor price. I know that `floor price' have become dirty words, but we will have to think about it. I know that other people wish to speak and Senator Panizza is giving me the wind-up signal. I think the Senate should debate this issue at a later time in greater depth.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the wee small hours of the last occasion that we sat before Christmas, Mr Punch, the former Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, tabled the Midford Paramount report. We were unable to do that in this chamber on that occasion because we were engaged in long and lengthy debate; we rose at 6 o'clock in the morning. So, in effect, the report was presented to the Senate whilst we were not sitting. This is the first opportunity that I have had to address this very important report which is the result of two years' work.

PARA.TAB: The report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into Midford Paramount is the tale of the punishment of defendants who were not convicted of any crime. The inquiry arose out of a Senate estimates committee investigation into the Australian Customs Service and a reference to the Public Accounts Committee upon a resolution of the Senate. It was a reference that the Government opposed but, in the end, a bipartisan report was brought down unanimously by all members of that committee.

The matter revolved around the directors of Midford and its tariff adviser who were charged in June 1988 with $4.5 million of Customs fraud. A year later the committal was discontinued soon after the DPP withdrew the charges. In February 1989, costs of around $365,000 were awarded against the Commonwealth. Despite the withdrawal of charges and the award of costs by the magistrate, the committee noted that the defendants suffered enormous financial losses through unreimbursed legal fees and diminution of the value of their businesses. Others involved in the case also suffered.

After an exhaustive two-year investigation the committee generated a report and 134 recommendations concerning the Midford Paramount case—and we said it was indeed a paramount case of a failure of Customs. Many of the 134 recommendations are simply sensible statements, either of commonsense or of basic good management. It is a terrible indictment of the Australian Customs Service that such fundamental matters needed to be raised in the report. I will give an example of some of those recommendations. Recommendation 1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The defendants in the Midford case and others be compensated for their unrecovered material and legal costs.

The committee found that the Australian Customs Service was at best incompetent or at worst conspiratorial and deceitful. An excessive number of inconsistencies, inaccuracies and contradictions was found in evidence by key witnesses from government agencies.

PARA.TAB: Importantly, the committee concluded that the Comptroller-General cannot be held personally responsible for every action of individual subordinate officers, but he must accept responsibility for the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the performance of the Australian Customs Service, the prevailing culture in the service and the changes that must be made.

SPEECH.PARA: The report shows a constant refusal of the customs service and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce to accept the verdict of a court of law and demonstrates what some would call a vendetta against innocent parties. It was best summed up by the statement made to the committee by the Australian Customs Service's National Manager of Investigations, who said:
The Magistrate's summation has been studied carefully. It is his opinion. The Australian Customs Service does not share his view and in fact strongly disagrees with it.
One of the DITAC witnesses before the committee said:
Maybe the court got it wrong.
At every turn, there was no willingness to accept the rule of law. But the findings of the report are totally consistent with the findings of the magistrate, who said:

As was disclosed from Cabinet papers and other confidential papers, a cover-up permeated throughout the department (that is, DITAC). I find it totally unbelievable that (the DITAC witness) knew very little of the Cabinet paper disclosures. In my opinion, the two officers—
the one from DITAC and the one from the Australian Customs Service—

were totally discredited. These witnesses departed sufficiently under cross-examination from their sworn statements tendered to the committal proceedings. Their evidence was incorrect and insupportable.

The Public Accounts Committee hopes that the Australian Customs Service will view the recommendations in the report positively and improve its operations to regain the trust of those it is meant to protect. Challenging the committee's findings is not a good start.
The committee found it necessary to recommend:

that the powers of the Customs officers be limited; increased emphasis be placed on protecting the rights of individuals through improved mechanisms for investigating and resolving complaints against the customs service; the expertise, training, qualifications, supervision and management of the Australian Customs Service investigation officers be improved; investigations be conducted into apparently false representations made by ACS officers to Ministers; and allegations that an Australian Customs Service officer forged evidence during a recent Crimes Act prosecution.

Since the release of the report, to date bureaucratic wranglings have done little to progress the matter. It is understood that initially it was proposed that Customs and DITAC would determine what compensation should be paid. Naturally, the intended recipients rejected major involvement of ACS and DITAC in the process.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) recently agreed that an interdepartmental committee be formed which would have a DITAC and Australian Customs Service observer. However, it now appears that the observers chosen by those two agencies are at the deputy secretary level, far outranking all other members on the interdepartmental committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Justice cannot and will not be seen to be done under an arrangement where there is a potential for undue influence from the two offending agencies, especially given repeated demonstration of recalcitrant attitudes by those agencies. Further still, latest advice is that the IDC now proposes to re-examine the whole of the Midford affair rather than undertake the task intended of simply determining the quantum.

PARA.TAB: The court and the Public Accounts Committee have already conducted extensive examinations and found that the defendants have already been severely punished, even though not convicted of any crime. What the IDC proposes is a severe insult to the Public Accounts Committee and borders on a contempt of parliament, it being inappropriate for an IDC to retry this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —What evidence do you have that that's the case?

—I will show the Minister later. Throughout this inquiry witnesses from the Australian Customs Service have constantly maintained that Midford had not been cleared of the charges, that it was guilty of crimes and that the magistrate was wrong. Despite both the legal system and the parliamentary committee process laying the fault at the feet of the bureaucrats, the agencies involved are still defending their original positions and they are, in effect, maintaining that they are above the law and the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: On Tuesday the new Minister responsible for the Australian Customs Service, Senator Schacht, announced a review of the operations of the service. The Minister's press release stated that he will review and examine issues of responsibility and accountability, the relationship of the service to other agencies and the public overseas developments and Customs administration. This appears to be a bland statement. We do not know who will conduct the inquiry, we do not know the role of the Parliament, if any, and we do not know who will head it. But I do welcome the statement and I do welcome the fact that the Minister says that the Government is committed to ensuring that the shortcomings identified by the Midford report and other reports are corrected. I can assure the Minister that he will certainly have the utmost cooperation from me and, I am sure, from other members of the committee.

PARA.TAB: I would like to place on record our thanks to the staff and other members of the committee who put in long hours and carried out hard investigative work, where thousands upon thousands of pages of evidence were presented to us. I can only commend the staff for the work that they did. I say to the Minister that if we can achieve a change and achieve justice for the people who were wronged, that two years' work by a parliamentary committee will have been thoroughly worth while.
Debate interrupted.
