TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks about the report of the Public Accounts Committee into the Midford Paramount case and related matters, which was published at the end of last year. As Senator Bishop said, I am now the Minister responsible for the Australian Customs Service. I assure Senator Bishop that I have not treated the report of the Public Accounts Committee lightly. I spent 14 hours on Easter Friday reading the whole 600 pages of the report, noting and underlining the various comments made.

PARA.TAB: As the responsible Minister, I am not in a position to accept or reject a lot of the description in the various chapters. I have had detailed briefings and discussions with the officers of Customs. Overwhelmingly, the specific recommendations contained in this report have been accepted by Customs and will be forwarded to the Department of Finance, which has the responsibility of preparing the Government's response to be tabled in parliament to any report from the Public Accounts Committee.
Issues dealing with compensation are matters to be dealt with by the Department of Finance itself, a matter not in the hands of Customs.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are on the committee.
—I wish to correct one matter Senator Bishop raised. The Customs and DITARD officers are represented on the committee as observers.
—At deputy secretary level.

—Whether or not they are at deputy secretary level, it is overstating it somewhat to say that the Department of Finance, of all departments, would be railroaded by any other government department. Anyone who has any knowledge of the role of the finance department in Australian public administration would realise that it certainly is not a pussy cat as far as putting its view forward and administering these sorts of matters.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made it clear in letters to me and other Ministers that this IDC is dealing with the issue of compensation and is not revisiting all the evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner, I was speaking about the report by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into the Midford Paramount case and the Australian Customs Service. As the new Minister responsible for Customs, I explained that I had thoroughly read the report. Although I do not accept automatically all the criticisms contained in the report, I indicated that Customs had overwhelmingly accepted most of the 130-odd recommendations that related to it, excluding the issue of compensation; that is being dealt with by an interdepartmental committee chaired by the Department of Finance, which is in accordance with government administration.

PARA.TAB: Two days ago, I announced a major review of all the operations and aspects of Customs. I did so after consultation with the portfolio Minister, Mr Alan Griffiths. We believe that it is necessary not just because of the Midford report, which dealt with only one aspect of Customs operations, but also because of the very important nature of Customs itself. It collects over $13 billion in revenue for the Commonwealth government and employs nearly 5,000 people throughout Australia. It also delivers a number of bounty program payments to the Australian public. Of course, it is responsible for maintaining the integrity of Australia's international border controls. It has a particularly onerous and difficult task in fighting the illicit drug trade and smuggling. At times, that means it has to exercise powers that do not make it popular with some members of the public.

Overall, Customs, which is one of the oldest public service departments in the Commonwealth, has performed an outstanding role. But, like all departments that deal with a multitude of services, nothing is ever 100 per cent perfect; they occasionally lapse.

The Midford report dealt with some of those areas. Of course, the Government will bring down a response to the Public Accounts Committee report by the middle of the year. In the meantime, I thought it would be appropriate for the Government to conduct an independent review of all the services of Customs, particularly because there has been no overall review of it since 1985 when it became a statutory authority. There have been many individual inquiries. Many of them were at the parliamentary level and dealt with specific areas.

In the last three years, a major work has been done by the Australian Law Reform Commission into the Customs Act. The Customs Act is one of the oldest Acts of the Australian Parliament; it was established in 1903. I am informed that there has been no major review or rewriting of that Act since then. Of course, it has been substantially amended piecemeal over the decades. The Australian Law Reform Commission review recommended a major rewriting of the Act. While those recommendations are before us—I have certainly had discussions with Customs about a timetable for rewriting the Act and when it could be introduced into the Australian Parliament—it seemed to me to be opportune to combine the work of the Australian Law Reform Commission and the rewriting of the Act with a review into the administration of the customs service.

I have certainly encouraged Australian Customs Service officers to see the review in a positive and constructive light that puts forward the very good work that they have been doing and the good service that they have provided to Australia. The Australian Customs Service has a very good story to tell in many areas. It is at the cutting edge of any world customs service in the introduction of electronic procedures to make it easier for importers and exporters to deal with customs with the minimum of inconvenience. Other customs departments elsewhere in the world are looking at taking up a number of the new initiatives in this area that the Australian Customs Service has developed.

All in all, I believe that the Midford case should be put into perspective. It was a major review by the Public Accounts Committee of a particular case. But there are many other areas of Customs where the customs officers should be given congratulations for the energy and enthusiasm with which they have adopted many new reforms and procedures to help Australian business.

I believe that the review is timely. I look forward to having it completed by the end of this year. In the next few weeks, I will announce the full terms of reference for the review and who will conduct it. I can assure the Senate that it will be an independent review to which the public will be able to make submissions. As I said before, I encourage Customs to make its own submission about its activities. I am sure that it will. I also believe that the review is part of the public debate about public administration. No government department should escape the need to have an independent review of its activities from time to time, because that means that we will have better administration and better quality in the performance of government departments.

I realise that the Public Accounts Committee report has made a savage attack with scathing criticism on a particular area of customs activity. The Government will respond appropriately in the next few months to that report. In the meantime, the review will get under way. I believe that that is the best way to deal with ensuring that, as we move towards the 21st century, we have a customs service that is capable in every way of meeting the needs of the Australian community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a member of the community affairs committee that produced the report entitled Employment of people with disabilities. I have not yet had an opportunity to see the Government's response to this report. I know that the committee members had some very grave concerns about the way people with disabilities were actually being affected by the limited access to certain things they required for their disability. Recently, the committee has had further submissions relating to other disabilities. The committee's current reference relates to mental health.

PARA.TAB: The problem we discovered in this report was addressed in our minority report. The problem was that the Government was not looking at ways in which to improve the delivery of services to those with disabilities. I am particularly concerned, when referring to people in the electorate who have various disabilities, whether they be mental or physical disabilities, to find that the services being provided to them are inadequate.

It is for that reason that Senator Lees from the Australian Democrats has made a reference to the committee about the facilities for those affected in terms of mental health. As a parliament, we have to look at ways in which we can deliver these facilities far better. My colleague Senator Walters, who wishes to speak on this report, has also been a member of that committee. We need to be able to assess the facilities that are being provided. (Quorum formed)
Let me return to what I was saying earlier about the intellectual disability access program. One of the recommendations on that program was recommendation 17, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Commonwealth public sector be required to provide more employment places for people with disabilities, including people with severe disabilities. Strategy plans are to be developed by each department, authority, etc. to demonstrate how such employment policies will be implemented.

I think that is of particular concern to a number of people because in a hard and tough economic climate there is great difficulty in getting employment for people—full stop; period—let alone for those who have disabilities. The concern that was constantly raised with the committee was how people with disabilities would be able to compete with those who were ablebodied.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that the Government's response to the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Under Section 33 of the Public Service Act, entry to the Australian Public Service is to be based on merit and is to be without patronage. Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) in the APS has its basis in the merit principle which requires that people seeking appointment, promotion and transfer to jobs in the APS must be assessed in fair and open competition, taking into account abilities, skills and personal qualities and without discrimination, patronage or favouritism.

It is of great importance that we look at some of those areas, because we have been concerned for a number of years that this will discriminate against those who are able bodied yet not give an opportunity to those who have disabilities. The further requirement for the private sector to put on extra staff members to cater for those who have disabilities is also a barrier to employment, which we discovered in that committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are a little concerned that Senator Walters's amendment would not do exactly what she wants it to do. We can see that she does have a point, in that there are occasions on which estimates committee reports will come up with something quite extraordinary that ought to be debated in the chamber, but we are not sure that this particular motion would not leave the door open to enable a good deal of the estimates committee report to be debated.
—Could you point out where it leaves the door open?

SPEECH.PARA: a proposed motion to take note of a particular matter in an estimates committee report

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with debate on the estimates committee reports anyway?

—You could drive five London buses through clause 30.

—I am not sure about five London buses, as Senator Schacht interjects, but I am a bit worried that, because this has only just been drawn up, particularly devious people—I will not name any who I think are particularly devious, but I for one can be devious when I feel like it—could find ways to get around this.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that there are times when these sorts of things can be addressed. They can be addressed at Question Time; suspension of Standing Orders is always available, as are referrals to committees—the possible misuse of Department of Social Security printing facilities has been referred to a committee. We are concerned that this is not the best way to address that point, but because of our concern that Senator Walters does have a good point—and we have not yet given it enough thought—after we have finished with this motion we would like to refer to the Procedure Committee the concerns Senator Walters raised in her speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have circulated an amendment to order of the day No. 1, which relates to the Procedure Committee. I have not spoken in this debate, which is about the implementation of a reform which would have the effect of abolishing the Committee of the Whole debate on estimates within this chamber. It seems to me that before the Senate abandons any of the opportunities it has for ensuring proper financial accountability of the Government, it should ensure that it is at least putting in place an alternative mechanism that can reasonably achieve the same objective.

PARA.TAB: I understand that colleagues who have spoken before me have made the point that the loss of the opportunity to address questions to Ministers in the form of this traditional Committee of the Whole debate will be the loss of an important opportunity for the Senate to examine the Government on its expenditure in detail. Therefore, this is a decision that should not be taken hastily. There has been a debate, I concede, at the level of the Procedure Committee and there is no doubt that in here tonight the numbers—that is, the Australian Democrats and the Government—favour passage of this change that will abolish—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am finding it difficult to hear Senator Hill in view of the rather audible conversation going on to my right. There appears to be another meeting taking place. I hope you might ask those who are engaged in that rather audible conversation, which is limiting my ability to hear what Senator Hill is saying, to desist.

—Order! There has been quite audible conversation and movement in the chamber while Senator Hill has been attempting to put his case. Perhaps, if the negotiations are needed, those honourable senators might move to the back of the chamber.

—I was just saying that the Government and the Democrats between them have determined that this change should be passed tonight—and that is a change that will abolish an opportunity for the Senate to require financial accountability through the examination of Ministers. But, in acknowledging that that will occur, it is nevertheless important that we look in some detail at what the Procedure Committee puts before us and determine whether it adequately achieves the objective that the Procedure Committee is seeking.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the alternative that the Procedure Committee has put is that, instead of coming in here for a debate in the Committee of the Whole, matters such as unanswered questions by Ministers should be referred back to the estimates committee which should then hold a supplementary hearing to deal with those matters rather than honourable senators being given the opportunity to question Ministers directly in this chamber.

However, when I looked at the drafting of that proposal, it seemed to me that there was no obligation upon the Government to ensure that such supplementary hearing takes place before the Bill is returned to this place for what will simply be the third reading stage of the process. I have had drafted a very simple amendment which is designed to ensure that the estimates committee hearings do in fact take place and are completed, in accordance with the design that the Procedure Committee has put to us tonight, before the Government brings the Bills back in here for passage.

It might be said that the Government would not do this; it would not seek to curtail the procedure. But we have a certain responsibility to ensure that the procedures of this chamber will not be avoided by governments which no doubt will tell us at the end of each session that there is great urgency and that the supplementary procedure perhaps should be abandoned. Therefore, I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Before paragraph (1), insert the following paragraph:

"An appropriation bill authorising proposed expenditure referred to estimates committees shall not be proceeded with until estimates committees have completed their consideration of the proposed expenditure, including consideration in supplementary hearings, and presented their final reports on the proposed expenditure.".

I cannot imagine any argument that the Government, let alone the Australian Democrats, would put against the passing of an amendment in those terms—an amendment which, presumably, would simply ensure the implementation of the process in accordance with the spirit in which the Government has brought these procedural amendments to us tonight. I therefore commend this amendment to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Last night I spoke about what I considered to be the gross hypocrisy of the Opposition in trying to erode the powers of Parliamentary Secretaries that were established in this chamber during the last Parliament. I pointed out that the hypocrisy of this move by the Opposition is manifest and obvious when one considers the fact that, in the case of the Government, there is only one Parliamentary Secretary in this chamber, Senator Sherry. But, in the case of the Opposition, which wants to curtail the powers of Parliamentary Secretaries in this chamber, Dr Hewson, the temporary Leader of the Opposition, has seen fit to appoint five shadow Parliamentary Secretaries in the Senate out of nine shadow Parliamentary Secretaries overall.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the irrelevancy of this debate. The truth of the matter is that, notwithstanding their great ability, none of our secretaries will be appearing before estimates committees. This is a debate about the apprentices appearing before six estimates committees when the Government has 10 Ministers; it is not about the quality of our wonderful front bench.

—There are so many shadow Parliamentary Secretaries that they cannot all sit on the front bench. There are so many shadow Parliamentary Secretaries that half of them are halfway out the door. There are not enough seats in the chamber to accommodate the number of Parliamentary Secretaries that the Opposition has. So what gross hypocrisy it is.

PARA.TAB: What is being proposed in this motion is no different from the sessional order that was in place during the last Parliament. There is not a skerrick of difference. While this debate was ensuing yesterday, we heard so many eulogies and so much praise about how well Senator McMullan did his job as a Parliamentary Secretary. One would think the Opposition would have been convinced. Apparently, times have changed. It was good enough for the Opposition to support this arrangement then.

The Liberal and National parties have a very good and a very long record of supporting Parliamentary Secretaries. They are appointed under the Parliamentary Secretaries Act 1980—legislation that was introduced the last time the coalition was able to form a government in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am not sure which standing order this comes under, but there must be something that prohibits the Minister from continually shouting. Can you ask him to quieten down a little bit. The sound is amplified. We can hear him quite effectively.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—I could not have put it better myself, Senator Hill. We would all appreciate it, Minister, if you could do so or at least vary it a little.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth remembering that the Fraser Government enacted the Parliamentary Secretaries Act. It is under that Act that the Parliamentary Secretaries operate. Again, it seems to me nothing short of gross hypocrisy for the Opposition to oppose this sessional order. There is no reason for not following previous practices in this House and there is no reason, in relation to the Parliamentary Secretary issue in general, for not following previous practices in both Houses.

PARA.TAB: Let us be absolutely clear about this. Why is it not better for a Parliamentary Secretary, who has responsibility in a particular portfolio or ministerial area, to appear before an estimates committee as opposed to a Minister who represents a House of Representatives Minister in this chamber. I would suggest to those opposite that the Parliamentary Secretary may well have a more immediate and closer understanding of many of the issues that Opposition and Democrat senators would want to explore before the estimates committees.

There is absolutely no justification for the amendment that has been moved by Senator Calvert. On this occasion the Government is doing nothing more than putting forward a sessional order that worked well, effectively and in the best interests of the Senate during the last Parliament. I believe that any reasonable person would support the proposed sessional order in its entirety. I ask the Senate to reject the amendment, as moved by Senator Calvert, and to support the motion standing in my name.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to address Senator Calvert's amendment, which is a very sensible change to the Government's proposal. I take the opportunity to remind the Senate what this debate is all about. The Government now has 10 Ministers in this chamber, yet feels that 10 Ministers are unable to fulfil the normal duties and responsibilities of Ministers—so much so that it has to have an extra Parliamentary Secretary to whom it wants to give similar responsibilities and powers. No case has been made out at all by the Government as to why it is necessary for Senator Sherry to carry out these functions in this chamber when the Government already has 10 Ministers to do the job.
—They only had six last year.

—As my colleague said, the Government had only six Ministers last year. It has expanded the number to 10. There is no reason why it now needs an eleventh. Government members have not really even sought to make out a case. It is rather one of those examples which we experience so often in this place where the Government moves a motion and we are just told that we should basically support it.

PARA.TAB: What are the functions that Senator Sherry must carry out in this chamber that are so necessary and that cannot be performed by other Ministers? One of the functions, we are told, is that he is to take the place of a Minister before the estimates committee. There are only going to be six estimates committees. There are, as we have said, 10 Ministers but yet the Government still says that one of those Ministers should be avoiding the responsibility of appearing before, and taking the appropriations through, the relevant estimates committee.

In this instance it seems that it is being specifically provided for the benefit of Senator Cook, because Senator Cook has the representational functions in this chamber which cover exactly the same areas that the Government is giving as a responsibility to Senator Sherry. Why cannot Senator Cook carry out that function before the estimates committee? Has the Minister sought to explain to the chamber why Senator Cook cannot meet that responsibility? If he had sought to do that and convinced us of a sound reason for doing so, he would have made his case, but he has not put before this chamber one single reason why Senator Cook cannot do the job.

We might have our doubts about Senator Cook's capabilities, but I presume that we are not intended to interpret this as a vote of no-confidence on the other side of the chamber in relation to Senator Cook. Certainly we know that in relation to primary industry Senator Cook had all that experience in the last session with the AQIS debate—experience that he will not forget.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what he is running away from.

—Is that what it is all about? Was he found to be so inadequate in relation to that debate, so failed in his responsibility in relation to that debate, that the Government has decided that Senator Sherry, its newly appointed Parliamentary Secretary, should take over Senator Cook's responsibilities in relation to that estimates committee? Is that what it is all about? If that is what it is all about, the Minister who has the responsibility for managing government business certainly did not have the courage to put that argument before us tonight. He has put no argument in support of his case.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, there is no reason why the amendment put by my colleague Senator Calvert—that Parliamentary Secretaries should not have a responsibility in relation to the estimates committee, that Parliamentary Secretaries should not take the role of Ministers in relation to the estimates committee—should not be accepted by the chamber. I presume, because there has been no argument put by the Government, that the Australian Democrats will finally, on this occasion, support us in this amendment and that Senator Calvert's amendment will be successful. So I have pleasure in supporting this amendment and look forward to this vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard from the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, that this is overturning precedent.

—I take a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I believe that Senator Bourne would need to seek leave, as I have spoken in reply. I am happy to grant leave—I hope for a very short time—and then let us deal with the matter and divide.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.
—You can speak for as long as you like.

—I thank Senator Boswell, but, as the Senate knows, as long as I like is usually a fairly short time. The Manager of Government Business has told us today that we should not be doing this because we are overturning precedent. We are actually in the business of overturning precedent this evening, by the look of it. I tend to agree with what Senator Hill has said. We cannot see any problem with Ministers turning up to all the estimates committees. We cannot see any problem with Senator Cook turning up for the estimates committee. As Senator Hill said, I am sure that Senator Sherry is a very able and apt person to turn up in place of a Minister for estimates committees. But we do have 10 Ministers here, all of them very able, and we would really like them to turn up to estimates committees. We would like to be able to question them about their own responsibilities, in particular, and about the responsibilities of those people whom they represent each day here in Question Time. So we will be supporting Senator Calvert's amendment to the motion.

That the amendment (Senator Calvert's) be agreed to.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That, during question time:

TAB.TAB: (a)the asking of each question not exceed 1 minute and the answering of each question not exceed 4 minutes;
(b)the asking of each supplementary question not exceed 1 minute and the answering of each supplementary question not exceed 1 minute; and
(c)the time taken to make and determine points of order not be regarded as part of the time for questions and answers.

PARA.TAB: (2)That this order operate as a sessional order.

SPEECH.PARA: There is very little difference here between the position that has been enunciated by Senator Hill on behalf of the Opposition and the position of the Government relating to the time limit for an answer to a question in Question Time. The Government is proposing a time limit of four minutes for answers and the Opposition is proposing a time limit of three minutes. Both the Government and the Opposition are proposing a time limit of one minute for supplementary questions and a time limit of one minute for supplementary answers. As I understand it, that is the position that Senator Hill has adopted.

PARA.TAB: I have been invited by Senator Kemp to address the Senate at length on this matter, but I have decided to reject his kind offer. I think honourable senators are aware of the issues. Experience has shown that the time limits in Question Time have not altogether been a disaster for the way in which the Senate has worked. In fact, I think the time limits have probably provided a useful discipline at times. I find it a little hard to be terribly emotional about this issue, but I think the motion outlines a reasonable time limit and I would ask the Senate to support the motion as it stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever there were evidence of a need for a time limit on answers to questions without notice, it was the performance of Senator Collins yesterday and today. This is a very useful reform. It was a reform that the Government resisted with all the vigour it could muster during its last term. I must say that the sort of grudging acknowledgment by the Manager of Government Business (Senator Faulkner) that some form of discipline can be useful is overdue; nevertheless it is recognised and appreciated.

PARA.TAB: In the previous session of Parliament, Ministers demonstrated that they were unable to impose self-discipline and provide sensible answers that concentrated on answering the question. Instead, Ministers were making long statements that should have been made after Question Time in the form of ministerial statements. It was really an abuse of Question Time. Ministers, particularly Senator Collins and Senator Cook, were giving us answers that went for many, many minutes. As I said a moment ago, Ministers often failed to even answer the question during such extended periods.

It became apparent to those of us on this side of the chamber—and, I have to say, to the Australian Democrats—that it was necessary for the Senate to impose some discipline upon Ministers. You will remember, Madam Deputy President, that we carried out a number of experiments to determine the appropriate time for a Minister to adequately answer a question without encouraging that Minister to speak in excess of what was necessary. We had an experience with a four-minute time limit on answers, which is the time limit contained in Senator Faulkner's motion. We also tried three minutes and—Senator Kemp might remind me—I think we had a go at two minutes.

At the end of the last session, I thought the consensus was that about three minutes is the right length of time. It is an adequate amount of time for a Minister properly to answer a question without encouraging him or her to speak for an unnecessarily long time. It is therefore disappointing that the Government, being dissatisfied with that experiment that worked reasonably well—after we tried three separate periods of time—feels it has to come in here tonight and have another go at extending the period for answering questions to four minutes.

What we are really trying to do, apart from cutting out the unnecessary expressions of Ministers, is get more questions asked and answered during the time allowed for Question Time. Unfortunately, the record of this Government has been poor compared with that of previous governments. It has taken less questions and therefore answered less questions. The opportunity presented to this chamber to require accountability during Question Time—which some might say is the principal opportunity presented to an Opposition in the Parliament to require accountability—has been unduly limited.

In addition to the constraint on the time in which a Minister can answer a question, we suggest that a minimum number of questions should be asked and answered. So far, regrettably, that has been rejected not only by the Government—which is not surprising because it objects to answering any questions—but also, surprisingly, by the Australian Democrats. I say `surprisingly' because I cannot understand any argument by which the Australian Democrats would wish to limit their opportunity to ask a reasonable number of questions and to get answers. In fact, because of their very small numbers in this chamber, they have limited opportunity to do so in any event.

If the Government were required to answer a reasonable number of questions, the Australian Democrats would have the opportunity to ask more and, therefore, presumably, better fulfil their responsibility to the electors who put them here. For some reason that I do not understand, they have been unwilling to accept that very reasonable reform.

That is a debate for another day, but it brings me back to the principal issue we are debating here—that is, whether our approach, the three-minute option, the more successful of the options, should be re-endorsed tonight or whether the Government should be extended further liberty than that previous time constraint which seemed to operate quite well at the end of the last session.

I would hope that the Australian Democrats will realise not only that three minutes is an adequate time in which a Minister can answer a question, but also that by constraining Ministers to three minutes they hopefully will again have more opportunity to ask questions themselves. If we add the minutes allowed for asking questions to the four minutes that the Government proposes for answers, plus the two minutes for supplementary questions and answers, we are up to a maximum of seven minutes per question. In an hour—the Australian Democrats can work this out by simple arithmetic calculation—very few questions might be answered if the Ministers decide to take their full time. On the precedent of today, it looks as though these Ministers will take every second that they are allowed to answer questions. I ask Senator Kemp how many questions that would bring us down to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixteen.

—No more than 16 questions will be asked in Question Time, eight to the Opposition. The Democrats would be lucky to ask two questions in an hour and I presume that they would want better than that. I presume that the Democrats would prefer the option of three minutes to answer questions than four. Therefore, I move:

PARA.TAB: Substitute `three minutes' for the Government's stated period of `four minutes' in part 1(a) of the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I trust that the Democrats will support our amendment, and that the Senate will support the amended motion that will continue the useful reform of providing restraint upon Ministers, but for a more appropriate time than the Government is seeking to implement tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Hill. This is part of a package of reforms which the coalition has proposed to improve the procedures of this Parliament and to make sure that the Senate makes the Government more accountable for its actions. I, too, hope that the Democrats will join with us in supporting our motion. I believe that the motion before the chamber and the amendment to it do not go far enough. Senator Hill has shown an eminent sense of compromise and tried to reach a position which would meet the needs of the Democrats.

PARA.TAB: Some very interesting figures have been pulled out to see just what happened when we had one minute for a question and four minutes for the answer, followed by one minute for the supplementary question and one minute for the answer. Those figures showed that we might as well have no limits, because that arrangement brought us right back to the average experienced in this chamber when there were no limits on questions and no limits on answers. Over the period of the Hawke and Keating Governments, on average, there were 22 questions and answers each Question Time.

I asked the Clerk to provide me with some figures to show what happened previously when we had time limits, as is now proposed by the Government. Interestingly, the figures that the Clerk's office pulled out for the period from 6 October to 15 October—when we had one minute for the question and four minutes for the answer—show that there were 22 questions and answers a day, which is precisely the same situation, almost to the decimal point, that we had when we had no limits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! That's not correct.

—It is correct. That was our experience, and I will show Senator Bourne these figures as I am not making them up. If we go down a step and move to three minutes for answers, as is proposed in this motion, basically we will get an extra one or two questions in the hour. It is a very moderate proposal. We tested that from 3 November to 17 November.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Hill made a very effective point. I said that the best approach is to have a minimum number of questions to be answered. If the Government chooses to answer those questions in less than an hour, it is entitled to bring to an end Question Time; if it chooses to make long answers, it will have to go over the hour. The Australian Democrats have a problem with this and I will tell honourable senators what the problem is. If the Democrats had joined with us in proposing major reforms to Question Time, which would have enabled them to get an extra question—

TALK.START.PARA: —Like time limits? Time limits is a major reform.

—It is incomprehensible to me, it is incomprehensible to my colleagues and it is probably incomprehensible to the Democrats' supporters why the Democrats would not want an extra question in Question Time. They get two questions in Question Time. Why would they not want an extra question in Question Time? I do not know why and I hope Senator Bourne tells us when she stands up.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill has proposed four or five major proposals to processes by which this Senate operates which will make the Government more accountable. If the Democrats had any particular function, I would have thought that that was one function on which they would have joined with us. I think it is a great pity that we may not have been able to persuade Senator Bourne and her colleagues to join with us on this occasion.

This experiment has been going on for well over half a year. All the statistics are available from the Clerk's office. All Senator Bourne had to do—as I did—was go to the Clerk's office and say, `Could you please provide me with the tables you have done showing how the various time limits operate?'. I do not know how Senator Bourne's party operates but I would have thought that in relation to Question Time—

TALK.START.PARA: —More effectively than yours, obviously.

—There is no sign of any improvement in Senator Faulkner. Before the election I said to Mr Hand, `It's going to be quite good to get Kim Carr in this chamber because, basically, the Left are pretty hopeless in this chamber'. He said, `Why do you say that?'. I said, `Well, Mr Hand, you don't have to sit in this chamber and watch Senator Faulkner perform all the time. If you did, you would see the merit of what I say'.

PARA.TAB: I dare say that Senator Carr and I differ on just about every conceivable issue, but there is no doubt that the Left needed a bit of pecker in this chamber. I suspect that Senator Carr will be waiting for half a year until the Left moves on Senator Faulkner, unless his form improves. I did not think I would ever say this in the chamber, but we miss Senator McMullan as Manager of Government Business in the Senate. I say that sincerely, because we used to get through all these matters quite efficiently without all the sort of nonsense that is occurring at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Grimes was the best.
—Senator Grimes was better.
—He's welcome to the job. If he wants it, he can come down here and do it.

—I just hope that that comment is recorded in Hansard so that when the big challenge comes, Senator Carr will be able to quote Senator Faulkner's words back to him. I thank Senator Faulkner for that comment; it is much appreciated.

PARA.TAB: This is a very serious matter. How the Government conducts Question Time and the rules which govern Question Time are very serious matters. As I think everybody now concedes, there has been a serious slippage in behaviour and performance of the Government in Question Time. Therefore, it is appropriate that the Senate, where the Government does not have the majority, should start to take the lead and respond to the public wishes to try to improve the performance of Ministers at Question Time. This is indeed a very modest step in that direction.

I hope Senator Bourne will table in this Parliament the reasons why she and her party refuse—and Senator Bourne may be prepared to reconsider her position—to vote with the coalition in this matter. If Senator Bourne is not prepared to accept this proposal, I hope she will say why she is not prepared to accept it so that her reasons can be carefully analysed.

I thought there was a commitment by Senator Bourne and her colleagues to have a fresh look at how we could improve the operations of this chamber and the accountability and performance of the Government, as demanded by the public. Senator Bourne will be aware that last year a record number of Bills were passed—rammed through, in some cases—through this chamber last year.

The Australian Democrats and the coalition do not agree on too much, but at least we can agree that this Senate chamber should operate more efficiently and that the Government should be made more accountable. It is a serious matter to which I am committed. I had hoped Senator Bourne's party was also committed to that view.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—They are not committed to it.
—You are a sad case.

—Senator Bourne says that I am a sad case simply because I believe that the Government should be prepared to answer more questions in Question Time, that there is too little accountability by this chamber of the Government's performance, and that the Government needs to have more scrutiny. If the Democrats cannot join with us on many policy issues, I would have thought that at least they could join with us in trying to reform the procedures of this Parliament.

—The Australian Democrats have carried out an analysis of the questions asked in Question Time last session when the time limits applied—and I for one will be looking forward to those limits coming back on. According to our analysis, when the allowance was one minute for questions and two minutes for answers, on average we got through 31 questions per day.

PARA.TAB: When we had one minute for questions and three minutes for answers, we averaged 23 questions per day. When there was one minute for questions and four minutes for answers, the average number of questions per day was again 23. So there was the same average over a four-week period, irrespective of whether there was one minute for questions and three minutes for answers or one minute for questions and four minutes for answers. That tells me that the Ministers are keeping their answers to about just under three minutes. They only need that extra minute, on occasion, to answer a particularly complicated question.

Senator Kemp believes the best system would be to set a finite number of questions which we would have to reach irrespective of time considerations. I am afraid that would encourage points of order, because there would be no time limit on Question Time and we could go all afternoon. We will be voting for the procedure of one minute for questions and four minutes for answers because, from our experience of last session, it seems to be a reasonable time, and we are into being reasonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to speak for a few minutes on the matter at hand. You might remember that I moved the first notice of motion that led to the trials last year. I did it because I was sick and tired of sitting in here at Question Time waiting weeks on end to ask a question while Ministers abused the procedure. At that time I thought the biggest abusers were former Senator Button and Senator Collins.

PARA.TAB: Generally Senator Button, as then Leader of the Government in the Senate, was asked the first question. He would spend the first five minutes bucketing the questioner, the next five minutes bucketing the Opposition and probably another five minutes answering the question. Some 15 or 20 minutes were taken up before the answer to the first question was finished. We would then hopefully get a few shorter answers to other questions. But then as soon as Senator Collins was asked a question, time got away again.

Having had enough of this, I went around to the Clerk's office and got some advice on how to stop this abuse of Question Time. The first suggestion was to have one minute for the original question, two minutes for the answer, one minute for a supplementary question and one minute for the subsequent answer. We must remember that that proposal got off the ground with the help of the Democrats. They at least saw the need to give it a trial.

As Senator Bourne has just pointed out, we averaged 31 questions while that trial occurred. It was rather fast and furious, but I thought that questions were being answered to the best ability of the Government Ministers at the time without the usual bucketing of the questioner and the Opposition before the questions were answered. I thought it worked fairly well.

But then we tried having one minute for the original question, four minutes for the answer, one minute for the supplementary question and one minute for the supplementary answer. We also tried having one minute for the original question, three minutes for the answer, one minute for the supplementary question and one minute for the supplementary answer. I believe that most of those trials were fairly successful. As Senator Bourne has said, there was no difference in the number of questions asked as between a time limit of four minutes or a time limit of three minutes for answers. She reckoned the number was the same. I think she said 23 questions were asked within those time limits, if I am correct.

The reason for that result—there being no difference in the number of questions asked with a three-minute or four-minute answer limit—is that it stopped the Ministers abusing the available time. It stopped them using the first 20 minutes of Question Time to answer one question, so that both those trials virtually had the same effect.

I cannot understand the Democrats not supporting the three-minute answer limit, because it gives people a chance to ask a question. One minute for the original question, three minutes for the answer, one minute for a supplementary question and one minute for the answer adds up to six minutes. So our proposal should allow for at least 10 new questions an hour. Under this proposal, eight or nine questions per hour could be asked. Therefore, our proposal would mean a chance for senators to ask an extra question.

I know that Senator Kemp has already asked Senator Bourne why she cannot support that sort of situation. I believe that the Democrats have as much right as we have in this Senate to question the Government. I cannot really see why the Democrats would turn down the opportunity of being able to ask an extra question of the Government. As I said before, the Democrats helped us before. We would not have got the proposal up without their help. I forget who I dealt with at the time; it was probably Senator Coulter, the defrocked leader of the Democrats. Certainly the Democrats helped us with the experiment. It worked in stopping the abuse of Question Time. I cannot see why they would want to give up the chance of asking an extra question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Hill. In the 12 months that I have been in this chamber I have seen a variety of timings for Question Time. When I first came into the Senate, there was unlimited Question Time. We then went to having one-minute questions and two-minute answers that Senator Panizza talked about. I could see that some Ministers were struggling under that time constraint, because it was quite obvious that their staff were well used to preparing five- and six-minute answers and that Ministers were trying to get them through in two or three. We could see the difficulty that that was presenting to some Ministers.

PARA.TAB: We then came to a reasonable conclusion of three minutes and one minute. I fail to see Senator Bourne's logic when she says we have the same number of questions whether it is a three minute limit or a four minute limit; therefore, we should go for the four-minute limit. Surely if three minutes is the average, the most sensible thing to do would be to have three minute answers to questions. This would mean that Ministers would then be confined to answering questions in three minutes instead of spending four minutes plus one minute to answer supplementary questions which are sometimes dorothy dixers from their own back bench. This sometimes limits the answers the Ministers give to Opposition backbenchers or shadow Ministers.

I was told when I entered the Senate that the opportunity for asking questions, particularly from the back bench, was somewhat limited. I came in at a time when lengthy answers were being given by Ministers in response to questions. I think that because of the workings of the Senate up until Christmas time last year there was scarcely a senator on the Opposition side who complained about the number of questions that they had the opportunity of asking. This was because of the time constraints that were placed on Ministers answering questions.

I fail to see why the Democrats would want to do anything else but get the opportunity to ask more questions than they would have had the opportunity to ask when there were no time constraints or even when there were four-minute time constraints. This also applies to Independent senators.

The more chances we get to ask questions the more opportunities there are for senators on this side of the chamber, as well as government backbenchers, to ask questions of interest. I think if senators get the opportunity to ask more questions then they are able to raise many issues which are brought to them by their constituents and which they wish to raise in order to get direct answers.

I believe Senator Hill's amendment is a very reasonable one. Of all the proposals we tried last year—we tried the whole gamut of no time limits and two, three and four-minute answers to questions—it seems that the three minute time limit was the most satisfactory both for Ministers to answer questions and also for Opposition, Democrat and Independent senators to ask a greater number of questions.

I cannot for the life of me see the logic in Senator Bourne's argument that because there was no difference in the number of questions asked, whether the time limit was three or four minutes, she would go for the higher time limit. This means that there is then the possibility that fewer questions would be asked than there would be if a three-minute time limit were applied to the answers of Ministers. I hope the Democrats will see their way clear to support this amendment so that all senators may be able to meet their obligations in the Senate and have far more opportunities to ask questions on matters they feel are important.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That a Senator shall not speak for more than 20 minutes in a debate on a motion for the second reading of a bill considered during the remainder of the 1993 sittings.
(2)That this order operate as a sessional order.

This reform seeks to ensure that the sessional order that was in place at the end of the last Parliament remains in place for calendar year 1993. I really believe that most honourable senators would agree that this limit on speeches at the second reading stage worked to the benefit of all honourable senators and the chamber as a whole. I believe that anyone who cannot deliver a speech on the second reading in 20 minutes should not be a member of parliament. Most of the effective speeches that I have heard in this chamber—and none of them have come from the Opposition side—have been a great deal more limited than 20 minutes in duration.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are one of the great orators!

—Senator O'Chee, of course, is the most longwinded person in the chamber. In his entire life as a senator he has never laid a glove on the Government. In his case it would not make any difference whether he made a speech on the second reading—or any other speech—for 20 minutes, 30 minutes, 40 minutes or 40 hours. Even though he may have been fourth-placegetter in the world schoolboy debating championships, he is no good in here—and all his colleagues know it.

PARA.TAB: This sessional order took effect on 25 November last year and I do not think there was one complaint from the Opposition after it came into being. I stress with this motion—as I have done with a range of other motions that we have been debating—that, with the exception of one or two or perhaps three honourable senators on the other side of the chamber, everyone in the chamber agrees that this motion is a necessary reform. Although a whole range of honourable senators on the other side of the chamber will be dragging their feet to vote against this motion, they will all hope like hell that it gets up, because there are one or two or three of their colleagues whose contributions they want to have constrained by a sessional order limiting speeches on the second reading to 20 minutes.

This time limit worked well at the end of the last Parliament, and every honourable senator knows that it worked well. It worked in the best interests of honourable senators themselves and the whole chamber. Let us be clear: it saved absolutely oodles of time in the Government's legislative program. The situation is that interminable, boring, convoluted, irrelevant speeches on the second reading came ad nauseam from the other side of the chamber about every possible red herring and bearing very little relevance to a matter before the chamber and they were used as a filibuster in a deliberate ploy by Opposition senators to ensure that the processes of this chamber bogged down. We all know it. Those opposite all know it. Most of them want this to get up. Look at the smile on Senator Calvert's face. He just hopes like hell that this gets up because he no more wants to listen to Senator Bishop or Senator O'Chee for 30 minutes on a speech on the second reading than I do or Senator Loosley does. None of us does.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Faulkner knows quite well that the reason why Senator Calvert was smiling was that he was laughing at Senator Faulkner's stupidity, not agreeing with the arrant nonsense he was saying. It is highly out of order for a senator to ascribe improper motives to the conduct of another senator in this chamber. Senator Faulkner should be asked to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—There is no point of order. I ask honourable senators not to provoke responses from across the chamber and to address their remarks through the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I appreciate your calling errant senators to order. I asked the Clerks to take out some figures on the length of speeches on the second reading. Everyone else seems to do this. Senator Kemp seems to have any number of documents about the length of Question Times, the number of questions that are asked and how things went in the period of the Fraser Government, but I looked at some recent history in relation to second reading speeches.

PARA.TAB: In a sampling done by the Clerks of the Senate for the autumn session 1990, in the fortnight from 8 to 17 May, 68 per cent of speeches on second reading debates were 20 minutes or less in length. In the fortnight from 21 May to 1 June 1990, 62 per cent of such speeches were 20 minutes or less in length. In the Budget session of 1990, in the fortnight starting 11 September, 71 per cent of speeches were 20 minutes or less. In the fortnight starting 10 December, 89 per cent of speeches were 20 minutes or less. For the total of the Budget sittings in 1990, 76 per cent of speeches during second reading debates lasted 20 minutes or less.

TALK.START.PARA: —So why change it?

—It just goes to show how many people can make their point within an appropriate time limit. There are just a couple of windbags on Senator Patterson's side of the chamber who cannot. In the fortnight starting 12 February in the autumn session 1991, 64 per cent lasted 20 minutes or less. For the whole of the autumn session 1991, 68 per cent took 20 minutes or less. Budget session 1991, 78 per cent, 20 minutes or less. Autumn session 1992, 76 per cent. Budget session 1992, about 60 per cent. It is very clear that the vast majority of speeches during second reading debates in this chamber take 20 minutes or less. Senator Patterson is an obvious exception, but most people have the intellectual capacity to make their point in 20 minutes. If you cannot make your point in a second reading speech in 20 minutes then you do not have a point worth making.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I put it to you that to attack Senator Patterson's intellectual capacity is quite offensive to her. She is one of the most highly qualified senators in this place and I could spend some time talking about her fine academic record and her contribution as a tertiary teacher. I suggest there is a lot that she could teach Senator Faulkner. She could start with Debating 1 because he is making an awful mess of this.
—What is your point of order, Senator Hill?
—That Senator Faulkner's statement was offensive to Senator Patterson and should be withdrawn.
—Senator Faulkner, in so far as you did make any offensive remark about Senator Patterson, I ask you to withdraw.

—In so far as I did make any offensive remark about Senator Patterson, I withdraw. I do believe that the arguments for time limits are strong. They worked well as a sessional order at the end of the last Parliament. It constrained the few senators in this chamber who, unfortunately, have a record of always abusing their right to make a speech during a second reading debate and waste everyone's time. This is a reform that worked. It is a reform that most Opposition senators support. It is a reform that they all want to see a majority of senators vote for and I believe that, because of its merits, it is a reform that will be adopted by this Senate as it deserves to be.

—I have never heard anybody debate an issue in a way that actually supports the Opposition's case as Senator Faulkner has in telling us how many people actually speak for less than 20 minutes. It indicates that we do not need this rule. This proposition is typical of this Government in that it interferes with those concerned and tells them how to run their lives when, in fact, they can run their lives quite well. We can run this chamber quite well with people speaking for about 20 minutes or less.

PARA.TAB: I want to put to the Senate today that many people, as Senator Faulkner has demonstrated with the figures that have been produced for him, speak for 20 minutes or less, but there are occasions on which people need to speak for up to 30 minutes. That would be when the Government jams legislation through this chamber or, for its own purposes, debates Bills cognately, when shadow Ministers or backbenchers find themselves trying to discuss three or four Bills in half an hour—what the Government now wants to make 20 minutes.

I would like to see us at least consider the possibility that when two or more Bills are being debated cognately we have a 30-minute time limit rather than the 20-minute time limit. I would ask the Democrats to consider that as a possibility—as a compromise for what I think is a stupid decision to have the time limit reduced to 20 minutes. If we were to do that, at least issues could be debated properly here.

I find it somewhat offensive that Senator Faulkner would stand up here and say that debating issues in this chamber is a waste of time. He may think it is a waste of time and it shows his attitude towards the role of parliament and the opportunity for representatives of the people to debate Bills and debate issues. We do not think it is a waste of time, but I do believe it is important that we have time to debate Bills in a very full way, especially when we have two or more being debated together. I move:
That after paragraph (1), insert:
"(1A)Paragraph (1) shall not apply where 2 or more bills are taken together or debated together.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Patterson's amendment because it is a fall-back position. I am certainly opposed to reducing time limits for speeches in second reading debates from 30 minutes. Only a short time ago the time limit was an hour, and I go along with that being a bit over the top. Senator Faulkner spent 15 minutes illustrating why we should speak for 20 minutes. In his own words, he should have been able to do that in three or four minutes but he had to extend it to 15 minutes to point out to the chamber why we should speak for 20 minutes. If that is an indication of why we should have 30-minute speeches—to accommodate people such as Senator Faulkner who cannot get their point across—then I think we ought to take that into consideration.

PARA.TAB: This particular chamber should have time to examine very thoroughly and make our point on legislation that needs review. To reduce our time from 30 minutes to 20 minutes would be to erode this chamber's necessary rights. I was going to make the point that Senator Patterson did, that an average of 76 per cent of speakers could make their point in 20 minutes. If 76 per cent require only 20 minutes, then the majority is speaking in 20 minutes or less. I think Senator Faulkner would agree that I am not someone who gets up here and speaks on every Bill on every occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't speak on every Bill on every occasion.

—I said Senator Faulkner would agree. When I do want to speak and make a contribution in this chamber I want sufficient time to be able to put down a case in a manner that people can understand. Last time I spoke during a second reading debate I had to seek leave to go three or four minutes over my 20-minute time limit. That speech was prepared, it was culled, reculled and culled again to get a 30-minute speech down to a 20-minute speech. Even then, I had to ask Senator McMullan to extend me the courtesy of another three or four minutes, which he did.

PARA.TAB: I am totally opposed to this reduction because it is an evasion of our rights, a cutting down of what is meaningful in this Senate, and that is, being able to get up and debate a case thoroughly. I know that when we get into cognate debates towards the end of the session, we jam up to eight or nine Bills together, but surely to goodness we can appeal to the Democrats for a bit of commonsense on this. They did display some commonsense on an amendment about four or five minutes ago. I do not know what the Democrats are up to. This certainly would not have happened in Senator Chipp's time or Senator Haines's time, and I am not sure that the previous leader of the Democrats, Senator Coulter, would have let it happen.

I can go along with this as a sessional order when the Bills are jamming up towards the end of the session, but why do we have it at the beginning of a session when we have a whole three years to go? I am totally opposed to the reduction of time to 20 minutes and I am opposed to Senator Patterson's amendment, although I will vote for it because it is a fall-back position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am also opposed to the proposal that reduces the speaking time for speeches during second reading debates from 30 minutes to 20 minutes. I implore the Democrats to think very seriously about it. I suggest this particularly to Senator Bourne, who gave us an argument a short time ago in relation to the reduction from four minutes to three minutes for the answering of questions during Question Time. She said that we really end up with the same number of questions being answered even if we reduce the time from four minutes to three minutes. The argument she used—and clearly the Senate agreed with her—was that most of the Ministers would answer in three minutes anyway.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Faulkner has quite sensibly and adequately outlined to the Senate that on a clear majority of times, senators' contributions are indeed 20 minutes or less. There are very few occasions—and he has, with his statistics, shown us that it is roughly 24 per cent over a couple of years—where speeches have exceeded 20 minutes.

I know personally—I have only been here for coming up to three years now—that on only three occasions in my memory did I speak for 30 minutes. The first one was my first speech—and I did not enjoy that 30 minutes one bit. I see Senator Sherry, who is wearing his liquor and allied trades outfit, nodding in agreement. I think Senator Sherry has been down at the Hyatt moonlighting as a butler to make up for the lack of pay of Parliamentary Secretaries; Parliamentary Secretaries do not get paid—I had to slip that in.

Senator Faulkner in his argument has put before us—and clearly gets some agreement from senators who do not like to sit here listening to so-called windbags—that this is really to constrain windbags. He has agreed during his contribution tonight that this proposal does constrain people. But I put it to the Senate that it does not just constrain windbags; it constrains everybody. This is why I am opposed to it and why I think the Democrats should be opposed to it—because it imposes a constraint that is not necessary.

We have already all agreed that most speeches during second reading debates are made in less than 20 minutes, but there are other occasions. I just mentioned my first speech; we heard a contribution from Senator Carr yesterday, and I do not think he would have wanted to reduce his contribution to less than 30 minutes. Another good example of a long speech in this chamber this week was of course the Governor-General's speech, and I think many of us would have liked to have constrained that to 30 minutes. But, again, it is a good example of a speech where there is detailed policy and arguments to be conveyed.

The second example I remember when I spoke at great length was my speech on the so-called political ad bans package of legislation on which many speakers spoke for a long time. I am sure that members of the Government would have called that a filibuster, most unkindly. That is a good example of a package of Bills which contained many philosophical, intellectual and policy arguments which required very earnest reflection and some consideration and development of arguments. Indeed, the High Court of Australia, if one reads its judgments in relation to the constitutionality of those laws, would spend a lot longer than 30 minutes developing its arguments.
The third occasion on which I gave a speech longer than 30 minutes—if I remember correctly, on that occasion I actually success

SPEECH.PARA: fully sought an extension of time—was in relation to a package of corporations laws amendments which were extremely detailed. It was just simply impossible to cover all the points that the Opposition needed to make in a contribution of 20 minutes or less.

PARA.TAB: So I plead with the Democrats to allow the flexibility for senators to use 30 minutes on the occasions they do; to, of course, exert natural pressure on our colleagues to make concise contributions; but to recognise that there are many occasions when senators do need that full 30 minutes. None of us like getting up here and wind-bagging for 30 minutes, except for a few notable exceptions, but they are the exceptions. I implore the Democrats to apply the same logic to this debate—that by limiting contributions from 30 minutes down to 20 minutes we will not actually shorten the time the Senate devotes to second reading stages of Bills. Therefore, by keeping it at 30 minutes we are not constraining senators.

We should not be constrained. We are very much the only legislative chamber in this Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. The other place, of course, is not a legislative chamber; it is merely a rubber stamp for the Executive. This is the only chamber where one can properly deliberate upon legislation. For the Democrats to agree with the Government to restrict our time for speaking on second readings is, of course, in contravention of the fundamental reason for this chamber and for us being here. It is, therefore, against the very principles of democracy for which we should stand. I urge the Democrats—indeed, I urge all senators—to oppose this restriction, restraint and constraint upon senators' contributions to second reading debates.
Debate (on motion by Senator Hill) adjourned.
