PARA.TAB: That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to exclude certain shares and securities from consideration in determining pensions and benefits.
Motion (by Senator Faulkner) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to raise two matters of particular importance.
—Keep it brief.

—Without interruption from Senator Boswell, it will take much less time. The first matter I wish to raise concerns the attack on certain small business enterprises by the Labor Party through the Federal Airports Corporation.

PARA.TAB: In August last year the assistance of my office was sought by Tasmanian car rental companies to oppose a proposal by the Federal Airports Corporation to impose on them a particularly severe contract and set of charges. The contract was and is designed to get money out of hire car operators who meet customers at airports after having arranged a contract with them either through a travel agent, by mail or over the telephone. It is not business which is in any way won or touted at the airport.

Of course, having become a public corporation and being directed by the Labor Party that it should raise its own revenue, the FAC is understandably on the lookout for every little device that it can dream up to make a dollar. I suppose it should not be criticised for that. We should be, and we are, critical of the Labor Party—each and every Labor senator and member of the House of Representatives.

To meet this corporatisation philosophy and profit seeking goals, the FAC proposal was to impose a three tier structure of charges, with tier one being a staffed desk, tier two an identifying sign and car space and tier three the right to meet customers outside the terminal and no designated car space. For this privilege the operators would have to pay $6,000. That was the first proposal the FAC came up with. Understandably, the car rental operators rejected that proposal outright; understandably, they felt that they were seen as a threat by the major car rental companies which were wanting protection.

In October a new four tier proposal was put up and that was no better. It still attempted to impose a massive fee increase on small car operators. I said at the time, `It particularly penalises the small businesses who meet only their pre-booked customers at the terminal'. It certainly did. The proposed 11 per cent turnover fee was outrageous compared with the five per cent to be imposed on larger operators. This was at a time when we were still talking about level playing fields. That particular concoction would also mean for the smaller operators a considerable increase in record keeping, audit fees and accountant fees. It was a proposal that the operators were never going to be able to afford.

At that time I called on my Tasmanian colleagues to stand up for small business and for operators to continue to resist the proposals. The operators have held the line. Most Tasmanian politicians—I say with deference to Senator Calvert who is intently listening to this—have been conspicuously silent. It can only be because they agree with taxing small Tasmanian businesses out of existence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have approached the Minister.
—I acknowledge that approaches have been made by him to the responsible Minister.
—Senator Sherry has too.

—I have seen correspondence that Senator Sherry has also addressed to the Minister. What I would like to see as a result of my raising the matter here tonight is a little more backbone in our combined approach to the Minister on this matter. At that time, when I was asking for support, a subsequent motion in the Senate by myself on that subject got nowhere. It is all very well to sing and dance and wave arms around but when the opportunity presented itself by a motion in the Senate, begging for support, it was met with silence. That demonstrates what action and what real support was given.

PARA.TAB: In November I wrote to the Tasmanian Minister for Tourism thinking that he would be interested in supporting Tasmanian small business, particularly because it was providing a service to tourists. I suggested to him that the Tasmanian Government might consider establishing Tasmanian welcome centres at the airports. He did not think the idea was very practical. Since then, despite requests from operators, he has shown no interest whatsoever.

In February this year the operators received a new set of contract proposals involving an access fee, a designated meeting place fee, a car parking fee and a booking fee. For the operators this all added up to an increase in costs of over 100 per cent. The proposal succeeded in creating a new national grouping to oppose the FAC. That group has become known as the Licensed Off Airport Car Rental Operators.

In February this grouping met with the FAC. At that meeting the FAC led the operators to believe that the proposal would be reconsidered. It was, but the FAC did not change anything. Operators are not to be permitted inside terminal buildings unless they agree to pay 11 per cent of their turnover derived from customers who use FAC terminals.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are making only a seven per cent profit.

—That 11 per cent is in excess of the rate of profit that they make. The operators wrote to the FAC to express their opinion on this particular offer. I quote from a letter written by Mr Theo Coppens, spokesperson for the Licensed Off Airport Car Rental Operators, and addressed to Mr Brian Maxwell, the Manager, New Business, at the FAC head office. In part the letter reads:

PARA.TAB: Without exception all operators reject the proposal in its entirety.
What you are proposing is almost with total disregard of the points raised at our meeting in Sydney on the 24th February.
Not one Off-Airport Car Rental Operator will subscribe to this proposal.

You have totally alienated this sector of the industry and we will now seek every assistance from all avenues to get the necessary support to have this totally unfair and financially crippling proposal abolished.
You will so severely effect the livelihood of so many people that all affected will take drastic action in this matter and are totally unified for the first time in the industry's history.

SPEECH.PARA: I cease quoting from the letter to point out that we are talking about a group of people who are quite notorious for the intensity of the competition that they engage in with each other.

PARA.TAB: These are people who are engaged in private business. They are seldom able to come together on any issue, because if they are not in competition with each other, they are seeking different markets and have little in common in terms of a professional association. But the FAC succeeded in uniting them. To that extent, forceful and sincere language was used in that letter. The upshot is that the letter does not seem to have evoked any meaningful response from the FAC, despite it being fairly clear that the negotiations had reached a stage of mutual stand-offishness—I can only call it that.

However, the FAC decided that the new contracts, signed or not, were to operate from 1 April. I just wonder what sort of authority the FAC thinks it has to do that. Magnanimously, the operators were given 45 days by the FAC to agree to the proposal. It seems to me that the options these particular people had were a bit like being asked, `Do you want to be throttled, strangled or hung?'. None of the options presented to them were able to be accepted by the operators if they wanted to remain in business.

At the end of April I received yet another plea for assistance from a beleaguered operator. This letter sums up the frustration and belated hope for a fair deal. I might add that we do not agree with the operators. We do not think that they should have to pay anything. We do not believe that the FAC should be corporatised and that we should be trying to extract a dollar out of every government activity. We thought that was also the Labor Party position, but it seems as if that has been lost in the mists of time. It is no different from the present conservative position. The letter that I was talking about reads as follows:
After months of negotiations with F.A.C. the new contracts are about to be signed by car rental operators. The conditions have been in force since 1st. April.

As a Tasmanian independent operator who is seeking to continue meeting pre-booked clients at the Hobart and Launceston Airports in the same friendly way we have been doing for 10 years, we are appalled at the petty barriers being enforced by F.A.C. since 1st. April. Because we consider our business falls below the 2% of total turnover generated from the airport, we have been prepared to sign the Alternative A contract which demands an airport access fee and $5.00 per booking. But, we cannot accept that our staff can be excluded from entering the air-conditioned/heated terminals to personally greet our pre booked clients. With the Tasmanian winter fast approaching, our staff are being forced to stand outside exposed to the elements to meet our tourists.

Our alternative, if we wish to enter the building, is to sign the contract Option 3 which according to F.A.C., is designed for operators whose business exceeds 2% of airport turnover. By going with option 3, we could meet our clients inside the terminal but instead of $5.00 per booking our charges would be 9% of our airport turnover. This would be financial suicide.

As the member of LOARCO (Licensed Off Airport Car Rental Operators) we would welcome a revision of the Alternative A contract that would allow us to meet our pre-booked clients inside the terminals. This would allow us to be supporting and promoting Australian tourism in a manner conducive to the hospitality industry, thus saving our clients from any stress and embarrassment at the commencement of their Tasmanian holiday.

SPEECH.PARA: That letter speaks very well for itself. It does not need any glorification from me to prove its point. Since the beginning of April, the Federal Airports Corporation at both Launceston and Hobart airports have been acting as if the contracts are in place. Security personnel have been physically preventing representatives of the car rental companies from entering the terminal buildings.

PARA.TAB: I have issued a press release calling for these hired thugs of the FAC to be called off. The only response was from the General Manager of the Federal Airports Corporation in Tasmania, Mr Bernard Lynch. He said on radio, and he is reported in the Launceston Examiner, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The companies inside the terminal—
and that refers to Avis, Thrifty, Budget and Hertz—none of which are Tasmanian companies—
are paying handsomely and need to have their business protected.

There we have it. That is exactly what the FAC is really about—creating a limited and cosy market for its big business clients. It seems that that is also what the Labor Party is about. I have not had any recognition from the Minister or any other spokesperson on behalf of the party that it is unacceptable for the FAC's General Manager in Tasmania to be considering that that is his proper role and duty.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps he is being led to think that. I read with interest the latest newspaper of the Federal Airports Corporation. On the front page of volume 1, No.1, of April 1993, we are told `A Big Mac and corporate culture'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: McDonald's was used as an example of a corporate culture the FAC might emulate at a conference of the corporation's senior management in Brisbane.

If that is the sort of game we are in, no wonder we cannot serve our clients; no wonder we cannot provide airport access to people. They are in there for the buck. That is what is what it is all about. To charge people for the simple exercise of meeting customers as they get off the aeroplane is one thing, but to justify that exercise as providing protection to businesses is well and truly beyond what I would expect of the Labor Party, and it is certainly does not seem to describe properly the role of the Federal Airports Corporation.

PARA.TAB: To make it worse, the restrictions that we have seen so far have only really been applied to the Tasmanian car rental operators. Why is it that Tasmania is being singled out? Senator Sherry would know. It is because Tasmania is an easy target. It is because it is only Tasmania where these smaller operators have a significant percentage of customers who they meet at airline terminals. Why? People who travel to Tasmania have to cross the water. A lot of them do not bring their cars with them on the aeroplane. They like to hire cars. So they are sitting ducks for this manipulation, this bullying tactic, by the FAC.

If that is not the case, I wonder whether any instructions have been issued to security personnel at any other airport. That is a question I have addressed to the Minister. I have addressed a couple of questions to the Minister. I have received no answers yet. I just wonder whether he really knows what is going on here. If he does and endorses it, I am disgusted.

If it is only Tasmania, the practice will have a severe effect on Tasmania's image as a tourist State. The companies do expect to lose business if they cannot meet their customers in a civilised manner and they cannot afford the rates being demanded by FAC. They cannot afford to pay that sort of money just to meet somebody—just to stand on the carpet for five minutes—with whom they have already done business, with whom they have already made an arrangement and with whom they have a contract which they wish to fulfil by showing the person where the car is. The whole episode is a sad, sorry and unAustralian saga that must be brought urgently to a sensible and amicable conclusion. I seek a conclusion which is much less greedy and much less heavy-handed.

I apologise for monopolising the time, but it is important that I raise tonight another matter that is also Tasmanian-oriented. As senators, we are here to represent concerns in our own States. I draw the attention of the Senate to recent activities of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission. Constituents of mine living and farming organically around the Lorinna water catchment were horrified to learn that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission had gone ahead and sprayed the herbicide Atrazine in the Lorinna area, after much pleading and after the residents had pointed out how residual Atrazine is.

As of today four residents of this sparsely populated area have been arrested so far, fighting to protect their right to uncontaminated water. For five years, the residents have been fighting to protect their water catchment—firstly from logging, which resulted in significant siltation of the water supply, and now from being sprayed with a very persistent herbicide. This herbicide, Atrazine, in its various forms is recommended by some manufacturers to be applied at the suggested minimum rate of 55 litres per hectare and up to 110 litres per hectare.

General instructions on the label of one brand of Atrazine warned that rain immediately following an application can concentrate the chemical in soil depressions at rates of more than 3.6 litres a hectare. As Senator Sherry would know, Lorinna receives over 1,000 millimetres of rain per year. It rains frequently. If Atrazine is applied at a rate of 6.5 litres per hectare, it will persist in the soil for 18 months. Higher rates of application will persist a great deal longer, perhaps several years.

The people of Lorinna have until now enjoyed what should be the right of every human being—the right to uncontaminated water, food and air. In that particularly peaceful setting of Tasmania, this is something which has until now been readily available. I call on the Tasmanian health authorities to provide a written guarantee to these people that the chemical will not turn up in the local water supply. Further, I call on them to provide a guarantee that the State Government will compensate these people if they are denied `Level A' organic producer accreditation from the National Association for Sustainable Agriculture Australia. If that certification is not available due to the actions of the forestry commission, I believe that the State Government of Tasmania is liable for having caused that certification to be unavailable to those people. Until now, they have certainly been able to attain that accreditation.

In this area, unemployment is up in the order of 90 per cent. The local Commonwealth Employment Service should seriously consider starting up an employment scheme which offers the opportunity to remove manually the weeds which are the subject of this application of Atrazine. If that could be done, in conjunction with the forestry commission, we might be seeing an alternative which would be very useful.

In this area, five families have been planning and working for three years to convert their productive areas by using organic farming principles. They are doing so for some very good and commonsense reasons. Australia is following the movement towards chemical-free foods, in line with the trends that are well documented overseas. For example, in the United Kingdom and in Europe in general, demand for organic produce has grown considerably.

The Forestry Commission of Tasmania, by wilfully causing a residual herbicide to be sprayed in the catchment area that organic farmers use as a water supply, has behaved in what could only be described as a disgraceful way. Section 17(1)d of the Tasmanian Environment Protection Act 1973 states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not cause or knowingly permit to flow, put, or knowingly permit to be put, any pollutant into any river, stream, watercourse, lake, pond, or marsh.

The Tasmanian Forestry Commission—or indeed any person the Minister looks favourably upon—can be exempted from this Act. That effectively makes the Act hardly worth the paper it is printed upon. The situation can only be described as a disgrace. The legislation to protect Tasmania's environment must be amended to do what it is supposed to do—protect the environment. As it is, the people of Tasmania are faced with legislation in the shape in which it might have been in the 1940s. What is accepted as best environmental management practice in most of the developed world just does not exist here.

PARA.TAB: Many of the people of Lorinna have chosen to make the valley their home due to its cleanliness and proximity to pristine world heritage areas. But the Forestry Commission, by spraying herbicide in the local water catchment, has put at risk a valuable and potentially growing export market. The export market for Tasmanian organic food is set to boom. Rainwater from Tasmania is already sold overseas because of the demand for a pure product. That is an image which has rested easily upon Tasmania until now.

The food grown organically and exported will undoubtedly grow in volume in successive years partly, I must say, because on 3 May this year the Commonwealth Government commissioned the advertising agency Mojo to develop a clean food export strategy, at a cost of some $5 million. Quite rightly, the Commonwealth Government believes that it is worth investing that sort of money. Yet that sort of investment is jeopardised by the activities that have gone on under the auspices of the Tasmanian Government. Clean green Minister Crean quite rightly identifies with this push. I dare say that he should be offended by actions which compromise that clean green push. In Australia, in 1990, the Australian domestic organic market was worth some $28.7 million. In that year, in the United Kingdom, sales of organic produce were estimated to be worth $217 million—representing two per cent of total expenditure by British citizens in food shops. The West German health food cooperative Neuform sold $750 million worth of organic health food in 1985. The potential has been recognised by Minister Crean.

In the United States, Supermarket Business publication estimated that organic produce accounted for some $350-odd million of national retail sales. A share of this market, indeed access to this market, for a community like the one at Lorinna is vital if the community is to prosper sustainably and unemployment is to be affected favourably. But the actions of the Forestry Commission in splashing a residual herbicide around the catchment has put this budding sunrise Tasmanian industry at grave risk.

This market is particularly sensitive. Any food that has lost its organic accreditation status due to contamination by chemicals will not be sold on the sorts of markets that I have been describing. The market is an informed market. It is a market which seeks the certification, the signal, that the food has been properly accredited, and it is a market which is prepared to pay for that accreditation. Consumers of organic food usually are quite happy to pay 10 or 20 per cent more, with premium quality produce perhaps even commanding 40 per cent more, than conventionally produced foods. Things like organically produced chickens will command perhaps even 80 or 100 per cent above other retail prices.

A telephone poll of a thousand voters conducted on 1 May and 3 May 1989 established that 83 per cent of people would prefer food grown without chemicals even if it cost more. Only 16 per cent of those people polled said that it was sensible to use chemicals. The organic food producers of Lorinna are well aware of the fact that so many modern consumers feel very strongly about the food they eat and are prepared to pay considerably more for what they see as necessary for their wellbeing.

The organic producers at Lorinna are poised to gear up to cater for this growing industry. It would be extremely difficult to qualify for venture capital to start these organically sustainable projects on a larger scale if a bank or other leading institution perceived that there was a risk of them losing their accreditation due to circumstances beyond their control. That is really the crux of what I have been getting at tonight: the Forestry Commission has, despite protestations, gone ahead in its usual red-necked manner and put at risk the necessary accreditation that producers of organic foods must have in order to gain access to those organic markets.

Whatever senators may personally feel about organically grown produce, the fact is that there is a growing demand for this clean food. That demand must not be jeopardised by the actions of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission. If the Tasmanian State Government is to have any credibility in protecting the environment it will amend the Environment Protection Act to allow for the prosecution of government departments that are found

SPEECH.PARA: acting outside the law with a nod and a wink exemption from the Minister. The current situation is unacceptable and deserves the attention of all Australians, not just the members of this place. It is something which should not be tolerated by any Australians.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 30 March 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the department routinely disseminate or circulate all or some of the media releases of its responsible Minister or Ministers, to organisations apart from national media organisations; if so, for what reasons are Ministerial media releases circulated by the department, and to how many individuals or organisations.

(2) For each, and which, Ministerial media release circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the releases, and how many copies of the release were circulated.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Prime Minister and Cabinet: Advertising Campaigns

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the details of all advertising campaigns to be undertaken by the department and agencies in 1992-93, including, in each case: (a) the campaign; (b) its cost; (c) its purpose; and (d) the name of the company or agency undertaking the campaign.
(2) Are there any proposals for additional campaigns to be undertaken in the near future.
(3) Given the imminence of the Federal election, could the information be provided by 13 May 1993.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question. It should be noted that the response does not include any recruitment activity in respect of the portfolio:

ANSWER.PARA: OFFICE OF THE STATUS OF WOMEN

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) The Commonwealth Community Education Program on violence against women is a three year program from 1992-93 to 1994-95.

(b) It has funding of $3.48 million for the three years, and is being implemented by the Office of the Status of Women (OSW).In Year 1 of this program, 1992-93, a sum of $25,000 has been spent on the development of promotional material. Of this amount, $5000 was spent on concept testing, and the remainder in the development of the posters. A further sum of up to $275,000 has been allocated for the printing and national marketing and distribution of the posters.

(c) The Community Education Program on violence against women aims to contribute to the elimination of violence against women. The four posters are designed to encourage the community to discuss the issues.
(d) Barbara Riley-Smith concept tested the material—$5000; and Pemberton Advertising developed the posters—$20,000.
(2) There are no proposals for other campaigns to be undertaken in the near future.

ANSWER.PARA: OFFICE OF THE INTERNATIONAL YEAR OF THE FAMILY

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) The Office of the International Year of the Family has printed and distributed an Information Kit as the initial part of its International

ANSWER.PARA: Year of the Family (IYF) Communications Awareness Campaign.

PARA.TAB: (b) The cost for the second release (printing only) was $16,994. Estimated costs for the third release are $10,300 excluding printing.
(c) The purpose of the Awareness Campaign is to stimulate interest and encourage participation in the Year from all sectors of the community.

(d) The first and second releases were produced in collaboration with the Public Affairs Branch of the former Department of Health Housing and Community Services, and the latest proposed version will be handled by the Billy Blue Group, located in North Sydney.
(2) There are no proposals at present for additional campaigns to be undertaken in the near future.

ANSWER.PARA: COMMONWEALTH OMBUDSMAN

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) A three week advertising campaign was conducted in November 1992 in the Liverpool, NSW, area. It consisted of press advertisements; radio advertisements in the four ethnic languages, in Koori and in English; outdoor poster advertisements; and a one week promotion at the main shopping centre conducted by Ombudsman staff.
(b) The cost of the campaign was $17,200, which included $5,600 for an external evaluation by the Roy Morgan Research Centre Pty Ltd.

(c) The purpose of the campaign was to raise the level of awareness of the Ombudsman and was specifically aimed at people from non-English speaking backgrounds, young people, people on low incomes and Aboriginal people.
(d) Neville Jeffress.
(3) Yes.
